description:
Argo Park is located right behind City Hall and features a disc golf course, playgrounds, a picnic pavilion, and a paved running/walking path. 

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
The lot closest to the park is level, but the lot near the road has a severe cross-slope. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically at least 4 feet wide. 

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

Enjoy this 2.0-mile loop trail near Montgomery, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 38 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Get to know this 2.5-mile loop trail near Daphne, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 52 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Explore this 0.8-mile loop trail near Tuscaloosa, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 14 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are November through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 1.5-mile loop trail near McCalla, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 31 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Check out this 2.4-mile loop trail near Jasper, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 59 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and fishing, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through June. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Cutchenmine Trail is a leisurely hike with beautiful water views along the way. There are benches with a view of the lake along the trail to rest. There is a small pull-off area at the trailhead. If you don't have room to park here, head toward the Short Creek Boat Ramp, where you'll find a parking lot with picnic tables and restrooms.

This featured ride is long, flowing, fun, and covers all of the trails in the Forever Wild Trails system without relying on the fire roads.

This ride covers all of the trails and boardwalks on the Forever Wild Property. It does not cover all of the Emergency Roads. Starting on the Flowers Chapel Road side, warm up on the Beaver Tail Flats and then go on the boardwalks on Connector A to Connector B and then turn left on Connector B and make your way to Zion Cemetery Ridge. 

Turn left and go to the large junction and turn left on the upper part of the Big Levee trail. Make your way around to S.A.M.'s Creekside Trail. After that, continue on Big Levee back to the main junction. Take the fast track back to the parking lot and then head back to Connector B. After crossing the connector, go left to Stagecoach Plateau and go left at the T-intersection to go to Dragon's Tail. Turn left onto Dragon's Tail and when you reach the end of this trail, start heading back to the parking area by using Stagecoach Plateau and Connector A.
Contacts

Experience this 1.0-mile loop trail near Hayden, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 27 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 1.5-mile loop trail near Hoover, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 36 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Historic Bridgeport Walking Trail starts at the Bridgeport Depot Museum. It leads to the Tennessee River, where you can cross on a converted railroad bridge with an active train line running parallel. The trail is a peaceful, scenic one-mile out-and-back route, mostly flat after a short incline from the museum parking lot, with shaded portions in the park and sunny areas across the bridge. You can enjoy river views, passing trains, and river traffic below along the way. Visitors can explore the museum before or after the walk, adding a historical touch to the scenic experience.

Head out on this 2.2-mile loop trail near Trussville, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 48 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This route leads to the King's Chair overlook, with significant elevation gain before looping back via the Far End Back Trail. The scenic overlook provides stunning southward views, making the climb worthwhile. Well-behaved dogs on a leash are welcome, and there's a nearby picnic and primitive camp spot at the overlook.

Enjoy this 0.7-mile out-and-back trail near Tuscaloosa, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 20 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Head out on this 5.4-mile loop trail near Huntsville, Alabama. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 14 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 2.4-mile loop trail near Fort Payne, Alabama. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 54 min to complete. This is a very popular area for camping and hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 1.7-mile loop trail near Birmingham, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 36 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking and walking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 4.0-mile loop trail near Birmingham, Alabama. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 41 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 0.6-mile loop trail near Birmingham, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 12 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through May. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 1.8-mile loop trail near Pelham, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 51 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking, mountain biking, and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through July. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This trail offers convenient parking access to the trailhead without having to drive too far into the park. You'll start with the Green Trail, which eventually connects to the White Trail and takes you right by the falls. Although there are a couple of challenging spots that might get your heart rate up, overall it's a very enjoyable hike. Keep in mind that the falls may be dry during certain seasons, so it's best to visit after heavy rainfall if you want to see them at their best.

Explore this 3.2-mile loop trail near McCalla, Alabama. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 10 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through November.

Come prepared for a challenging hike as the trail is rocky, rugged, and requires a high level of fitness. You will encounter poison ivy along the way, so be cautious. Some sections of the trail have been impacted by fallen trees, but they are manageable to navigate around. It is important to note that there is a particularly risky section of the trail where you will need to navigate unstable rocks for a significant distance. Despite the challenges, the trail offers beautiful views that can be enjoyed from various points along the way.

The Pisgah Gorge trail offers a scenic route through wooded areas and along the gorge's edge. Expect views of the gorge's rock formations and a beautiful waterfall, as well as some river views. It's a peaceful and quick trail, perfect for those looking to enjoy a quiet hike in nature with some nice vantage points along the way.

This is a nice and peaceful walk through the Service Park forest close to the Tombigbee River- there is also access to the river at this park. There are not many views along the trail, however, there are many opportunities to view wildlife and wildflowers. The trail can become muddy during wet conditions and waterproof shoes are recommended.

Explore this 0.7-mile out-and-back trail near Fort Payne, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 19 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through June.

This route features a mesmerizing waterfall and breathtaking views of Sipsey Canyon. Some sections of the trail are poorly maintained, so an offline map may be necessary for navigation. Despite these difficulties, the trail has some fantastic features, including the stunning East Bees Branch falls that are worth the hike. Towards the southern end, you'll encounter some beautiful and secluded areas.

Explore this 3.9-mile out-and-back trail near Huntsville, Alabama. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 44 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

About halfway down the trail, you'll encounter a spring that adds lovely feature to the hike. While the water flow isn’t particularly impressive in the summer, it becomes quite lively in the spring. There's a nice bench nearby where you can relax and enjoy the surroundings. 

Though this short trail features some elevation that increases the difficulty, it's manageable with a bit of extra time and effort.

Get to know this 16.9-mile out-and-back trail near Sylacauga, Alabama. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 5 h 47 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This route features a pleasant and easy hike through a forested area where wildlife is abundant. This trail is intended to be multi-use and is shared by mountain bikers, horseback riders, and hikers.

For more information on the Chapman Mountain Nature Preserve and trails in the area, please visit their website at https://www.landtrustnal.org/properties/chapman-mountain-preserve/

Get to know this 0.5-mile loop trail near Birmingham, Alabama. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 14 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

The first few segments of the White Falls are on system trails, 201 and 209. When 209 meets the Sipsey Fork, one must go off trail (although there is an impacted foot path, it is still considered off trail) and hike downstream and then go up the first drainage which is White Creek. One will then arrive at the falls and the upper falls is above that. 

Note that trying to reach the upper falls is VERY dangerous with one spot having a 30 foot drop off merely a few feet away.

Try this 1.2-mile loop trail near Wasilla, Alaska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 28 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 2.4-mile out-and-back trail near Anchorage, Alaska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 8 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.
This trail is closed. We'll update this page if and when it reopens.

Head out on this 1.7-mile loop trail near Fairbanks, Alaska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 46 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, mountain biking, and snowshoeing, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 3.0-mile out-and-back trail near Juneau, Alaska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 19 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through August.

Discover this 4.2-mile out-and-back trail near Homer, Alaska. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 16 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

The Eielson Alpine Trail is a very steep hike of around 1,000 feet. The trail travels up to Thorofare Ridge. The views are particularly impressive on clear days! During the summer wildflowers are in bloom in the open meadows. Wildlife such as caribou and marmots can sometimes be spotted along the way.

Discover this 0.9-mile out-and-back trail near Stevens Village, Alaska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 26 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Explore this 7.5-mile out-and-back trail near Juneau, Alaska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 10 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through September.

Fort Abercrombie State Historical Park is the historic ruins of a World War II coastal defense installation. Its trails travel the length of surf-pounded cliffs, below deep spruce forests, and through meadows bursting with wildflowers. This route stays to the north, passing through the campground and the Kodiak Military History Museum, which offers gorgeous views of the Gulf of Alaska.

The Gold Stream Winter Trail is accessible year-round and travels through wetlands and a dense riparian environment. Although it is open year-round, there will be sections of this route that are boggy and impassable in the spring and summer. Stay alert for wildlife and expect many mosquitos along the trail.

The Hidden Creek Trail offers a peaceful hike through Alaskan wilderness, winding through forests and along the creek. The trail leads to a secluded spot on the shores of Skilak Lake, making it a perfect escape into nature. This is a great trail with its mix of beautiful forested paths and scenic views over the Alaskan wilderness. This is quite an active bear area, with mostly black bears, but grizzly bears do frequent this area.

Experience this 0.7-mile loop trail near Hoonah, Alaska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 19 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through August.

Mat-Su College and Matanuska Lakes State Recreation Area host several trails through dense riparian forests. This route is a challenging and gorgeous loop, passing several lakes, including High Ridge, Baird, and Long Lakes. When recreating outdoors in Alaska, it is important to stay alert for wildlife and always carry bear spray.

This is a challenging and beautiful trail to the beginning of Indianhouse Mountain's south ridge. It requires prior experience hiking in the alpine and knowledge of off-route navigation and scrambling. Be prepared for wildlife encounters and inclement weather at any time of year. Given the exposure to the elements for most of the hike, there is a small window of time in the summer when this can be hiked without threat of snow conditions or weather.

Jewel Lake has a small parking area with a sandy beach and a designated swimming area. A trail heads north from the park, offering access to Sundi and Sands Lakes. Sand Lake is a primary, year-round spot for outdoor recreation. The lake is open to walking, cycling, and running in the summer, and the city grooms a perimeter path in the winter for cross-country skiing. Ice fishing is also popular.

Get to know this 1.4-mile loop trail near Ester, Alaska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 37 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, snowshoeing, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 5.1-mile out-and-back trail near Haines, Alaska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 4 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Mouth of Peter's Creek Park offers a short trail through dense riparian forest to the shores of Knik Arm. This is a popular place for fishing and recreating, and when the tide is low, you can hike along the beach. Be careful in the intertidal zone when the tide is low; it is very boggy and can behave like quicksand if you stand in it too long.

Northwood Park is a small and scenic marshland surrounded by a dense neighborhood. It has a donut-shaped lake with unique brown water and a metal boardwalk that leads to a wildlife viewpoint. Two trails travel on the north and south perimeter of the park. There is always a chance for a wildlife encounter, and waterfowl are common here.

This 3-km loop traverses a southwestern facing hillside with aspen-birch-spruce boreal forest, with nice views of the O’Connor Creek valley. The loop, which can be accessed from September Court, combines portions of the O’Connor Ridge Trail (green) and the middle portion of the O’Connor View Trail (yellow markers). The trail has an elevation range of 70 m and mostly has a gentle grade appropriate for intermediate level cross-country skiers. A portion of the trail traverses a north-facing black spruce woodland with thick moss that can be spongy in the summer. With a maximum elevation of around 485 m, it can be considerably warmer than the valley bottom on a cold winter afternoon. There are maps of the local trail network as various points along the trail. As there are many other trails in the area, it is best to have a GPS track of the trail. A map of the trail network can be downloaded at  https://www.interioralaskatrails.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/Oconnor-Ridge-Trails-Map-2021.pdf

The Mendenhall Glacier Visitor Center allows access to gorgeous, wild trails through the riparian environment south of Mendenhall Lake. This route heads south on the Old River Trail to Moraine Lake, and follows a trail around the lake. Always be bear aware and stay alert for wildlife on the trails in Alaska.

Explore this 5.1-mile out-and-back trail near Kodiak, Alaska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 40 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Check out this 7.3-mile out-and-back trail near Kupreanof, Alaska. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 5 h 17 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

The long stretch of shoreline south of the Bartlett Cove docks allows for a pleasant stroll. You could walk for miles. An extended hike to Point Gustavus (six miles one way) can be completed in a full day. Low tide reveals a myriad of intertidal life. (Please walk carefully!) It's a terrific place to see land, shore and sea birds. Listen for the breathing of humpback whales, feeding sea otters, and bald eagles. Flowers are profuse in mid-summer on the beach meadows. Let the magic of Glacier Bay surround you for an hour or even a full day.

Check out this 1.0-mile out-and-back trail near Ketchikan, Alaska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 27 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Seaton Recreation Area is located along the Alaska Highway and offers a picnic pavilion and multiple trails, including an interpretive loop trail around Seaton Lake. This route loops around the lake and follows trails within the thick boreal forest.

Always be alert for wildlife on the trail and carry bear spray.

Follow along this trail as it winds through a valley of eroded volcanic activity and interesting geological features. Explore the jagged peaks in the distance created by Skookum Creek Volcano many years ago where volcanic ash and hot gasses flowed down the volcano to make the tan and gray rocks you see today.

Head out on this 2.8-mile loop trail near Fairbanks, Alaska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 20 min to complete. This trail is great for cross-country skiing, hiking, and horseback riding, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October.

Head out on this 1.8-mile loop trail near Fairbanks, Alaska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 54 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October.

Explore this 12.8-mile out-and-back trail near Cooper Landing, Alaska. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 7 h 4 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through August.

Discover this 5.7-mile out-and-back trail near Glennallen, Alaska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 52 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

The Wasilla Creek Boardwalk is just as it sounds: a half-mile-long boardwalk alongside the slow-moving Wasilla Creek that ends at a small viewing platform. The boardwalk is narrow—if someone is coming in the opposite direction, there will be a bit of a squeeze to move past them. Take caution, as the boardwalks can accumulate a thin layer of ice in colder weather, which is extremely slippery.

This trail offers beautiful views as it winds through narrow paths among the wild grass and flora. The canyon surrounds the path and provides a stunning landscape with saguaros and cacti along the canyon walls. The trail requires several creek crossings, and there are shade trees around the creek. Be cautious of loose rocks and rocks that jut up from the ground.  Wearing hiking shoes or boots is advisable. The area is home to lizards, birds, and various wildlife. Parking is available in a small section on the west side of the road.

Head out on this 5.1-mile out-and-back trail near Flagstaff, Arizona. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 47 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Turn right on Vernon Rd. from U.S. 60 and head in to town until you reach FR1361 and turn left. Drive down the rd into the mountains a few miles. The rd turns in to rd. 61. You can take the 2nd heavily trafficked road to the right in between mile markers 1 and 2. If you reach a fork in the road you have gone slightly too far. Maybe about a half mile in you will reach a stream. Park somewhere and follow the stream up and you will find a cool waterfall... continue on up and you’ll find a 2nd smaller water fall that is right next to the rd. Enjoy the scenery :)

Bull Spring Trail #34 is part of the Mazatal Wilderness Trail system and forms part of the Arizona Trail. This trail is accessible from the Doll Baby Trailhead and requires you to hike FR406 to get to the trail (No vehicles allowed).

Warning: This hike is very strenuous and requires a lot of time and water. The hike starts from the Doll Baby Trailhead and requires a 3.7 mile hike along FR406 before you get to the actual trail start point. Once on the trail, the first 1.5 miles is moderately level, then the 2 mile ascend begins to the top of the mountain. Once at the summit, views are great. It is difficult to find where Bull springs trail splits from the Arizona trail, but look for the Cairn to help find the trail. The trail then goes into more desolate landscape, with a few interesting points along the way to Bull Spring.

Please don't forget to grab a pass, as the gates are locked and codes are required to open them. For more information, please visit https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/tonto/recreation/camping-cabins/recarea/?recid=35555&actid=34.

It is recommended to use 4x4's and quads on the first wide sandy section. However, no motorized vehicles are permitted once you reach the hiking trail.

Not very challenging, an easy trail due to the steady (not steep) grade, almost flat with a few hills. Bring lots of water as there is no shade and wear good ankle support since it’s all rocky/gravel. Popular with OHVs and dirt bikes. In some areas it’s loose and sinking feeling almost like sand. Fun to make it to the Bunker Bar for a refreshment before heading back.

This route starts at the Aspen Creek Trailhead Parking lot and takes you on a steady incline until the trail ends. It is in the Prescott National Forest and offers well-marked trails, beautiful scenery, and plenty of shade among pine trees. At times, this area can get muddy, so make sure you prepare beforehand.

This trail starts from the parking lot off Old Walnut Canyon Road. You'll encounter rocky paths, wooded areas, and meadows along the way. Bird enthusiasts may catch glimpses of species like the Mexican jay, red-tailed hawk, and various hummingbirds. This route has minimal shade, so stay hydrated and protect yourself from the sun.

Head out on this 11.5-mile loop trail near Apache Junction, Arizona. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 8 min to complete. This trail is great for camping and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This trail is marked private for the Vistancia neighborhood only. Only residents and their guests are allowed access. For more information, visit: https://vistancia.com/life-at-vistancia/trail-parks/

This route is pretty flat, but there are enough curves and inclines to make it interesting. Be cautioned, this trail follows along a wash or waterway so changing weather conditions may influence this trail.

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Vistancia Boulevard at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. There does not appear to be a curb cut to access the trail at the start. The trail surface is paved concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

The Doe Mountain Trail offers stunning scenery, with some challenging and interesting terrain, and breathtaking panoramic views from atop a mesa. From this trail, you can see Bear, Maroon, and Wilson Mountains, as well as Secret Canyons, Chimney Rock, and the Cockscomb. On a clear day, you can even catch a glimpse of Sedona in the distance, along with Munds Mountain and Sycamore Pass.

This trail begins about 100 yards past the end of the pavement on Bowes road. Park where you can on the slope south of the gate. The trail starts to the left of the gate and goes up to the ridge. The trail fades away after an hour or so, but just stick to the ridge until you approach the steep SW-facing slope of the first summit. Go right around a large outcrop, it'll be obvious. There are cairns at various points along that approach to the first summit that should help, especially in the descent, where it's easy to go wrong.  

Gibbon has two summits.The first one you reach after climbing that steep slope.   It's a large flat area with some cairns and a jar for signing in. That is not the true summit. The true summit you'll see to the east, about 10 minutes away.  It's smaller, but higher. There you will find an ammo box.

Head out on this 3.9-mile out-and-back trail near Safford, Arizona. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 22 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Experience this 14.6-mile out-and-back trail near Rio Verde, Arizona. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 53 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are November through April.

This paved pathway for walking, running, or cycling is a great way to take in some of the sights at this popular destination. Stop and relax at some of the best lookout points and trailheads in the park.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off Canyon Plaza Lane at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 1.4, 2.5, and 4.3 miles when going north. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

This trail is named after Louis D. Boucher, the "hermit" of the Hermit Creek basin, who lived in this area for 20 years. This route is recommended for experienced hikers. Due to the challenging terrain and time required, it is not advisable to complete the entire route to the Colorado River and back in one day. The trail is very exposed and not suitable for hiking during the summer. This is a great option for a multi-day backpacking adventure that avoids the crowds and allows you to savor solitude in the canyon.

The route starts from the Hermit Trail access and connects with the Tonto Trail and Hermit Creek Trail, leading to the banks of the Colorado River. The trailhead is located just west of Hermits Rest. To reach the trailhead, follow the dirt road from the restrooms. Access to Hermit Road is limited to shuttle buses from March 1st to November 30th. During this time, there is no day parking for personal vehicles, and hikers must use the free shuttle bus to access the trailhead. However, backpackers with a valid backcountry permit for the Hermit or Boucher Trails are allowed parking access.

This is a multi-directional trail that travels along some singletrack, dirt road, and wider trail sections. In addition to the elevation, the terrain poses technical challenges to mountain bikers. For riders, if you are only going the trail one way, start at the top and head down for a downhill-focused ride. This is a well-marked and maintained trail.

Explore this 3.2-mile out-and-back trail near Patagonia, Arizona. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are October through April. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

The Little Horse Trail is a part of the Bell Rock Pathway. To reach the destination, head south along the wide trail and take the old jeep road to the left at the fork marked with basket cairns. The road drops to cross a dry streambed, climbs a bit, and ends at the 0.75-mile point. From there, continue to the left on the trail, which climbs moderately and reaches a large, flat expanse. Turn right here and follow the level trail into a stand of Arizona cypress. The trail intersects Chapel Trail from the Chapel of the Holy Cross, near the "Madonna and the Nuns" spire rock formation. Keep going for a short while, passing the base of the knobs of Chicken Point on the left. Then, take the path to the left for a short climb onto the bare rock and enjoy the wonderful views. This point is used by jeep tours via Broken Arrow Road.

Try this 7.0-mile out-and-back trail near Duncan, Arizona. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 40 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This trail may present some challenges as it consists of sandy and rocky terrain, with several parts overgrown. However, it runs parallel to the water, making it an excellent spot to bring your furry friends. The water level may vary due to the rain level. You can enjoy picturesque views of the forest, creek, and rec rock formations along the way.

The Old Man Corona Loop highlights the preserve's diverse vegetation, hills, and ridges as it winds through a desert landscape. Clearly defined switchbacks lead up a steep hill to a ridge from which you can enjoy stunning views of the city and the preserve.

Be cautious of loose gravel on the steep inclines as you approach the switchbacks. Once you reach the ridge, you will be treated to a panoramic view of Eagle Pass and the surrounding desert terrain.

This loop trail starts at the end of West Staggs Road in Sanctuary Cove and leads into Saguaro National Park. It offers stunning views of Safford Peak and Tucson. Due to limited shade along the route, wear sun protection and bring plenty of water. The trail is rocky, with numerous loose and embedded stones, so sturdy hiking shoes are highly recommended. Along the way, you'll be surrounded by beautiful desert scenery with a variety of unique wildlife and vegetation.

The trail to Pilot Rock is an old mining road that leads to a dark red lava rock outcrop in the Colorado River. This landmark was historically used by steamboat pilots for navigation. Today, Pilot Rock continues to assist modern boaters, marked by a navigation light that blinks from its summit at night.

Pilot Rock is the highest point in Petrified Forest National Park, but there are no trails that lead to it, and there are no petrified fossils in its vicinity. Most visitors can get a closer view from a viewpoint along the road at Kachina Point.

Discover this 12.3-mile point-to-point trail near Yuma, Arizona. Generally considered an easy route. This trail is great for off-road driving, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through March.

Sears Kay Ruin is a historical site that offers visitors a glimpse into a unique lifestyle long before Columbus. You can take a self-guided loop to explore the Hohokom Ruins. The site was first occupied in around 1500 AD and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. 

Please help protect this national heritage, which is a priceless resource. If you witness any looting or vandalism at this or any other archeological or historic site, please call 1-800-VANDALS.

Check out this 4.1-mile loop trail near Tucson, Arizona. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 48 min to complete. This is a very popular area for birding and hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are September through May. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

This route begins at the Bill Hall Trailhead and begins along the Bill Hall Trail. Travel through rugged terrain along the majority of the way, with many sections exposed to full sun. There are several designated campsite areas along Thunder River Trail and Tapeats Creek Trail. Enjoy some of the more remote views of the Grand Canyon with incredible opportunities to admire vistas along the way.

The route is best enjoyed as a multi-day backpacking trail with several camping options located along the way. For information on camping permits and reservations, please visit the NPS website at https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/permitsandreservations.htm

Discover this 5.7-mile loop trail near Happy Jack, Arizona. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through September.

It is recommended to have a 4x4 vehicle to reach the trailhead as the access road is not well-maintained. For more information and a guided tour, please visit https://www.blm.gov/visit/white-pocket-trailhead

This is an off-trail adventure to visit some beautiful geologic formations in Vermilion Cliffs National Monument.

Since there is no cell phone service in the area, it is advised to download the offline map ahead of time to help navigate.

The Williams Peak Loop Trail is a great ride for mountain bikers looking for a mix of forested sections and gentle climbs. The trail winds through pine forests and rugged terrain. Along the way, bikers will encounter rocky sections, and sweeping views of the surrounding mountains. With the the whole rest of the trail being downhill towards the car!

This easy, flat, paved trail runs on the south side of Eightmile Creek following the stream from Rotary Park to Harmon Park. The multi-use trail is well-marked, maintained, and excellent for walking, running, and cycling. Mowed grass flanks both sides of the path, with the creek running on one side and the treeline on the other with lush green leaves that bud with colorful displays in the spring. 

Accessibility:

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking  
It is unclear where there designated accessible parking is available right by the trailhead, but there are at least 6 designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles on the west side of the baseball fields in Rotary Park.

Surface  
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically 6 to 8 feet wide. A painted dividing line along most of the trail reduces the width.

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

The Arlie Moore Interpretive Trail is located in the Arlie Moore Recreation Area.  The trail is a double segment loop, approximately 1.3. miles (2.2 kilometers) in length.  The trail meanders through a mature southern pine forest.  In 2002, the trail was rehabilitated in large part due to a partnership grant from ALCOA.

In 2007 the National Recreation Reservation Service selected the Arlie Moore Interpretive Trail as one of America’s Top 25 Hiking Trails.

Rangers give interpretive walks along the trail pointing out plants, trees, and wildlife along the way.  All throughout the year, school groups and campers walk the shaded trail and enjoy the hidden sanctuary of this secluded little trail.

Bailey Falls is just a mile away from Falling Water Falls in the Richland Creek Wilderness area. After a stream crossing, there is a small stack of rocks on the right-pointing the way to bushwhack down the hill to Marie and the bottom of Bailey. Most of the trail follows along a wise horse trail that is relatively easy to navigate.

This route involves some light bushwhacking and follows an old road, and there are some parts where you'll need to venture off-trail. The hike is most enjoyable during late fall to early spring when there are fewer leaves on the trees.

The hike features two large waterfalls, several minor falls along a beautiful creek with large boulders, and two caves. You may explore one of the caves, but the other is off-limits to protect the local bats.

Built by hand in 1894, the historic stone-cut dam is a Black Bass Lake Trail landmark and one of the oldest in the Ozarks. Numerous bird species can be seen in Black Bass Lake, such as pileated woodpeckers, white-breasted nuthatches, and bald eagles. Visitors may also see ribbon snakes, slider turtles, and deer. The trail has excellent markings and is well-maintained. It winds between maples and grassy lakeshore, with mild inclines and breathtaking views.

While the roads are mostly accessible by standard vehicles, the last 1.5 miles include two rough spots where higher clearance is recommended—an SUV or 4WD is ideal. Consider alternatives to a low-clearance car.

Start on a clear vehicle/UTV trail. After about 0.8 miles, the trail veers left and begins descending. Continue until the trail makes another left and passes a downed tree. The trail ends shortly after—this is a good place to drop a GPS pin (Apple Maps can track your location even without service).

From here, turn about 70–90 degrees to your right and head downhill toward the creek. This section is steep, about a 40% grade, and closer to 0.5 miles. Once you reach the creek, turn left and you’ll likely find an ATV trail.

Explore this 4.3-mile point-to-point trail near Ponca, Arkansas. Generally considered an easy route. This is a popular trail for scenic driving, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Briscoe Falls is located right off the namesake road, and is an easy pull-off to catch a view of this magnificent waterfall. While there is not much hiking, this is still a great stop to make on the way to hiking trails. There is a beautiful pool at the base of the waterfall, which is great for dipping your feet in on a hot summer day.

5½ mile forest loop, plus optional spur trails, located in the Leatherwood Wilderness, Ozark National Forest, near Lone Rock, AR.  This loop network is connected to the Elephant Head loop to the north, via two connecting trails.  Dogs and horses allowed.  

The “Brush Creek Trail” trailhead is located on a high ridge in the wilderness section of the Ozark National Forest, 7 miles west of a similarly named trailhead on the Ozark Highlands Trail.  Non-maintained, unmarked trail network in Leatherwood Wilderness.  

The 5½ mile loop trail descends a long ridge on an old road trace with views of remote, rugged hollows.  The loop trail (clockwise) first descends a road trace 1.3 miles, leaves the road trace to and descends a single track footpath through Brush Creek Hollow, crosses Brush Creek, ascends the ridge slightly east of Cleveland Knob, and follows Brush Creek Road back to the trailhead.  There is one creek crossing, dry feet normally possible.  

A spur trail to the river adds 3 to 3½ miles, veering away to the east from the loop 1.3 miles from the trailhead.  The river spur trail continues on the old road trace across the top of High Burr Bluff, and descends steeply to the Buffalo River across from Sheep Jump Bluff.  Horse trails in the river bottom allow exploration.  The spur trail is steep, the river bottom is 660’ below the ridge top, and this spur trail more than doubles the loop trail mileage.  

Another spur trail to Leatherwood Creek leaves the loop trail at the same location 1.3 miles from the trailhead, and descends south into the canyon.  Leatherwood Creek is a deep canyon that features amazing geology and remote hollows, winding 8 miles to its confluence with the Buffalo River underneath High Burr Bluff.   Hikers can roam miles up and down L. Creek.

This stretch of the Buffalo River travels from Erbie to Ozark. From Erbie Access, the journey begins with a left sweep against a sandstone wall, leading into shaded pools and swimming holes named by former local farmers. About halfway to Ozark, Porch Bluff juts out on the river right before Sawmill Hollow, a wildflower haven in early spring with massive sycamore trees. The river's canopy opens up about a mile later, offering sunbathing spots on rock shelves, and just before the takeout, Briar Bluff towers over a clear swimming hole near Ozark Campground. Shuttle time between Erbie and Ozark is approximately 30 minutes.

This trail winds through the woods near the shore of the White River on a natural-surface path lined with limestone outcrops and hardwood forest. The terrain is gently rolling, offering shaded stretches beneath oaks and hickories and filtered views of the river through the trees. Trail-goers may spot great blue herons, wild turkeys, or deer along the way. Spring and fall bring bursts of color and the soothing sound of flowing water nearby.

Farkleberry Trail is a short lakeside trail along the southern shores of Lake Maumelle.  The current trail is about 0.35-miles long.  Note that the original trail, according to signage at the site, was only 0.13-miles long, but has obviously been extended and has potential to grow longer.  This short walk offers nice views of the lake, bird watching opportunities, and wildflower viewing.

Lake Maumelle is a protected drinking water source and no swimming, wading, canoeing, kayaking, or any activity that allows bodily contact, is prohibited at this location.

This is an off-trail bushwhack. It is not a marked or well-traveled trail. The initial descent is very steep and involves 30% or more descent gradients. It is highly recommended that you download the GPS map, as the path can sometimes be confusing to follow. This route involves several creek crossings to access all three falls.

Enjoy this 3.0-mile out-and-back trail near Compton, Arkansas. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 8 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

This trail starts at the picnic area and crosses the highway and the head waters to  Shoal Creek. It meets the the Mossback Ridge Trail to make a loop with the North Rim Trail.

The area now occupied by the Greenfield Picnic Area and the visitor center was a family farm before the Great Depression. The Greenfield Trail starts in the picnic area, crosses the highway and the headwaters of Big Shoal Creek, and meets the Mossback Ridge Trail. It climbs 210 feet in elevation. This is a good place to start a 14-mile hike to Cove Lake. (Green Blazes) A .3-mile spur leads down an old wagon road to Turkey Springs.

Try this 2.7-mile loop trail near Hot Springs, Arkansas. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 21 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Get to know this 2.9-mile loop trail near Arkadelphia, Arkansas. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 5 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping, hiking, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This trail circles Lions Club Park and Golf Course. The trail, locally known as the Leslie Darden Memorial Trail, is paved and wide, with a small hill at the beginning and another just after the halfway point. Most of the path is shaded by tall trees with some sun exposure on the west 1/3 of the loop. This loop is great for spotting many local and migratory bird species.

Accessibility:

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Surface  
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically 4 to 6 feet wide.

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info  
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

This scenic hike follows a well-defined trail through a dense forest, leading to a series of cascading waterfalls along a rocky riverbed. The route includes gentle elevation changes and a mix of dirt and rock surfaces, making for a moderately easy trek. The falls tumble over rugged rock formations into clear pools, creating a peaceful and picturesque setting perfect for nature lovers and photographers alike.

This is a quick hike to Longpool Falls. To find the waterfall, go from the parking area, walk over to the Loop B camp area, and go all the way to the back. There is an old road that travels between campsites #14 and 9. Take the road past the water tank, continue uphill just a little, and then downhill. You will reach the waterfall on the right.

This moderate trail leads through scenic rock formations and picturesque waterfalls, offering a peaceful and rewarding experience. Following a rocky creek bed with multiple crossings before reaching a stunning waterfall, the terrain is uneven, requiring careful navigation over loose rocks and fallen logs.

A hike to Nebo Springs and down Nebo Steps.

A delightful hike to moss-covered Nebo Springs begins behind the visitor center on the Rim Trail.  Turn right onto the Rim Trail then down Nebo Steps (light blue) to the Bench Road Trail.  Turn right on the bench and follow until you get to the sign for Nebo Springs.  The climb back up Nebo Springs Trail, then right onto the Rim Trail, completes a rectangular "circle." Highly recommended for the historical significance and natural beauty, this loop is, however, strenuous.  The stone enclosure of Nebo Springs, located directly below the bench, dates back to the 1800's. Children were often sent to the spring
with buckets to fetch water for meals.

According to Accessible Nature (https://www.accessiblenature.info/?page_id=324): This trail is wheelchair accessible and now fully paved. This trail begins at the visitor center. Signage informs visitors about the plants, animals, and geology of the area. An overlook area provides wonderful views of it all too.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of State Highway 12 at the west end of the trail. 2 of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with partial edge barriers) and smooth. It is typically at least 4 feet wide with many wider passing spaces.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) but there are steeper sections at about 1200 and 2000 feet when going counterclockwise. According to the park website, this trail is wheelchair-accessible and ADA-compliant. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. The visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

Enjoy this 1.7-mile loop trail near Murfreesboro, Arkansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 36 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 6.9-mile loop trail near Bella Vista, Arkansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 38 min to complete. This trail is great for mountain biking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through December. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Razorback Regional Greenway is a primarily off-road shared-use trail that connects the communities of Northwest Arkansas, including Fayetteville, Springdale, and Bentonville. This extensive trail system offers a scenic journey through diverse landscapes, including forests, wetlands, and urban areas, providing ample opportunities for photography and sightseeing. Along the way, hikers and cyclists can enjoy views of local attractions and various parks and recreational areas. The Greenway also passes through downtown areas, offering access to local shops, restaurants, and cultural sites. Whether you're interested in hiking, cycling, or simply enjoying a peaceful walk on sections of this trail, this is a great way to explore the towns of Arkansas.

This crushed granite hiking trail is a pedestrian-only trail with rock bluffs on one side and overlooking views of the Crystal Bridges Museum Of American Art's north lawn and the Crystal Bridges Trail on the other. This trail runs parallel to Crystal Bridges and Dogwood Trails.

The name for this trail is derived from the rock bluffs once carved into the hills to make way for a nineteenth-century railroad that was planned but never completed. The Rock Ledge Shelter offers a place to rest and enjoy nature.

Explore this 4.1-mile out-and-back trail near Siloam Springs, Arkansas. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 15 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Serendipity Interpretive Trail is nestled in the beautiful Ouachita National Forest near Oden. This gravel path features informative signs along the way that share interesting facts about the forest, including the various layers of trees and the plants and animals that inhabit the area. Depending on the season, you might encounter tall pines, sturdy oaks, and even some wildflowers. It’s an ideal spot for a gentle walk, where you can learn something new and enjoy the beauty of nature. There are also benches available if you want to take a break and soak in the surroundings.

Smuggler's Run features a narrow trail that winds through cliffs and offers stunning views. The trail is shared with mountain bikers. You'll find benches along the mostly paved path to rest and take in the surroundings. The terrain is mainly rocky, with striking rock walls and cave-like structures. It's a well-maintained area.

The Sylamore Scenic Byway comprises a 26.5-mile portion of Arkansas State Highways 5 and 14, along with Forest Service Road 1110. The route traverses 16.5 miles of Arkansas State Highway 5 from Calico Rock to Allison, joining Arkansas State Highway 14 for 6.7 miles to its intersection with Forest Service Road 1110. There are beautiful stops along the way to go for a hike, check out a roadside waterfall, or simply admire the surrounding forest.

Get to know this 3.5-mile out-and-back trail near Bentonville, Arkansas. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 17 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November.

A beautiful park with lots of flowers, a creek, and a paved walking trail. There's even a play castle for the little ones, plus many benches on which to rest and a history lesson thrown in for educational purposes.

Accessibility: There is one designated accessible space in the parking area off of North Wilson Avenue in the center of the trail. It is van-accessible with an access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges), smooth, and typically at least 4 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 0.4 miles heading clockwise. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.5 - 0.8 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

The Ahwingna Trail starts at the parking lot off Orange Grove Avenue and leads to Whittier Hill in Puente Hills Preserve. The trail winds through hilly terrain with a steady incline, ending at a scenic water tower. Be prepared for steep sections with dirt and rocky parts that can be slippery—sturdy footwear is recommended. Your effort will be rewarded with expansive views of Los Angeles.

This is a beautiful stroll along the stream at the bottom of Aliso Canyon. The trail crosses the stream in several places, but it's usually shallow, and there are rocks to walk on. 

The first part of the tail is nice and shaded before opening up to full sun as you walk right down the middle of Aliso Canyon Park. Along this popular route, there are many wildflowers and wildlife to admire.

The Badwater Basin is the lowest point in all of North America, at 282 ft (86 m) below sea level. The Salt Flats trail goes right through it, offering visitors an opportunity to see the salt polygons that Death Valley is known for. Despite the basin’s name, the water here isn’t necessarily “bad,” just very salty. 

Accessibility: Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade. There are 3 designated accessible parking spaces in the paved parking lot with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved and wooden boardwalk (with edge barriers and partial railings) or a natural (salt and sand) surface. It is typically at least 5 feet wide. This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less). There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the east end of the trail.

For more information, check out Wheelchair Traveling: (https://wheelchairtraveling.com/death-valley-national-park-wheelchair-travel-hiking/).

Begin from a small parking area along Mulholland Drive. This lot only accommodates 15 or so cars, so an early start is recommended. The trail is mostly wooded, but at a few points, there are better viewpoints. The path is close to private property at points, so please remain on trail. Downloading the route beforehand will help navigate the trails and stay off the private property. 

This route can also be started from the other end at Coldwater Canyon Park.

The trail is a great loop that offers some challenge, and will get your heart pumping!  Expect moderate inclines, but little shade. The trail offers sweeping views throughout most of the adventure, with a fairly wide dirt path. The path is wide enough to walk side-by-side as you travel through rolling hills and meadows. You may even see deer and other wildlife on the trail!

Another section of the network of interconnected trails surrounding the HB / Bolsa Chica ecological center, a bird-watching hotspot. Great place to walk but no bikes are allowed.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Warner Avenue at the northwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is gravel or a natural surface (dirt, rocks). It is typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section at about 0.8 miles when going south. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. There are benches along the route for resting.

Great hike in Irvine. The trails are well-maintained, wide, and the area is quiet. You will see many other hikers, runners, and mountain bikers on the weekends. There is little to no shade along the way, so bring plenty of water and sun protection. The trails are well-marked. There are nice views along the way.

Hours: 7am - Sunset

This loop takes you from the Martson Point gateway to the Martson house and Upas Street entrance, looping back via the west end park trails. You'll pass the Pine Grove picnic area, Cypress Point picnic area, Redwood Circle, and the Bowling Green. There are a few spots along the way to stop at restroom facilities. You'll also pass Nate's point dog park right before going under the Cabrillo Bridge.

This trail is a short, quiet hike through a pine forest and alongside a creek that ends at Carlon Falls - a series of cascading waterfalls. This trail enters into Yosemite National Park, and dogs are not allowed past the national park boundary. This is a great trail to cool off from the summer heat. This trail can sometimes be overgrown or blocked by downed trees, so downloading offline maps can help you navigate the trail.

The Colby Canyon to Strawberry Meadow trail in California offers a scenic and challenging hike through the Angeles National Forest. Starting at Colby Canyon, the trail ascends steadily. As you climb up you will get breathtaking views of the surrounding mountains. The trail includes a variety of terrain, with rocky sections and steep climbs, making it an excellent option for those looking for a more strenuous hike. This hike is more about the journey rather than the destination, if you are looking for a more clear end point, consider hiking Strawberry Peak from the same trailhead, but there is some scrambling at the top!

Check out this 8.8-mile out-and-back trail near Milpitas, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 33 min to complete. This trail is great for horseback riding, road biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Eagle Mountain is the highest peak in the range, although it is less popular than some of the other hikes in Joshua Tree National Park. The first half of the hike climbs gently, and the last mile to the 5,350-foot summit is relentlessly steep. It is advised to download this map to follow the route.

This hike should only be considered by experienced adventurers and avoided in the peak of summer. Although it does not require any technical climbing skills, this route is off trail, requires some scrambling, and is exposed to the sun without any shade or water on the trail.

Folsom Powerhouse State Historic Park, on a scenic bluff overlooking the west bank of Lake Natoma, will take you back in time to a pivotal and colorful period in California’s history. The 1895 plant, one of the oldest hydroelectric facilities in the world, was one of the nation’s first power systems to provide high-voltage alternating current over long-distance transmission lines for major municipal and industrial use. Its significance has earned it a place on the National Register of Historic Places.

The south end is at Franklin Creek Park. This opens up to tight switchbacks that climb to utility roads. The utility roads are well-signed as the route twists and rolls through the foothills. After about 5 and a half miles, the trail leaves the road and climbs to the top. This section is still rough with many obstacles. After about 8 miles, the Divide Peak OHV Route is reached. The trail continues directly across this but may be hard to see. Follow the overgrown flatter area west through reaching trees and it should become easier to follow as it goes. Alder Creek Camp is about a half mile below and easily recognized. Blackberries toward the bottom can make travel there difficult as well as the initial navigation up the trail from that side.

The George Wolfberg Park at Potrero Canyon was established in 2022 and is a mile-long passive park with trails in and above the canyon. The area protects the riparian habitat and only allows passive recreation such as hiking and running. There are meadows throughout the canyon and expansive views of the Pacific Ocean. Parking is available at Palisades Recreation Center.

Out and back to a nice swimming area.

This trail leads to swimming holes along the South Yuba River and historic Hoyt Crossing, a popular hangout for skinny-dippers and other river lovers in summer.  Southern exposure means warmth on cool days and wildflowers in the spring. 

An optional extension up the old Hoyt Crossing Road makes for a vigorous 4.5-mile in-and-out hike.

This loop takes you to Fern Falls. The falls are best viewed in the spring, or after a good amount of rain. The trail offers a moderate amount of shade, but part of the hike is very steep. Keep your eye out for wildflowers, butterflies, and even California newts near the falls. It's also a good idea to wear pants and take precautions against poison oak and ticks, as they are both present along the trail.

Enjoy this 6.2-mile out-and-back trail near Lawndale, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 48 min to complete. This trail is great for road biking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This route follows a paved road around Lake Cascade. Please use caution if sharing the road with motor vehicles as there is not a protected shoulder here...the use of reflective strips, lights, or flagging is recommended on any wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the way for resting.

This loop travels along the hillside above Lake Poway. At points, you can access the shoreline. Near the two-mile mark, you will hike above the dam. There are some benches along the way to stop and rest at and enjoy the views.

Bees are often in the area, so it is advised you carry an Epipen if you are allergic.

This route travels up to a wonderful viewpoint of the Los Angeles skyline. Benches are in place at several spots along the loop to rest and enjoy the view. During the spring months, wildflowers can be spotted growing along the hillside. For the most part, the trail is wide enough to walk side by side with a hiking partner. There are many side trails, so downloading offline maps is recommended.

Head out on this 7.7-mile out-and-back trail near Lee Vining, California. Generally considered a challenging route. This is a popular trail for backpacking, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are May through October.

This is a great loop around Griffith Park with nice views along the way. There are spots to view the Hollywood Sign, and the trail also passes by Griffith Observatory. The observatory is a great option for a pit-stop along your hike - go inside and explore the exhibits. The loop can be hiked in either direction. Trekking poles are recommended, as there are a few steep/rocky sections.

The Pioneer Trail spans the entire distance between Five Mile House and White Cloud along Highway 20 within the national forest. To complete this entire route, you'll need to set a recovery vehicle or shuttle at one end. The route will take you past several features including Skillman Campground, Chalk Bluff, Bear Valley, and the South Yuba River. The Pioneer Trail crosses several roads in the Tahoe National Forest throughout its length, and travels along Bowman Lake Road for a short distance a few times during the trip. 

The Pioneer Trail is a result of a twenty year project by the Gold Country Trails Council and the Forest Service. Most of this trail was entirely volunteer-constructed. In 2003, The Pioneer Trail was designated as a National Recreation Trail.

This trail begins at the North Lake Campground and winds through a large valley, before reaching Puite Pass, which overlooks the Humphrey's Basin. This trail is a great access point for many larger backpacking trips in the Sierra. There are many beautiful lakes and streams along the way. Keep in mind that there is no day-use or overnight parking in the campground. You will need to park in the parking lot near the Bishop Pack Outfitters and walk the road to the trailhead.

A lovely trail along a creek surrounded by redwoods. With a permit, one can camp anywhere along the creek (away from the bridges), the only place in the park where camping is allowed outside a campground. 

This area is hiker access only, bikes, pets, and horses aren't allowed. The bridges over the creek are only in place between June and September, other times of the year the creek may be too high to cross. Before building a campfire, check on the park website to make sure no fire restrictions are in place.

Located in San Bernardino National Forest, the trail up to Sugarloaf Mountain offers great views of San Gorgonio, southern California's highest peak. Although the summit area does not offer all-encompassing views, hikers will find good views along the ridge-line climb.

The parking area can be accessed south of Sugarloaf where Wild Horse Meadows Road intersects with Route 38. From here it is a nice hike down a dirt road to the trailhead. Sugarloaf trail will meander alongside Green Creek for the first two miles. If you have a 4WD vehicle, you can get 1.5 miles closer to the trailhead, by continuing up the dirt road.

Those interested in plants and trees will enjoy diverse species including the the mid-mountain White Firs, Jefferys and Ponderosas and the upper-mountain's Manzanitas and Sugar Pines.

Get to know this 0.9-mile out-and-back trail near San Diego, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 24 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This is a great short hike up to Taft Point and The Fissures. The trail is well-marked the entire way. At Taft Point, enjoy magnificent views of Yosemite Valley, including El Capitan and Yosemite Falls. Near Taft Point, you'll see The Fissures, narrow fractures in the granite called joints. Watch out for drops of up to 2,000 feet at these fractures! There is no railing surrounding Taft Point so be cautious, especially with children or in icy or slippery conditions.

The parking lot here can get closed off when it is full and there is a long line of waiting cars, so try to arrive early. Slot Canyon is an unmaintained trail off a sand road and far from most visitor traffic. Flash floods formed the breathtaking slot canyon. At points, forty-foot-high walls arch above a foot-wide canyon floor.

Twin Peaks are located at over 7,000 feet above sea level. This route will take you past Waterman Mountain (without summiting it) to the summit of the Twin Peaks. A good portion of this trail does have shade. The stretch after the saddle closer to the peak is a scramble with loose gravel and steep elevation gain. Trekking poles are highly recommended!

The Antelope Trail is a moderate to strenuous hike that climbs through open grasslands and forests. As it ascends, hikers and bikers are rewarded with incredible panoramic views of the Boulder Valley and the distant peaks. Both trails are a haven for wildlife, including pronghorn antelope, deer, rabbits, and various bird species, which makes for excellent wildlife watching opportunities.

This trail heads in a loop around the reservoir. Some areas are paved while others are gravel.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces in the paved parking lot near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is pavement or packed gravel and is typically at least 4 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Enjoy this 5.9-mile out-and-back trail near Antonito, Colorado. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 25 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

In the winter this road closes and then reopens typically in early late June/early July. Please reference this page for more closure information: https://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/arp/recreation/?cid=stelprdb5339508

Fun route with a variety of modest challenges. Skirts eastern border of Indian Peaks Wilderness and passes by historic Caribou Townsite. Great view from high point of trail includes Eldora Ski Area. Explore several marked side roads. Camp only in designated numbered sites. Unlicensed vehicles may find it more convenient to start at large parking area at Caribou Townsite. There is a $1,000 fine for riding across meadows at townsite. Open June 15 to Nov. 30, weather permitting. For current conditions call Roosevelt National Forest, Boulder Ranger District at (303) 541-2500.

Much of route is easy. North end has muddy section after creek crossing that can be impassable in worst-case scenario. South end, dropping down to Eldora, is steep and narrow with tight switchbacks. Long vehicles will be challenged here.

The Cottonwood South Trail near Buena Vista, Colorado, traverses the scenic high alpine ridge lines. Starting at Cottonwood Pass, the trail quickly climbs up towards the top of the ridge, getting the hardest part out the way. From here, you will be rewarded with epic views of the surrounding mountains and valleys. The route is in high-altitude terrain that is exposed to changing weather, making this trail ideal for summer exploration. Allow plenty of time and look to head out in the morning, as thunderstorms can be quite prevalent in summer time in this area.

You have a few routes to choose from if you want to boat in this area. One of the nicer options for a launch site is mapped here. This is an area off of Dillon Dam Road where kayakers and paddleboarders can access to Giberson Bay which has a handful of little islands and is generally a bit shallower. This area is safe for kayaking  or stand up paddleboarding as long as you know what you are doing.

This route takes you along the Fraser River Canyon Trail on a steady decline until you reach the Fraser River, where you will enjoy some nice waterfront views. This is a popular fishing spot, so come prepared if you want to fish a little. Some sections of the trail can get steep and rocky, so wearing sturdy footwear is recommended.

This is a great road bike route that will take you on a very long loop trip which circles around Golden Gate Canyon State Park and the White Ranch Open Space Park. With over 6,000 feet of elevation gain over 52 miles, this is not an easy ride, to say the least. Be ready for a very long workout and a very tough day.

The Government trail begins at the trailhead behind the baseball fields near the Recreation Center in western Aspen. Hikers should cross the pedestrian bridge over Maroon Creek and follow signs for "Government Trail". This is a long route with some very formidable climbs, so be prepared for an intense and exhausting hike. Also, the trail closes during elk calving season. For more information, please visit: https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/whiteriver/recreation/hiking/recarea/?recid=40495&actid=50

This trail has it all. From a gorgeous mountain lake  to sprawling wildflower meadows to snow-capped rocky peaks in the distance, this trail provides hikers with pretty much all the sights you wish for in a Colorado hiking trail. There's a ton of elevation gain on the way out to the lake, so be ready for an intense workout.
This trail is closed. We'll update this page if and when it reopens.

Head out on this 2.0-mile loop trail near Edwards, Colorado. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 54 min to complete. This trail is great for cross-country skiing, hiking, and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This is a "lollipop loop" hike out along Hunter Valley Trail. Lollipop loops are trails which are mainly an out-and-back style hike but with a short loop at the end. This hike actually begins on Hunter Creek Trail, following that route briefly before becoming Hunter Valley Trail. The short loop begins at the turnaround point, when hikers begin the return trip on Hunter Valley North Trail for a while before rejoining Hunter Valley Trail.

This trail begins at the Ivy Creek Campground and ends at the Continental Divide Trail (#813) near South River Peak.  The trail cuts through a conifer forest for about a mile before entering a long open meadow and continuing along the creek (with multiple crossings) for about 4 miles.  The next mile climbs almost 1,000 feet out of the Ivy Creek drainage along switchbacks.
