After passing Fisher Mountain Trail (#891), the trail continues south through parks and groves past Goose Lake (which offers primitive camp sites) and Little Goose Lake, then passes Goose Creek Trail (#827) before climbing another quick 1,000 feet in one mile to reach its endpoint at the CDT.

Located in downtown Estes Park, this 20-arce conservation easement permanently protects the open, natural character of it's wetlands, the Willows, and the rocky crest, the Knoll.  No pets or bicycles are permitted as the area is intended for passive recreation and education. The site includes two historic structures of Albert Birch, former city editor for the Denver Post.  The Ruins, a small, stone bungalow on the Knoll that was burned and The Cabin, a rustic log structure built right after the fire, down by the Willows.  Elk and bear are known to frequent the area.

This beautiful route takes you up to Kroenke Lake through the Horn Fork Basin. You'll begin climbing into the basin, eventually crossing North Cottonwood Creek. Kroenke Lake is a quaint, forested subalpine lake. The trail itself continues past the lake to Browns Pass, but this route takes you back to the trailhead after visiting the lake. This route is typically covered in deep snow between late October until June. It is best to explore this area during the summer months.

This route is a shared hiking and OHV route in the Rocky Mountains that culminates at Loch Lomond Lake. You'll need a high clearance 4WD vehicle to reach the lake on this road. High up on the Continental Divide, this trail offers excellent views of the surrounding wilderness area and is a great place to spot wildlife and season wildflowers. There is no parking allowed on Fall River Road or within the subdivisions. During winter months, the upper gate is often closed due to snow.

All vehicles on this trail must be either street-legal or registered annually through Colorado State Parks' OHV Registration Program. All motorized vehicles are restricted to open routes designated for their use. For more information, please visit: https://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/arp/maps-pubs/?cid=fsm91_058275

This is not a publicly-accessible hike; it must be done as part of a group tour, guided by a ranger. There are tours annually through mid-October and there is a fee. Unlike other guided tours, this one is a full two hours long, but they spend a lot more time going into the details about the lifestyle of the amazing people who used to live here.

Dogs are allowed on the Long House Loop Trail, which makes up part of this route. Dogs are only allowed on trails that are marked as dog friendly within the Wetherill Mesa area. For more information, please visit: https://www.nps.gov/meve/planyourvisit/pets.htm

Head out on this 6.8-mile out-and-back trail near Loveland, Colorado. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 58 min to complete. This trail is great for road biking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November.

This is a steep hike with spectacularly rewarding views of the Ragged Mountain Range. Start at Yule Creek trailhead. At about half mile at the Y, stay right until you reach a 4 way intersection (with Anthricite). Go straight and start climbing. Once you reach the ridge, follow the to the highest point; that is Marble Point. The ridge trail continues on to Raspberry Creek Loop at the second valley.

Explore this 2.7-mile loop trail near Walsenburg, Colorado. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 48 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, fishing, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 7.4-mile out-and-back trail near Rand, Colorado. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 21 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and snowshoeing, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 5.5-mile out-and-back trail near Westcliffe, Colorado. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 31 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and horseback riding, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Please avoid the administrative site at the Monument Fire Center, follow posted signs and park in designated areas.

Monument Creek flows north through the Front Range, around the north side of Raspberry Mtn, and down into the town of Monument, where it turns south, paralleling I-25. Then it runs down through Colorado Springs, where it finally joins Fountain Creek on its way to become part of the Arkansas River on the south side of Pueblo, CO. This guide begins at a small trailhead just west of the town of Monument, leads you up and over the ridge that zig-zags behind Mt Herman, and drops you down into the Monument Creek Valley about two miles east of its inception. The trail for this hike is a multi-use trail; so expect to encounter bicycles occasionally (known to bikers as the "Stooopid Trail" because its curves and dips often launch them into the bushes, making them feel "dumb"). I'm only providing a guide for a 3 mile, out and back, hike. Should you have more time and/or energy, you could push on down the valley, all the way into the town of Palmer Lake (another 3 miles) - just remember, the return journey would be almost all up hill.

This loop is often used in both the winter and summer months. In the winter, it can be a great backcountry ski tour or snowshoe trip. It is a great option for a short hike with some great views. 

Heads up! To get to the trailhead, you'll need to cross Highway 50 and walk along the shoulder for a very short distance.

Check out this 12.6-mile loop trail near Grand Junction, Colorado. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 58 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

To hike this trail, a permit is required. First-come, first-served for backcountry camping, with only 5-10 spots available. 

This very steep and grueling route is recommended for first-time North Rim inner canyon hikers. S.O.B. Draw is famous for its abundant poison ivy. Long pants are recommended. The route has several short ledges to climb (8-12 feet, 3 m). There are numerous scrambling and large drops, so this trek can be challenging on the knees. Campsites are located a short distance downstream.

Park vehicles in the pull-through near the campground registration board, or at the North Rim Ranger Station. The route begins at the access ladder along the fence line just east of the campground. This is on the right side of the road when traveling from the ranger station to the campground. Follow the path to the top of the drainage gully and descend on the far right of the route.

Endless switchbacks on this route climb high above Georgetown. You'll get great views of Georgetown and the I-70 corridor. Mount Blue Sky can be seen from the top. There are old log cabins scattered along the route. Don't miss historic Georgetown and the visitor center. Parking is limited at the trailhead. Alternative parking can be found at the lake across from Cabin Creek Brewery. The high point of this route is over 11,000 feet in elevation. Parts of this road cross though private land and Araphao National Forest. It is a good idea to stay on the road when crossing through private land.  The road is very narrow in spots and it is prone to rock slides, especially after periods of heavy rain. Conditions can change quickly. The road is rocky and bone-jarring. 
 For current conditions call Clear Creek Ranger District (303) 567-3000 

Per County Ordinance #13, this road is not open to OHVs (Off-Highway Vehicles). This road is county owned. County roads are not open to OHV Use.

This is a really fun hike which begins pretty close to the center of Vail itself, so it's a perfect short day hike for anyone staying in the are who doesn't want to venture too far from civilization. The hike is pretty much all uphill as you make your way out to the turnaround point, so make sure you're ready for a climb!

Beautiful 12,154-ft. pass road between historic, quaint mountain towns 

Overview A beautiful high-elevation route starting and ending at historic, quaint mountain towns. St. Elmo is one of the most popular ghost towns in Colorado. It has a few active businesses, including a general store and ATV rental. Tincup is a small residential community with many century-old buildings. Active businesses include the Tincup Store and Frenchie's Cafe. Located in Gunnison and San Isabel National Forest. For current conditions call Salida Ranger District (719) 539-3591. 
 
Rocky at the top with one short section of narrow shelf road at 12,000 feet that often remains snow covered into early July. After the snow clears, this trail is suitable for any high-clearance, 4-wheel-drive SUV with low-range gearing. St. Elmo can be reached by car. The optional "Old Tincup" route has one difficult rocky section.

This trail offers stunning vistas of the Front Range mountains. The area was impacted by forest fires in 2020, but signs of forest regeneration are visible along the route. Due to limited shade, it's important to wear sun protection and carry an ample water supply. The trail starts at Heil Valley Ranch, where parking is available.

This route as mapped, represents a hike from Research Parkway out along the back side of the Cordera & Wolf Ranch neighborhoods near Wolf Lake. The path does a loop around Wolf Lake, and then doubles back to return to the "trailhead". This loop can be started at Wolf Lake itself, and be viewed as an extended version of the Wolf Lake walking path.

A nice walk through the woods which features beech groves, outcroppings, ledges, and vernal pools. If starting at the trailhead, you can also cross to Avalonia’s White Cedar Swamp trail across Jerry Brown Rd. 

The trails are well cared for and nicely blazed/signed. There are bog boards in several places that can be swampy seasonally.

This route takes you around the Chriswood Trace Open Space area along the Avery Farm Blue Trail on a mostly flat, well-maintained path. It features a unique stone slab bridge that crosses Haleys Brook and a section that takes you along the shore of Ed Lamb Brook, offering lovely waterfront water views.

Begin from the parking area at the end of John Todd Way. Follow the Todd Wood Trail north through the woods to reach Bald Rock. This lookout point provides visitors with views of Bogus Mountain and on a clear day, the foothills of the Taconic and Berkshire uplands.

The Town of Redding maintains this trail.

Discover this 1.8-mile loop trail near Woodbridge, Connecticut. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 36 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This hike begins with a moderate climb that's perfect for beginners looking to push themselves or seasoned hikers. It flattens out as you approach the top. You'll encounter rocky sections and some overgrown bushes, but the journey is enjoyable, culminating in beautiful views at the summit overlooking the surrounding area.

Head out on this 2.7-mile loop trail near South Kent, Connecticut. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 25 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are August through June.

Head out on this 0.9-mile loop trail near Beacon Falls, Connecticut. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 20 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are September through December.

Trout Brook Valley State Park Reserve has various color-blazed trails. The preserve is divided into several sections and this trail offers a casual walk in the Crow Hill Preserve section. This loop is not in a hunting area and is the only trail for off-leash dogs. Fishing in the reservoir, using drones, and camping are prohibited in the preserve.

Discover this 5.7-mile out-and-back trail near Roxbury, Connecticut. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 56 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Enders State Forest encompasses 2,098 acres of land in Granby and Barkhamstead, CT.  The main entrance to the park is located on Route 219 in Granby. Here, hikers will find peaceful woods and a waterfall. 

Hours: The park is open daily from dawn to dusk.
Founding Date: 1970
Restrictions: No alcohol, No fires, No smoking
Area: 2,098 acres

This short walk is a basically a tribute to the Greenman workers, who were shipbuilders. The property of Coogan farm where this trail passes was an area renowned for supporting this community with vital food that they needed.

Excerpt from the nature center, "Starts from section of his-toric Mystic, known as Greenmanville, into Coogan Farm, along a walled pentway to the Hamm Pavilion. Situated on a hill at the heart of the farm, this marks the northern border of Greenmanville. "

Check out this 1.3-mile loop trail near Moodus, Connecticut. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 25 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through April.

Hillside to Olde Roberts is part of the Hockanum River trail system. It connects to some of the other East Hartford trails. This trail has very little markings, so at times can be difficult to navigate. Just remember, this trail pretty much hugs the Hockanum and never veers too far away from the river. While considered "unimproved," this section is easy to traverse. Following the trail, you will eventually see a series of man-made waterfalls to your left. The trail then turns sharp right, leaving the river. This section can be difficult to traverse.

This is a beautiful nature walk, perfect for all age levels. The trail is beautifully enclosed and feels like venturing into another world. 

There are lots of butterflies, dragonflies, flowers, birds, and even turkeys. Hikers can easily connect to other trails on Holcombe Hill, or cross Birch Hill Road and connect to other trails including the Holcombe Memorial Trail.

Begin from the parking area on Wampum Hill Road near the intersection with Honey Hill Road. Follow the wooded access road north into the preserve. Briefly follow the white-blazed trail before turning onto the red-blazed trail. Make a small loop and retrace your path.

The Aspetuck Land Trust maintains this trail.

This route takes you on a straightforward, kid-friendly hike around Hop Brook Lake, a 536-acre area. The park features picnic areas and miles of trails for hiking and mountain biking, fishing, swimming, and paddle sports. 

Trail maps are available at the park entrance and trailhead at the top of the dam/ranger station, or you can download the route before you go to help navigate the trails.

This well blazed figure-eight loop is part of the Old Lyme Land Trust. There are no big views, but it is quiet and peaceful and you are likely to have the trail to yourself. There's lots of mountain laurel and rocky ledges, and opportunities for bird watching. There’s parking available for 1 or 2 cars.

You can hike the dirt trail or drive up the paved road to view Judges Cave. There are great views from the top. 
 
Accessibility: There are 6 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Blake Street at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is natural (dirt, rocks, roots, leaves). It is typically at least 3 feet wide. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the paved section from 0.8-0.9 miles at the north end of the trail. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the steep (8-12%) and very steep (over 12%) grade categories. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type/grade. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance along this entire route due to the consistent sections above a 5% grade (especially if using manual equipment). 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the West Rock South Overlook to Judges Cave trail: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/connecticut/west-rock-south-overlook-to-judges-cave

Little-Laurel Lime Ridge Park purchased by the town of Seymour in 1977 using federal and state grants, with additional funding from Seymour Land Trust. It consists of 209 acres of forested rolling hills, and a large ledge offering an overlook of the Housatonic River.

200 million years ago, this region was covered by an ocean that featured a coral reef surrounding a volcanic island. Lava had covered the coral, which eventually turned into the marble/limestone seen today. Between around 1790-1820, local farmers mined the marble and burned it in a kiln to produce "quick lime" for their soil. The remains of the quarries and kiln can still be seen within the park. A very small natural cave network also exists on the property (hardly large enough to crawl in, but one of only a few such natural caves within CT). Due to this history and unique geology, the property is designated as a historic and ecological preserve. 

Little-Laurel Lime Ridge Park is freely open to the public for passive recreation only: walking, hiking, and bicycling. No motorized vehicles, camping, fires, or hunting. Parking and Trailhead is located at the end of Tibbets Road. Dogs are welcome but must be kept on a leash.

The park's original trail system was two simple overlapping loops. This is depicted in the town's official trail guide. In recent years, several illegal trails have been constructed which overlap, cause erosion, damage the forest, disrupt wildlife, and simply confuse visitors. The town's trail committee has been working to close and remove most of them in an effort to help restore the forest. As of August 2020, the only officially marked trails are the boundary loop, which uses standard blazing in the color Blue, and the optional secondary entrance/exit at Partridge Road, which is Red.

The town has also reported an issue with ATV/OHV and dirt bike riders trespassing, marking trees, and causing other damage within the park. As a reminder, it is illegal within the state of CT to ride such vehicles on public streets and within state or municipal forests, parks, and open space designated for public use.

The trail is not well marked in some areas, downloading the map ahead of time is helpful for navigating.

Get to know this 0.9-mile loop trail near Cornwall Bridge, Connecticut. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 22 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Check out this 1.3-mile loop trail near Jewett City, Connecticut. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 27 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through November.

Trails through the park will lead the walker through centuries of land-use history. Heading northeast from the parking lot the trail utilizes the 1895 Berlin Iron Bridge, one of five remaining in Connecticut, to cross the Housatonic River. Across the bridge the Lovers Leap Trail heads southeast 1,200 feet to the rock formation that gives the park its name. From here, tradition has it, that the Pootatuck Indian Chief Waramaugs daughter, Princess Lillinonah, and her lover plunged to their deaths. The Chief himself died in 1735. 
 
The view to the south overlooks a now submerged Goodyear Island named for an early fur trader from Derby who came there to trade with the established Indian Community. Industrial era ruins still exist near the water on the northwest section of the park. Other ruins have been located on the accompanying map.

As you approach the top of Mamacoke Hill, the trail begins to climb gradually, leading to a rocky outcrop that offers spectacular views of the surrounding rural landscape. From the summit, you can enjoy expansive vistas that stretch out across the Connecticut River and the nearby Housatonic River Valley.

Enjoy this 0.3-mile loop trail near Milford, Connecticut. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 5 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 1.1-mile out-and-back trail near Storrs, Connecticut. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 30 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October.

Get to know this 1.5-mile loop trail near Burlington, Connecticut. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 39 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through January.

Get to know this 1.0-mile out-and-back trail near Storrs, Connecticut. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 22 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

One of the highlights of the loop is the Chatfield Hollow Brook, which flows through the park, creating small waterfalls and gentle rapids along the way. Several footbridges cross the stream, providing great spots to pause, take photos, or simply enjoy the soothing sound of running water.

As the loop transitions onto the Red Trail, the terrain becomes slightly more rugged, leading hikers to some of the park’s most striking rocky outcrops and ledges.

Head out on this 1.6-mile loop trail near Enfield, Connecticut. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 36 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Get to know this 2.7-mile point-to-point trail near Kent, Connecticut. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 53 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Tefftweald, a former Girl Scout camp, has a network of trails that run through forest, meadows, wetlands and along Wyassup Brook. Lots of history here as well—the old pavilion from Girl Scout camp days, old root cellars, foundations and an old water pump.

To see all the loops with the least amount of backtracking, it is best to do the East Ledge trail from the parking lot.  After that, take a left onto the lane that runs through the property.  If you go all the way down to the end and do Brook Loop, you can zigzag thru the side loops and hit everything.  Brook Loop to Pavilion Trail then Doodle Loop then Poet’s Bench Trail Loop then back to car.

Twin Brooks Park Loop is a great trail to explore just outside of Trumbull. It offers some great chances to get into the woods and spot wildlife. 

As of 2021, all vehicles are required to have valid parking permit (park sticker). Anyone without a park sticker is subject to a parking violation ticket. Please visit www.trumbull-ct.gov/parkstickers for more information.

Discover the beauty of Seth Low Pierrepont State Park on a hike up the White Trail to Barlow Mountain. The park was once the estate of Seth Low Pierrepont, who generously donated this land for everyone to enjoy. The trail circles the lovely Pierrepont Pond before guiding you up through a classic Connecticut forest. Listen for the calls of songbirds like the wood thrush as you walk among ferns and native wildflowers. It's a fantastic escape into nature, offering a mix of lakeside scenery and woodland charm right here in Ridgefield.

Explore this 1.1-mile out-and-back trail near Wilmington, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 26 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking and mountain biking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through July. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Starting from the parking area on Mulberry Landing Road, head northeast along the road before turning left onto a dirt path that leads to the banks of Miller Creek. Keep your eyes peeled for pileated woodpeckers and bald eagles.

Be sure to wear blaze orange during hunting seasons. 

Swimming is not permitted.

Start from the parking area on Double Bridges Road. You'll hike on dirt roads along a dove field and through thickets of trees toward the marshlands. Keep your eyes peeled for pileated woodpeckers and bald eagles. Enjoy views of Poke Hill to the southeast.

Be sure to wear blaze orange during hunting seasons. 

Swimming is not permitted.

This route is partially paved, partially on grass, and partially through a wooded area. The park has two ponds, a dog park, athletic fields, a playground, and tennis courts. This park along the Christina River was previously a plantation and is home to the historic Woodstock home. Its history extends back to Swedish settlers in the 1600s.

This short and sweet wooded loop features a lookout tower and pier and has abundant wildlife (watch for snakes, snappers, herons, and egrets).

Accessibility: There are no designated accessible spaces in the small unpaved parking lot off of Bear Swamp Loop Road at the south end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spots within 1 mile of the south end of the trail. 

The trail surface is a wooden boardwalk (with edge barriers), gravel, or a natural (dirt, grass, fallen leaf) surface. It is typically 3 to 5 feet wide. The entire trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces.

Check out this 2.7-mile loop trail near Milton, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 49 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Begin from the parking area off the east side of Blackbird Landing Road. There is an informational kiosk and restroom near the trailhead. Begin the Blue Trail by proceeding southeast to create a counterclockwise loop. Pass the boat launch along the river, and turn north. Bird-watching stations dot this route.

The Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control maintain this trail.

Enjoy this 1.7-mile loop trail near Wilmington, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 44 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Explore this 1.5-mile out-and-back trail near Hockessin, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 35 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 2.9-mile loop trail near Seaford, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 54 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are October through May. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 0.5-mile loop trail near Historic New Castle, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 10 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

The Eastern Loop is a beautiful waterfall trail that provides a relaxing experience. You follow the well-marked trail through gorgeous woodlands and a rocky, forested road. A serene waterfall is accessible via the walk, which is ideal for enjoying the scenery. The trail has some muddy areas, so watch your footing. Keep your eyes peeled for flora and fauna in this area.

Begin from the parking area off Welsh Tract Road. Follow the paved pathway around Folk Park.

The City of Newark maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
It is unclear whether any designated accessible parking spaces are available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 7 feet wide. Bollards near the parking area temporarily reduce the tread width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Experience this 2.4-mile loop trail near Newark, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 56 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Get to know this 2.0-mile loop trail near Newark, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 47 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Try this 3.3-mile out-and-back trail near Milford, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 0 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 0.3-mile loop trail near Milford, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 5 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Check out this 3.9-mile out-and-back trail near Newark, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 10 min to complete. This trail is great for road biking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This paved path loops around the park and provides an easily accessible place to go for a walk, run, or bike ride. It travels on the field edge with views into the surrounding forest. In addition to this path, there is a playground and multiple baseball / softball fields There are restrooms available near the parking area.

This is a nice city park with a lake and a dog park.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of St Anne's Church Road at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

This is an asphalt path amid the grounds of a former estate. The mansion museum is available for visitors to explore. This is a nice place for a stroll and a family picnic.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
It is unclear whether designated accessible parking is available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide with many wider passing spaces.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

Begin by street parking on Duck Creek Parkway near the northern end of the pathway. Additional parking is available at Smyrna Sports Park and at the high school. Proceed on the paved pathway to the southern terminus on Basset Street.

Accessibility:  

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.  

Parking  
Street parking is available near the trailhead, but there are no accessible parking spaces nearby.  

Surface  
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically at least 10 feet wide.  

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

Get to know this 1.4-mile loop trail near Hockessin, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 33 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 0.6-mile loop trail near Dover, Delaware. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 11 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a magnificent new and fully paved trail. It is great for all levels.

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Sunrise Drive at the northeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section at about 0.7 miles when going south. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety.

The Two State Breakfast Cruise trail takes you on a scenic loop through both Delaware and Maryland, with views of local landscapes and waterways. The trail is mostly flat, passing through fields and along creeks, offering a peaceful and easy-going walk. It’s a great option for a pleasant outing, with a little bit of everything, open spaces, water views, and quiet areas to relax. The trail is well maintained, making it great for bikes, jogging or walking.

This route starts you from the Brandywine Commons area and takes you along an enjoyable trail through the Brandywine Creek State Park and Ramsey Farm area. The trail features pleasant rolling hills and quiet, scenic paths. You will cross the road a couple of times and a creek. It can be challenging to navigate because the trails are not well-marked, so it's best to download the trail beforehand. 

In December 1787, 30 delegates convened at the Golden Fleece Tavern in Delaware and voted to ratify the new United States Constitution. This momentous decision made Delaware the first state to approve the document and its federal system of government. Learn more about First State NHP and America's 250th Celebrations at America's National Parks™: americasnationalparks.org/americas-250th

This paved and boardwalk trail offers trail-goers a serene and scenic stroll through a coastal dune ecosystem. Elevated above the delicate landscape, the boardwalk winds through stands of scrub oaks, palmettos, and native grasses, providing views of the surrounding wetlands and chances to spot birds and wildlife. With its flat, well-maintained surface and peaceful atmosphere, it’s an ideal trail for a relaxing walk and a quiet connection to the natural beauty of Florida’s Gulf Coast.å

This is a serene and well-kept community park that leads to the beach via wooden boardwalks to the Indian River. There is water access available here as well for paddle sports and fishing. Other amenities of the park include pit toilets and access to a larger boardwalk trail system. There are many opportunities to observe wildlife in this area.

This is a shaded trail that travels on part boardwalk and part sandy trail. There are beautiful views of the beach and plenty of flowers, butterflies, and wildlife to observe.

Visitors can depart the fully accessible Brackenridge Boardwalk Trail and venture onto the 0.5-mile Brackenridge Double Loop Trail. 

This trail is not fully accessible. It connects to the Fishing Trail and an Brackenridge observation deck.

The view from the lookout tower is very nice and makes this worth the visit. The woods that the trail runs through are peaceful. The first part of the trail leading up to the tower is in good shape but the second part of the loop may be muddy. 

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There is 1 designated accessible space with a striped access aisle in the paved parking lot off West Yulee Drive.

Surface
The trail surface is wooden boardwalks (with railings), gravel, or a natural (dirt and grass) surface and is typically at least 3 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

This trail heads around the Copeland Park. There is a wooden boardwalk in the center of the park not along this loop route.

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the partially paved parking lot off of North 15 St. at the start of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is a paved or natural surface and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved sections.

This natural scrub area is a virtually undiscovered treasure. This is a paved trail with cacti, pine, scrub, and gopher tortoises. There is an observation tower at the entrance. Please close the gate when entering or leaving. There is a secondary loop trail (unpaved) marked with wood stakes with a yellow circle. The best month is February when cacti bloom. 

Accessibility: There is 1 paved designated accessible space in the gravel parking lot off of Hypoluxo Road at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

This smooth, paved path winds through open green space and lightly wooded areas. Ideal for walking, jogging, or casual biking, the trail loops near a playground, picnic shelters, and sports facilities, creating a relaxed, family-friendly environment. With flat terrain and peaceful surroundings, it’s a convenient spot for everyday outdoor activity.

This is a multi-use trail shared by mountain bikers and hikers. The trail leads visitors along the Suwannee River with multiple viewpoints to stop and enjoy.  There are plenty of native wildflowers including a breathtaking valley of lilies. The route is half-shaded and half-exposed to the sun- sun protection is advised.

Get to know this 3.6-mile loop trail near Niceville, Florida. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 10 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, mountain biking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are September through May. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This scenic trail winds through a mix of pine flatwoods, freshwater marsh, and open prairie on a natural-surface path rich in Florida’s native beauty. It features flat terrain and wide, sunlit stretches bordered by saw palmetto, slash pine, and seasonal wildflowers. Trail-goers may encounter sandhill cranes, gopher tortoises, and white-tailed deer while enjoying the quiet rhythms of this diverse, conservation-focused landscape.

This is a fairly flat wide trail that travels through the woods and to the water's edge of the Cross-Florida Barge Canal. There are beautiful views located at the dam and plenty of wildlife in the area to observe. The trail is mostly exposed to the sun and bringing sun protection is advised. This route travels the perimeter of Inglis Island.

This wide and paved trail connects the communities of Kewanee starting from the town park and traveling along Howell Canal. This pathway serves as both recreational opportunities for the community as well as a way to commute to the nearby area. There are restrooms and a playground located at the trailhead.

This is a small park with paved trails, a splash pad for kids, and an art-house. There's also a boardwalk that offers great views of the lake.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Quail Pond Circle at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is a boardwalk (with railings) or smooth pavement, and typically at least 5 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

This trail travels through dense woods, a patch of palmettos, and features a beautiful waterfall. 

This trail begins from the back end of Oviedo Riverside Park. From here, walk across a grassy field to find the trailhead. Cross over the river using the tree bridge then walk along the river until you see the cypress tree next to a little waterfall. The waterfall is a little cascade that falls from some Cypress roots along the banks of the Little Econ River.

This route is the "warmup" in the area for this extensive mountain biking trail system. This is a great beginner trail and showcases a taste of what riding at Markham Park is like. The surface is single-track sand/dirt with little to no roots or rocks in the path. There are many other trail connections to extend your ride in this park.

There is a section of this route that does not allow dogs, however, the majority of this trail is accessible to dogs.

This is one of the best parks for birding in the area, especially during migration. The trails here highlight the places that are good to check while birding the area, including a short trip to a nearby lake. For more information about the area, please visit https://www.meadgarden.org/visit/

This is a short and sweet wooded and paved path around several lakes at Ormond Beach Central Park.

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Hammock Lane at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved concrete, asphalt, or wooden boardwalks (with railings). It is typically 3 to 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily.

The entire trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the south end of the trail.

Make sure to bring plenty of water and sun protection for this mostly sunny and partially paved trail. The first portion of this loop is a maintenance road, watch for maintenance vehicles.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the partially paved parking lot off of Manatee Avenue West at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is wooden boardwalks (with edge barriers and railings), gravel, or a natural (dirt and grass) surface. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

There is a double track along some of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate. The entire trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches along the route for resting.

This is a peaceful and short loop through the PeriwinkleBlue Skies Preserve. This trail is intended to be multi-use and is shared by mountain bikers and hikers.

The trail can become muddy during wet conditions and waterproof shoes are recommended. There are not many views along the trail, however, there are many opportunities to view wildlife and wildflowers.

This is a well-maintained and mostly shaded trail. The trails in this section are primarily for mountain biking as there are narrow sections of the trails and many switchbacks. There are some technical spots with ramps, stairs, and rocks. The park itself has restrooms and a nice lake for those to stop and enjoy the view.

This paved trail circles Mayor Roscoe Warren Municipal Park. The trail is flat, paved, and well-maintained, excellent for walking, running, and cycling. The trail cuts through tropical trees as it travels along the Florida City Canal on the southern stretch then passes through open grass fields before looping past the pavilions, facilities, and other amenities. The trail does not have much shade, but nearby trees and pavilions are available to take a break from the sun.

This scenic loop trail on Samsons Island guides trail-goers through a peaceful blend of coastal hammocks, mangrove shorelines, and open uplands. Accessible by boat or kayak, the natural surface path offers a quiet escape rich with native plants, birdlife, and glimpses of the surrounding Banana River Lagoon. With flat terrain, interpretive signage, and a sense of seclusion, the trail provides a unique opportunity to explore one of Satellite Beach’s hidden natural gems.

This trail is multi-use and provides a beautiful trail for both mountain bikers and hikers alike. Biking rentals are available at the ranger station, which is located at the entrance of the park.

The trail is mostly shaded and travels through a diverse variety of habitats along the way. There is also a campground located here for those interested in camping.

This is a nice paved path with restaurants, beaches, shops, drinking fountains, and restrooms along the way. The path is mostly exposed to the sun and bringing sun protection is advised.

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the large partially paved parking lot off of Tarpon Bay Road by the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically 3 to 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). There is a painted dividing line along the trail which reduces the width.

The entire trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms by the south end of the trail.

This paved, city park loop travels the perimeter of the area and showcases the many great amenities of the park.

Accessibility: There are 6 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of North Triplet Lake Drive by the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete. It is typically at least 4 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

The entire trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Broward County's first nature center, which opened in September 1978, comprises three vegetative communities found along and influenced by the New River: an inland freshwater cypress/maple wetland, a pond apple/mangrove community along the river, and, farther inland, a laurel oak hammock. The 57-acre site is now designated as an Urban Wilderness Area.

This loop takes you by three of the prettiest lakes in the Split Oak Forest, and it uses some of the lesser-known trails as well. Users recommend bringing sun protection as many sections of this trail are exposed. There is a decent amount of sugar sand along the way. The trail is well-maintained and easy to navigate.

This route is located at the northwest section of the park and travels through a variety of different habitats. From a grassy trail that leads through a longleaf pine forest, to exposed sections over sugar sand- this trail has it all. There are many views of the river along the way, and opportunities to observe local wildlife in the area.

This is an easy hike featuring mossy, rooted trails, beautiful trees, marsh areas, and fields.

The Preserve encompasses 69 acres of bottomland forest associated with the Pithlachascotee River and a small tributary, Ryals Branch, that crosses the site. Other natural communities include sandhill, upland mixed forest, and freshwater marshes. Documented or likely protected wildlife species comprise the gopher tortoise, Florida mouse, gopher frog, little blue heron, and snowy egret. The Preserve features five geocaches and two miles of trails, including a 1,500-foot boardwalk.

This is a preserve, which differs from an active park by offering low-impact amenities and natural resource-based recreational facilities. The parking lot is made of packed shell and includes one ADA parking space. The nature trails consist of packed earth, except for the wooden boardwalk. There are no asphalt or concrete surfaces.

This trail is intended to be multi-use and is shared by mountain bikers and hikers.
For those wishing to extend their route, there are many other trail connections to add distance in the area. Many other people refer to this area as the "Spider Kingdom Horse Trails". The trail is mostly shaded and travels through a forested area.

This is a primitive hike in Apalachicola National Forest that features varied terrain, unique habitat, and scenic cypress swamps. Users report that the route is not very well-marked and suggest downloading the route beforehand to navigate. There are many opportunities to view wildlife and local flowers along the way.

This trail is a beautiful, challenging, and technical path that runs alongside the river. However, it is important to note that Cloudland Canyon closes this trail after heavy rainfall. Therefore, it is recommended that visitors check with the park before visiting the trail to ensure it is open for use. 

There are two primitive campsites available, which are sites 12 and 13. Additionally, backcountry sites 1-11 can be found along the 2-mile backcountry loop, near the bear creek backcountry trail. All of these sites can be booked online.
This trail is closed. We'll update this page if and when it reopens.

Park on the side of the road on Old Andersonville Rd. and head out for 10.4 miles of unpaved and paved back roads and trails. True solitude in nature with a little travel back in time.  Great workout with multiple rollercoaster-like hills. At the midway point you do a loop around the town of Andersonville.

The rolling meadows, streams, natural shoals, and plethora of local wildlife may be found in Cherokee Bluffs. In addition, there are numerous historic sites for visitors to explore. The park is well-equipped with features, such as a dog park, multipurpose bike and pedestrian walking pathways, a pavilion, an amphitheater, and a playground. The wooden pathways and steps are shady and clearly marked. There are several huge rocks along the trail that make for great climbing opportunities.

Head out on this 1.6-mile loop trail near Newborn, Georgia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 32 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a nice paved loop that connects to the Woodland Loop and one other trail. There are walk-in campsites on this loop and some have access to the lake.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of North Boat Road at the west end of the trail.  The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 8 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle except for a very steep (over 12%) section at about 0.2 miles uphill when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchair/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

Try this 1.9-mile loop trail near Dalton, Georgia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 38 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This scenic rail-trail segment follows a wide, paved path through the heart of Union Point, bordered by grassy shoulders and scattered trees. Once a historic rail line, the route now offers a gentle, linear journey past quiet neighborhoods, open fields, and traces of the town’s past. The terrain is smooth and flat, inviting walkers and cyclists alike to enjoy a calm, uninterrupted passage through this small-town landscape.

The Freedom Park Trail via Ponce de Leon Ave NE begins at the parking area next to Moe's Grill on Barnett St. This paved trail winds through Freedom Park, passing notable landmarks such as the Carter Presidential Center and the Jimmy Carter Library and Museum, making it both a scenic and historically rich route.

The Path Foundation maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 10 feet wide. A painted dividing line along most of the trail and metal bollards at road crossings reduce the tread width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Take caution when crossing roadways; designated crosswalks are present. Expect traffic noise on this route. 

Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

This is one of many routes/trails you can walk in the Gibbs Gardens. To reach the Fern Dell trail, you must travel through the entrance, the Waterlily Gardens, and then finally through the Japanese Garden. The Fern Dell is a short circular route. The GPS map attached follow this path.

The route itself is very easy difficulty and can be completed with a stroller. Enjoy the wonderful views of the first two gardens and then the serenity of the Fern Dell. 

Accessibility: There are at least 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Gibbs Dr. at the west end of the trail. It is unclear if they are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is packed gravel and wooden bridge (with railings) and typically at least 4 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first half mile heading counterclockwise. The estimated grade is moderately steep (8% or less) except for steep sections at about 0.5 and 0.8 miles when going clockwise. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. There are benches along the route for resting.

Please visit the Gardens website prior to your visit to see if there is a pathway restriction in effect due to weather. The link to their website is: https://www.gibbsgardens.com/visit/accessibility/

This is a short but decently challenging trail that starts and ends at Lake Rutledge beach.  Using the southern 1-mile section of the Yellow Trail, this trail is designed as an interpretive nature trail and offers viewing platforms at various sites. For those who are wishing to extend their hike, check out the Yellow Trail which leads from the same trailhead.

Experience this 0.9-mile loop trail near Watkinsville, Georgia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 18 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 9.5-mile out-and-back trail near Crandall, Georgia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This trail is great for backpacking and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through July. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

If you're looking for an unforgettable hike through the Georgia wilderness, consider starting in Alaculsey and embarking on a 3-day backpacking trip up the entire Jacks River Trail. One of the most unique aspects of this hike is the 22 river crossings (one-way), which can be challenging due to the swift current and slippery rocks. 

It is recommended to bring trekking poles or find a sturdy walking stick to help navigate the crossings. If you're looking to camp, there's an excellent spot past the Rice Camp Trail near the river that is particularly beautiful.

The J.J. Biello Riverside Park has 3 trails; this route follows all 3 of them, forming an out-and-back on the Blue Trail with a loop on the Yellow and Red trails. These trails are a mixture of dirt and mowed grass, and they can become muddy after a rain. The Yellow and Red trails wind through the woods close to the athletic fields while the Blue Trail cuts straight through the trees to the Little River north of the park.

Get to know this 1.0-mile loop trail near Richmond Hill, Georgia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 17 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Mary Scott Nature Park Loop is a 0.6-mile gravel/soft surface trail within a 10.6-acre greenspace located in an urban neighborhood.  The park has mature hardwoods (several being specimen trees) and over one mile of interconnecting trails.  There are three trailheads.  The main trailhead is located on Briarcliff Rd and has ample public parking.  The other two, located at opposing ends of Overlook Dr, are neighborhood trailheads and have no designated parking area.  A small tributary of the North Fork Peachtree Creek denotes the park’s rear boundary.  On a bluff overlooking the creek are two chimney ruins that once belonged to an old homestead.  Various dirt paths from the ruins lead down to the creek.  Dogs may use this trail but must be on leash.

Get to know this 14.6-mile out-and-back trail near Moultrie, Georgia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 27 min to complete. This trail is great for mountain biking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through April.

To get to the Eagle's Eye Picnic Area, start from the main parking lot and follow the trail marked with yellow blazes. As you proceed, you will enter a dense and beautiful forest and reach the old CCC logging road. Keep following the road, and you will come across the Mountain Stewards picnic area before eventually returning to the trailhead. The trail has its fair share of ups and downs, but the stunning views towards the end make it all worth it.

Experience this 11.4-mile out-and-back trail near Ellijay, Georgia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 51 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, fishing, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is one of two trails in the area. The red trail is the longest marked trail with paved and gravel areas.

Accessibility: There are 6 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Mulberry Rock Road at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the paved portion in the first about 0.8 miles when going clockwise. The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section at about 1.5 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the gravel surface type and grade from about 0.8-1.6 miles.

Enjoy this 1.8-mile loop trail near Macon, Georgia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 39 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This section of the Pinhoti Trail can be challenging as it is usually overgrown. The trail starts on a service road and later connects with a natural single-track trail. The route includes rough terrain, strenuous elevations, beautiful scenery, and overlooks. The trail is well-marked but has limited access to water. However, there are great camping options available along the way.

This is a small but nice little trail that ends at a private property area behind the hill. There are several spur trails that lead to the Chattahoochee River, which make for great fishing locations. The route travels through a dense hardwood forest, and an abundance of wildlife can often be seen in the area. The beginning of the trail is paved, starting at the parking area on Cumming HWY  and wrapping around and under the bridge to the edge of the river. A dirt trail continues into the forest.

This trail follows the perimeter of Haig Mill Lake Park and offers a relaxing trail with calm lake views. It is on a wide path through the woods. There are several fishing piers and benches along the trail.  Swimming and wading in the lake are prohibited and for fishing, you have to have a valid Georgia Fishing License. The trailhead has a kayak dock, a playground, restrooms, and a pavilion.

Enjoy this 0.7-mile loop trail near Atlanta, Georgia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 18 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Experience this 1.7-mile loop trail near Crandall, Georgia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 39 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through December. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Black’s Bluff is open to the public during daylight hours without a reservation. To walk the trails at Black's Bluff, drive a little southwest of the (entirely inactive) quarries. There is a trail to the spring, unmarked at the road, but it's the last cable gate on the left before our property ends. 

You'll know you're in the right place because the big wooden "Welcome to Black’s Bluff Preserve" sign is about 20 yards down that trail, although it's difficult to see from the road. Once again, beware of fast traffic, and park beside the cable gate parallel to Black's Bluff Road with all your wheels off the road. 

If you pull straight down to the gate, you risk getting stuck on slick clay. Not ADA accessible.

The public trail, Spring Trail, will take you to the spring pools. It is moderately difficult and begins just beyond the preserve sign.

A lovely loop with plenty of trees in between Warm Springs Road and Oneal Drive, in the heart of downtown Waverly Hall. Some shade from the trees along the way.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There is 1 designated van-accessible space with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Waverly Circle at the northeast end of the trail. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

This trail loops around Ala Pu'umalu Community Park. There is a paved walking path, baseball field, basketball courts, and tennis courts. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Ala Puumalu Street at the southeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete sidewalk with some cracks or bumps and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is moderately steep (5-8%), with several very steep (over 12%) sections. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance along this entire route due to the consistent sections above a 5% grade (especially if using manual equipment) or motorized equipment may be needed for the grade.

Explore this 0.3-mile out-and-back trail near Honolulu, Oahu. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 8 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are November through April.

This is a paved trail through the Honolulu Zoo. Honolulu Zoo has a visitors admission fee to enter. 

Accessibility: There are at least 10 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Kapahulu Avenue at the northwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete, smooth, and typically at least 10 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less), except for steep (8-12%) sections at about 0.3 miles uphill, 0.6 miles uphill, and 0.8 miles downhill when going counterclockwise. 

Trail goers using wheelchair/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are multiple paths through the zoo, so there is likely a fully accessible route. The Honolulu Zoo website states the facility is accessible for those with disabilities and to contact them with questions. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. Strollers and wheelchairs are available for rent with a refundable deposit from the Gift Shop at the zoo entrance on a first-come, first-served basis.

This paved trail loops around the baseball fields and along the sidewalk through the neighborhood near Kahului Park. This trail has some road crossings, so please use caution. 

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Hina Avenue at the northeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. Please avoid parking here during school hours. The trail surface is paved concrete or sidewalk, smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

This natural walking path goes along the coast at Kalama Park. This is a great spot for watching the sunset or looking for turtles or whales. Kalama Park has basketball courts, tennis courts, baseball courts, an inline skating rink, skateboard park, outdoor showers, restrooms, picnic tables, and pavilions.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of South Kihei Road at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete, smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less), except for a steep (8-12%) section at about 0.1 miles downhill when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchair/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Hawaii's Plantation Village is a living history museum and botanical garden that preserves Hawaii's history of sugar plantations. 

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of C.O. Andy Anderson Loop at the northwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is packed dirt and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This is a beachfront park with some grassy fields and beach access. There are beautiful views from the park and it is great at sunset. There are public restrooms. 

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of West Waipuilani Road at the south end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is grass or sand and it is not a clearly designated trail. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade.
