Discover this 30.5-mile out-and-back trail near Cobalt, Idaho. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 11 h 29 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Heads up! This route to Diamond Peak summit is an unofficial, unmaintained route that requires offtrail hiking and scrambling to complete. It is recommended to take Pass Creek Road (off highway 28) via North Folk Pass Creek to road 796 to reach the trailhead. The road leading to the trailhead is better done with a high clearance vehicle.

Discover this 1.9-mile out-and-back trail near Grangeville, Idaho. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 14 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This route will take you on a flowy trip traversing the foothills of Challis. Take in spectacular views of the Sawtooth and Bitterroot Mountain Ranges. This trail is multi-use. Hikers, bikers, OHVs, and horseback riders alike share this trail. All recreators should make sure to yield to horseback riders.

Discover this 5.6-mile out-and-back trail near Hope, Idaho. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are July through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Stand on the roof of Idaho!

This is the highest peak in the Lost River Range of Idaho as well as the State's highpoint.  The standard route to the top of this 12,662 ft peak is the Southwest Ridge from the Birch Springs Trailhead.  This ascent of over 5,250 feet in less than 4 miles is steep but can easily be done in a day.  If it is early season you may want to bring an axe, crampons and your mountaineering skills.

This hilly loop offers a lovely, heavily forested experience, winding through valleys on both sides of the road. While the trail primarily showcases the beauty of the woods, it provides a peaceful and immersive nature experience. In a few spots, you may encounter some overgrown areas and fallen trees.

Enjoy this 5.7-mile loop trail near Dixon, Illinois. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 47 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, mountain biking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This paved loop heads around the sports fields and pond at the Madison Meadow Park.

Accessibility: There are at least 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of East Madison Street at the start of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is asphalt or cement, and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

Discover this 3.4-mile loop trail near Pekin, Illinois. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 9 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Several road crossings are necessary to navigate this paved multi-use trail. Several connections are available to trails at the Rock Cut State Park.

Accessibility: There are over 10 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of North Perryville Road at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). There is a painted dividing line along most of the trail which reduces the width.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible picnic tables with a firm and stable path and surface at the north end of the trail. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the north and south end of the trail.

One of the highlights of the Pimiteoui Trail is its variety of ecosystems. The trail passes through areas of dense woodlands, where the canopy provides shade and a peaceful atmosphere, as well as wetland areas where you can observe waterfowl and the occasional frog or turtle. The preserve also features open prairie meadows, offering expansive views and a chance to spot wildflowers in bloom, particularly during the spring and summer months.

This is the main loop at McNaughton Park. Sticking to this trail takes you around the entire park perimeter. There are many optional trails along the way to create variation in your trip. The trail alternates between sections of forests and meadows, and both provide ample opportunity to view wildlife.  
This loop starts at the main parking lot near the disc golf course, but there is a second entrance to the west at the dog park off Parkway Drive and a third to south off Sheridan Road. 

There are two creek crossings on this route without bridge. When the water is low it is possible to cross without getting wet, but most of the time you should anticipate getting your feet wet.

Experience this 4.9-mile loop trail near Crystal Lake, Illinois. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 37 min to complete. This trail is great for cross-country skiing, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 1.0-mile loop trail near Goreville, Illinois. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 23 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 11.2-mile out-and-back trail near Decatur, Illinois. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 3 h 32 min to complete. This is a popular trail for mountain biking, road biking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Discover this 5.4-mile out-and-back trail near Effingham, Illinois. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 47 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Trillium Trail in Giant City State Park is the perfect way to explore this beautiful patch of protected habitat. This hike winds along a lovely shaded path and features impressive towering sandstone bluffs. 

As you walk along the ridge, you will be treated to lovely views of the rock cliffs below. Sections of the trail are quite rocky, so take care, as they can be quite slippery in wet conditions. 

This is a great spot for birdwatching. You can spot lots of different species, including giant Pileated Woodpeckers in the treetops and Carolina Wrens in the bushes below.

This route takes you along a nicely paved trail that used to be the B and O railroad tracks. It was the first common carrier railroad and the oldest railroad in the United States. This portion runs east/west between IN 267 in Brownsburg, IN, and County Road 300 near Clermont, IN. It's mostly a bike ride, but hikers and runners can enjoy this trail, primarily done in smaller segments.

This is a fantastic hike to two beautiful waterfalls in southern Indiana. Parking is available at the start of this trail off Lower Falls Road. The route travels alongside Mill Creek, stopping by Upper and Lower Cataract Falls. 

The trail is partially paved with dirt sections. The view at both the falls is spectacular, especially when they are in full flow. There are bathrooms near the trailhead.

The Celina Interpretive Trail is an easy, short loop hike with placards along the way explaining the history of the area. The trailhead for the trail as mapped here is at the end of County Rd 502, just past Rickenbaugh Cemetery. 

Part of the Celina Interpretive Loop overlaps with the Two Lakes Loop, so anyone looking for a much longer hike could incorporate some or all of that trail into their route as well.

Try this 6.4-mile out-and-back trail near Albion, Indiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 10 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, skiing, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

The Charlestown State Park #6 Trail is an excellent way to see the Ohio River as it gradually rises and levels out at the top of the ridge. It passes through an open field with an old structure and crosses a bridge over a waterfall. There are lovely views of the Ohio River, the boat ramp, and Twelvemile Island from the top of the bluff. Along the way, you may see small abandoned wooden buildings and deer, which are common in the area.

A short trek over the creek. This is a very family-friendly route!

Accessibility: There are at least 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of South Center Street at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt (with railings at the bridge). It is typically at least 4 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

This is a really nice birding hike with views of the largest wetland complex in the Lake Michigan watershed. Flocks of coots, mallards, and wood ducks inhabit the area. Kingfishers, tree swallows, and rusty blackbirds are also commonly spotted. The Great Marsh abounds in the diverse animal activity of a healthy wetland ecosystem. During the migration periods, the wetland will be frequented by flocks of ducks and geese. The wading birds like herons and egrets, and the songbirds such as warblers and red-winged blackbirds are abundant.

The Great Marsh is the largest interdunal wetland in the Lake Michigan watershed. It serves as critical habitat for breeding and migratory birds. This popular trail features an overlook of the marsh where you can spot a wide variety of birds ranging from Great Blue Herons to Sandhill Cranes. While much of the marsh was drained in the early 1900s for residential and agricultural use, the National Park Service began restoration of this portion in 1998. The diversity of plants, birds, and habitats signifies the return of a healthy wetland ecosystem after decades of neglect. Now restored, the Great Marsh's fens, sedge meadows, and wet prairies are again thriving and providing the natural filter to improve the area's water quality.

- Open daily from 6:00 am to 11:00 pm.
- Trail surface is grass with some sections of packed dirt.
- No restrooms or potable water.
- This trail features a short, paved wheelchair-accessible trail to an overlook of the marsh from the north parking lot.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There is 1 designated van-accessible space with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Broadway at the northwest end of the trail. 

Surface
The trail surface is natural (dirt, grass) or a wooden boardwalk with railings. It is typically at least 5 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
The most accessible portion of the trail is the Great Marsh Overlook trail.

Get to know this 1.1-mile loop trail near Bainbridge, Indiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 27 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through June.

Get to know this 1.4-mile out-and-back trail near Carmel, Indiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 25 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This route on the Karst Farm Greenway begins at the North Trailhead in Ellettsville. Along this trail, you'll get several nice views of Jack's Defeat Creek which runs generally parallel to the trail. It is possible to travel to the main trail by traveling a short distance on Woodyard Road and Loesch Road. For the southern section of the Karst Farm Greenway trail, check out: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/indiana/karst-farm-greenway

There is no official parking lot for this trailhead, but Edward Jones has publicly stated that their small lot just east of the trailhead may be used.  There is also typically parking available in the Peoples State Bank parking lot on the other side of Highway 46 from the trailhead.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
It is unclear whether designated accessible parking is available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Known barriers include metal bollards at the trail entrance.

Enjoy this 10.7-mile loop trail near Borden, Indiana. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 25 min to complete. Explore this 1.5-mile out-and-back trail near Evansville, Indiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 28 min to complete. Green's Bluff Nature Preserve features forest, rocky bluffs, and a lush floodplain forest. The bluffs are house a grove of eastern hemlock trees, a species that is only found in Indiana on steep, north-facing slopes that provide a cool environment. 

This loop is located in the southern portion of the preserve. It offers opportunities for wildlife viewing, as well as a fun excursion that follows the area's ravines.

Check out this 4.0-mile out-and-back trail near Goshen, Indiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 10 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October.

Newburgh Trail starts at the nature preserve entrance and follows an out-and-back route through a shaded woodland. It passes the Nature Center and Maple Sugar Shack, offering a peaceful path ideal for birding or a refreshing jog beneath the forest canopy. Pets are not allowed anywhere in the preserve.

Check out this 3.7-mile loop trail near Griffith, Indiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 4 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through November. O'Bannon Woods State Park (formerly Wyandotte Woods State Recreation Area) lies in the central and extreme southern part of the state, bordering the Ohio River. It is nestled inside 26,000-acre Harrison Crawford State Forest, but is managed separately

Due to the nature of the terrain, most trails in O'Bannon will be slightly more difficult that their similarly labeled counterparts in other Indiana parks.

Try this 0.9-mile loop trail near Vincennes, Indiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 22 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Bear Creek flows through a deep ravine with high rock walls. It is joined by a small tributary stream that has carved an opening through a massive Mansfield sandstone formation and created a natural bridge known as Portland Arch. A few native white pine are mixed with oaks and hickories on the thin mantle of soil on steep slopes. The ground is covered with mosses and lichens, and supports scattered beds of blueberry, huckleberry, and wintergreen. This is the only place in the state where the Canada blueberry is found. The rare bush honeysuckle is found here as well. Vertical cliff faces have small crevices from which grow bulblet, hayscented, and marginal shield ferns. Several colonies of Forbes saxifrage are found in larger pockets of soil. Liverworts cover moist portions of some rocks, and are occasionally joined by the creeping fronds of walking fern. Portland Arch has been recognized for its uniqueness since the first settlers came to western Indiana. A resort and then a Boy Scout camp were located in this area in the past. Now Portland Arch is a National Natural Landmark, as well as a nature preserve.

Try this 1.0-mile loop trail near Covington, Indiana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 27 min to complete. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 2.9-mile loop trail near Muncie, Indiana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 57 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through January.

This trail winds through a former Christmas tree plantation of Douglas fir and then snakes its way through tallgrass prairie, adjacent to the Prairie View group picnic area, with big bluestem, Indian grass, little bluestem, side oats grama, and black-eyed Susan. The trail continues into a fen and meanders through a marshy area, where you may get your feet wet, before entering a field being invaded by osage orange, wild cherry, mulberry, and multiflora rose.

Get to know this 0.6-mile loop trail near Unionville, Indiana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 20 min to complete. This trail is great for camping and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are August through October. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

This is a paved path is used for walking, running, and cycling.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Engle Road at the south end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 10 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along most of the trail which reduces the width. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

This short trail makes a loop on the Tripton Park property and sticks to the outermost path. The trail is a common place to spot walkers, joggers, and children on bikes. Along with a network of intertwining paths, the park also features a small pond with a fountain, a playground, an amphitheater, and lots of open green space.

The City of North Vernon maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
It is unclear whether any designated accessible parking spaces are available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 9 feet wide. Bollards near the trailhead temporarily reduce tread width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Wheelchair accessible restrooms are available near the trailhead. Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Twin Swamps Nature Preserve contains wetlands, sloughs, and old growth forests which are a lonely remnant of the Ohio and Wabash River valleys. Check out the Cypress swamp and Overcup Oak swamp. The Overcup Oak is rarely found outside the immediate area.

This preserve is full of poison ivy, make sure to be prepared before coming. If the weather has been rainy, note that the trails will definitely be muddy. During the summer, there are mosquitoes and other bugs.

This partially paved trail goes along the north/west bank of the Wabash River. South of the 1.9-mile mark of the route, it follows the County Section of the trail which is more natural, secluded, and right along the river. 

Accessibility: There is one designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Tapawingo Drive at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement (with partial railings at bridges), packed gravel, or natural surfaces, and typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 1.8 miles of the route along the pavement. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved and uneven sections. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Heads up! This is a point-to-point paddling route, so you need to be prepared to set up a shuttle to get you and your boat from the finish point back to the starting point (or vice versa). 

Flowing from North to South, the White River is a popular choice for beginner to expert paddlers. Canoe Country in Daleville has a few established routes that they use for guided tours, and the same routes are popular for people floating the river on their own.

Enjoy the sights and sounds as you hike along the White River. There are several spots to begin the trail by the river. If you like to fish or canoe be sure to bring your gear with you. This is a great place to relax and enjoy time outside with the family.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
It is unclear whether designated accessible parking is available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved, dirt, or gravel.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Enjoy this 0.6-mile loop trail near Centerville, Indiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 12 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Discover this 6.7-mile loop trail near Lake View, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route. This trail is great for birding, camping, and road biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through September.

This multi-use path is popular amongst mountain bikers, trail runners, and hikers.  The Bluebird Trail creates a couple of small loops in a lollipop fashion while staying tucked in the trees above the water. You can extend your trek onto the East Lake Trail (bikes allowed) if you want to get next to the water.

Try this 2.6-mile loop trail near Webster City, Iowa. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 55 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through July. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Discover this 0.5-mile out-and-back trail near Solon, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 10 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a great location to hike or run. It is a double wide trail that is only a short drive from the city and bikes are not allowed.

This is a nice moderate dirt trail through Browns Woods. It has primitive benches to rest along the trail, a cellular phone audio tour, and port-a-pottys at the parking lot.

Experience this 4.6-mile loop trail near Davenport, Iowa. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 43 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November.

Experience this 1.0-mile loop trail near Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 18 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, hiking, and horseback riding, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Cool Hollow is one of the loveliest places in the state, let alone the Palisades-Keplar State Park. Visitors can expect a lush, green, temperate hike through a gorgeous wooded area. There is camping and fishing nearby, so this is perfect for a short day hike for anyone already staying in the area, and for visitors driving in for the day, there are plenty of other nearby trails to fill up your day.

Experience this 1.5-mile loop trail near Burlington, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 29 min to complete. This trail is great for road biking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Get to know this 15.9-mile loop trail near Fairfield, Iowa. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 5 h 9 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 5.4-mile out-and-back trail near Harpers Ferry, Iowa. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 5 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 1.7-mile out-and-back trail near Council Bluffs, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 41 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through October. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Check out this 2.2-mile out-and-back trail near Algona, Iowa. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 44 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

The East and West Hickory Ridge Trail's main feature is scenic overlooks, a series of burial mounds and the Bridal Falls Trails, There is also a spectacular scenic view at the north end of the trail. If you walk further north on the trail past the scenic overlook, there appear to be more burial mounds. It is  situated away from the tourist sites which make for a quiet walk through the woods. West Hickory Ridge is an invigorating hike when combined with the East Hickory Ridge trail.

Try this 1.2-mile out-and-back trail near Clarion, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 21 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, fishing, and snowshoeing, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This trail is mostly flat and accessible to all skill levels. There are 2 loops, the one on the East side of the parking lot is slightly longer than the Western trail. Please do not ride when it is muddy!

There are bathrooms at the park office across the road from the bike trail/river access parking lot.

These trails are maintained by T.H.O.R, a local organization that creates and maintains many mountain bike trails in the greater Omaha area. https://trailshaveourrespect.org

This scenic loop takes you through the Little Sioux Unit of the Loess Hills State Forest. Throughout the loop there is a mix of prairie remnant, restored prairie, and woods. The open meadow near the farmhouse shortly after the trailhead has a very Western feel, while the section beginning through the open tall grass prairie is lovely. 

There's a picnic shelter at the trailhead and plenty of space for parking. The area behind the fallow field next to the picnic shelter is interesting place to explore or have a picnic under the shade of trees after finishing the hike.

Try this 1.9-mile out-and-back trail near Decorah, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 38 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October.

Enjoy this 2.1-mile out-and-back trail near Ames, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 45 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October.

A wide and paved path heading north/south parallel to the train tracks. There are several road crossings and one railroad crossing along the way.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lots off of West Forevergreen Road at the south end of the trail. Most of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

Enjoy this 2.0-mile loop trail near Wallingford, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 38 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 1.1-mile loop trail near Sioux City, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 20 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Explore this 0.6-mile loop trail near West Des Moines, Iowa. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 13 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This route features a great nature trail setting by the dog park next to Rodeo Park. The trail has some rough surfaces and difficult hills to navigate along the way. This is a wonderful trail to explore while visiting the park, as it provides a mix of settings and passes through areas of forest and open fields.

Head out on this 2.1-mile loop trail near Sioux City, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 44 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through December.

This quiet grass and earthen path begins at Whitebreast Road. You'll skirt along Red Rock Lake, Iowa. The trail takes you through beautiful, shady forest in an area managed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. During the summer months, spiderwebs are often present in the path, especially in the morning hours.

Check out this 2.6-mile loop trail near Indianola, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 50 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November.

This enjoyable trail in Sycamore Park is suitable for hiking, running, and mountain biking. The route also passes by a swimming hole - the perfect spot to cool off if it's warm enough. This route has little elevation change, and the path is well-shaded. Bring bug spray in the warmer months, as the insects here can be relentless.

Get to know this 1.2-mile loop trail near Central City, Iowa. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 28 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are July through November.

Experience this 2.1-mile loop trail near Great Bend, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 39 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through October.

Try this 0.5-mile loop trail near Fort Scott, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 9 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 7.6-mile out-and-back trail near Paola, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 19 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through June.

Experience this 0.8-mile loop trail near Vassar, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 16 min to complete. This trail is great for camping and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This paved trail goes around the pond next to the baseball and softball fields at the Veterans Memorial Park.

Accessibility: There are 6 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of East Chicago Avenue at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved with cement (with railings at the bridge) and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and bleachers along the route for resting.

The Cottonwood Trail in the River Pond area provides a short nature trail with educational information stations. It is very convenient for campers as it is adjacent to the River Pond campground. The trail length is a quarter mile of easy walking, making it very inviting for young and old.

Interpretive trail with many trees, plants, and wildlife viewing opportunities.

Try this 2.9-mile loop trail near Stockton, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 0 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Enjoy this 0.9-mile loop trail near Lawrence, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 20 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This route starts at the parking lot on the east side of Lexington Lake, where you can take a quick detour to enjoy the views of the water. The trail takes you on a well-maintained, mostly flat trail as you go through the Lexington Lake Park area. You will be able to enjoy some stunning rock formations during this hike as well. Some parts can get rocky, so make sure to wear proper footwear.

This route as mapped here is a combination of the South and North Loops within the newly-added trail system at Ford County state Park. Both loop trails are winding and twisty, and both offer hikers some long stretches of walking alongside the peaceful Ford Lake. If you're there at the right time, you can spot some waterfowl or other wildlife. You can also alter this route, or choose to do just one of the loops, since the trailhead serves as beginning, end, and midpoint on this double loop.

This path is pretty straightforward: a long, clear walk (or hike, or run, or jog) along the Gypsum Dike and back. This is a great place to stretch your legs and get some steps in, but it doesn't offer much in the way of a traditional hike, so if you're looking for something like that, probably best to look elsewhere. However, if you want a place to clear your head and relax, this might be the place!

Try this 3.8-mile out-and-back trail near Olathe, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 13 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through October.

Experience this 2.4-mile out-and-back trail near Hiawatha, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 45 min to complete. This trail is great for road biking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Kanopolis Lake State Park has lots of different routes available. The northern and western trails are predominately set up for horseback riding, but largely work well for hikers too. Trails are marked well with color coordinated banners (although you will need to pick up a map at the visitor center to be able to identify which trail goes with which color). Often there is a water crossing on this route, depending on water levels and beaver activity. This crossing can be difficult. You can still access the trails to the west by either taking the mile-long detour to the north, or by mucking your way around the dam to the south (or by fording the water, which may require full-on swimming). Great views and beautiful, unusual scenery make it all worth it!

This is a lovely, short walk from the center of the park out to the waterfall and back. This route is short but sweet, and it stays flat nearly the entire time, making it a good walk to do with kids or anyone who needs or prefers a flat path. The waterfalls are definitely at their best when it's been raining recently.

This route follows the outer loop trails of Island Park winding around the oxbows and along the southern bank of Timber Creek. The path is paved and easy-going perfect for walking, running, and cycling for the whole family. This portion of the park's trails does not have shade so plenty of sunscreen and water are recommended. 

Accessibility:

Equipment  
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking  
There is 1 designated accessible parking space with a striped access aisle in the paved parking lot.

Surface  
The trail surface is paved asphalt or compacted gravel and is typically 8 to 10 feet wide. Grass growing in the center of the trail creates an uneven cross slope in some places. 

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

This loop begins from the parking lot and takes adventurers around the rolling hills of a former golf course. With open grassland, a babbling brook, and intermittent tree cover, it provides a diverse and scenic experience for outdoor lovers in the heart of Wichita. This loop also surrounds a known disc golf course, so pack a frisbee for more outdoor fun.

Check out this 7.1-mile out-and-back trail near Ozawkie, Kansas. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 44 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This is a packed gravel trail along the Kansas River.

This is a paved loop around a community park with tennis courts and a playground. The playground has some wheelchair-accessible features.

Explore this 1.6-mile out-and-back trail near Scranton, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route. This trail is great for scenic driving, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Travel around Rimrock Park.

Try this 1.6-mile loop trail near Salina, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 30 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through July.

Try this 2.3-mile loop trail near Bucyrus, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 49 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This paved, easy, multi-use trail spans from 75th Street to 53rd Street and goes along Turkey Creek, a butterfly garden, and several parks.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the small paved parking lot off of West Frontage Road at the south end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges) and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width (temporarily). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Discover this 1.7-mile loop trail near Manhattan, Kansas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 38 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through May. A 2-mile trail through Pittsburg. There are several road crossings along the way.

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the small paved parking lot off of West 11th Street at the northeast end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There are bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width (temporarily). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Alpine Loop Trail #520 is in Pulaski County in the Daniel Boone National Forest Stearns District. The trail leaves from the Alpine Picnic Area, right off US 27.

The trail traverses a dirt pathway to the northwest before intersecting a dirt road. The trail turns westerly down the old roadway to connect with the old railroad grade. The trail then meanders along the old railroad grade southeast for .25 miles to Forest Road #5088, where it turns northeast along the road back, returning to the beginning of the trail. 

Alpine Spur Trail #520A is a short 1/4 mile trail and an easy walk for most, with various things to see and hear. The trail begins off of Alpine Loop Trail #520 and continues around the hilltop to the old road, where it will take you back to the Alpine Picnic Area.

Experience this 5.8-mile out-and-back trail near Eolia, Kentucky. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 22 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Experience this 2.0-mile out-and-back trail near Elizabethtown, Kentucky. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 36 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are September through June.

Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

This is a growing and improving trail system, so please be flexible. There are three trailheads on Commence Drive and you can also ride from downtown Elizabethtown using Haycraft and Cave Springs Trails. Look for RED and YELLOW arrows marking the main 5 mile loop. Yellow is clockwise and Red is counter-clockwise. Trails are built and maintained by the local mountain biking and trail running community.

This smooth paved greenway runs from 5th Avenue to Kentucky Lake.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of 5th Avenue at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is smooth asphalt and typically at least 7 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 2.0 miles. 

The estimated grade is moderately steep (8% or less) except for very steep (over 12%) uphill and downhill sections at about 2.1, 4.2, and 4.4 miles when going outbound east. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

Get to know this 1.8-mile loop trail near Union, Kentucky. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 48 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are October through January. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This route takes Far Hill Loop Trail to Crutcher Loop Trail to Crutcher Creek, returning via Crutcher Trail along the ridgeline overlooking the Kentucky River. Far Hill Overlook has a great vantage point, where you can see the river to the east and open farmland to the west. The creek is surrounded by tall, dense forest. The wet environment is home to plenty of wildlife and interesting fungi can be spotted on decaying fallen trees.

Come explore the popular trail to East Pinnacle, known for its stunning vistas and enjoyable hike! The journey begins on a well-maintained and relatively wide path, perfect for a comfortable start. As you make your way up, you'll discover several spots to pause and enjoy the views even before you get to the final destination. Many hikers love to start early to see the sunrise from the top – an unforgettable experience!

The last section of the trail leading to East Pinnacle gets a bit more rugged and exciting, with rocky switchbacks that are fun to navigate. The effort is well worth it when you reach the summit and are greeted by sweeping views of the Kentucky landscape. Look around at the diverse forest, home to various trees, and listen for the sounds of birds. This trail offers a great combination of a good walk and picture-perfect scenery, making it a highlight for many visitors to the area.

The trail starts at a small parking lot just before the Green River Ferry. It follows a long section of boardwalk and a flat forest trail that leads to a major trail junction at the bottom of the main path, which passes the main Mammoth Cavern entrance. When you reach the junction, take the trail to the right at 3 o’clock (as you approach). This gravel trail goes uphill, past the cave entrance, to the Welcome Center.

Head out on this 0.9-mile out-and-back trail near Louisville, Kentucky. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 25 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through August. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This route begins at the Clear Creek Campground and follows a beautiful path through the woods until reaching the Furnace Arch Trail. The trail is marked by a white diamond blaze with a turtle inside. At the beginning, there is a small creek crossing and the trail connects to the Sheltowee Trace Trail which heads uphill for a mile.

Hisle Farm Park, once an old farm set in a big meadow, is perfect for peaceful, casual walks on a well-kept grass trail. The trail is wide, and there is minimal shade, so wearing sun protection would be helpful. There are many offshoots along the trail, so use the map to stay on the trail you intend to walk. A porta-potty is at the parking lot.

You'll be treated to beautiful lake views at the start of this route, followed by a scenic section alongside a rocky creek. Along the way, you'll encounter impressive large twig statues and benches placed at intervals.

It's advisable to wear sturdy shoes suitable for the elevation changes and rocky terrain. In the warmer months, you'll also want to bring along some bug spray for the grassy areas. The route starts from Conservation Drive, where you can find roadside parking.

This is a beautiful trail that is well-maintained and easy to navigate. Several loops eventually lead to Limestone Knob- you may adjust and cut these loops out if you are short on time or want a shorter route. A swinging bridge along the way is a fun feature that crosses over to a park. The trail up to the top of the peak can be fairly challenging and rocky.

This concrete path spans the length of Veteran's Memorial Park in Livermore. The short trail is excellent for a family outing or a quick dog walk or jog, with great views of the confluence of the Green and Rough Rivers. A well-maintained lawn and tall, shady trees line the trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Surface  
The trail surface is concrete or paved asphalt and is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less), with one moderately steep (5-8%) section in the beginning that can be avoided by using the path on the west side of the parking lot.

More Info  
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Experience this 1.0-mile loop trail near La Grange, Kentucky. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 22 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This area is mainly forested, with about 54 acres of openings scattered throughout the property. It features hilly terrain with some steep areas and sinkholes along the creek. It supports moderate to good populations of deer, turkey, squirrels, furbearers, and songbirds. There are no developed facilities, and the interior trails are maintained for foot travel only. ATVs, camping, and horseback riding are prohibited, but the area is open to public hunting. Check the Kentucky Hunting and Trapping Guide for seasons and dates.

This route travels to the beautiful sandstone arch that is named Raven Bridge.

The trail on the top of the ridge is relatively flat and leads from the lodge. The route is well-maintained and marked by blue blazes along the way. 

There are beautiful views at several different points to stop and admire the surrounding areas.

The trails wind through the peaceful and beautiful woods, and there are some great areas to enjoy some small water features and a great view of the Kentucky River. 

Several benches are throughout the park, so you can sit by the creek and enjoy nature. 

Trails are open from 9:00 AM to 4:30 PM and the park closes at 5:00 PM.

This rugged trail follows Reffits Branch through the remote and scenic Clifty Wilderness on a natural-surface path marked by creek crossings, rocky terrain, and dense forest. Surrounded by towering hemlocks, rhododendrons, and hardwoods, the route offers a deeply immersive backcountry experience. Trail-goers may encounter moss-covered boulders, cascades along the creek, and signs of wildlife in the quiet, untouched landscape of this wild Appalachian hollow.

Check out this 4.6-mile loop trail near Lancaster, Kentucky. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 51 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Head out on this 1.3-mile loop trail near Campbellsville, Kentucky. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 31 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Our most challenging trail, Sand Gap requires 4-6 hours to complete. There are no shortcuts once youve started, so allow adequate time to make this trip before dark. Sand Gap Trail begins near the upper end of the Balanced Rock Trail about 500 feet from the top of Natural Bridge. For the next 3.5 miles, Sand Gap follows an old logging road and is easy to moderate walking along the ridgetop. The first section of this trail is a part of the Sheltowee National Recreation Trail. At approximately 1.5 miles from the beginning, Sand Gap Trail makes a sharp right turn and the Sheltowee Trace Trail splits off of the Sand Gap Trail and heads south. Here you will turn right continuing on the Sand Gap trail which heads northeast. About 3.5 miles from the beginning, the trail descends steeply into Lower Hood Branch. It will level out in the vicinity of a bog, then turn right across a bridge and begin to meander below the cliffs through rhododendron thickets. At about 6.5 miles, the trail descends to a bridge over the Lower Hood Branch. From here, the trail climbs up the side of the valley for about .25 mile following a skid road built by loggers in the 19th century. As you climb this section, watch carefully for the sharp left turn where the trail leaves this old road. From here, youll wind around a couple of ridges then follow a fairly level grade for about 1.5 miles to the Hood Branch Trail. You will take a left onto the Hoods Branch Trail and walk downhill for approximately .25 mile which leads to the sky lift and miniature golf parking area. Elevation change of 450 feet.

This is a scenic section of the Sheltowee Trace Trail. The first few miles feature big rocks and steep hills with a couple of creek crossings. There are some beautiful rock formations along the way to admire. The trail is well-marked but pay close attention to the map as it can be difficult to navigate along some sections.

This short paved trail circles the Shively-Newman Library, offering a simple walk through landscaped grounds and grassy lawns. The smooth path is lined with shade trees and small garden plantings, creating a calm neighborhood setting. Open views across the library grounds give the route an airy feel, while benches nearby provide spots to pause. With its easy surface and quiet atmosphere, the trail offers a pleasant stroll around this community space.

Get to know this 0.9-mile out-and-back trail near Fisherville, Kentucky. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 16 min to complete. This is a popular trail for mountain biking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The fire tower has been closed since 2008 from a fire, but you can still enjoy the many beautiful views along this route. Please pay close attention to the map as it’s very easy to miss the trail marker on connector 1056 or Buck Creek. There are several wooden and steel steps that guide visitors through steep portions of the trail.

Tunnel Ridge traverses gentle hills with lovely views. As you explore the area, you’ll enjoy picturesque views of a nearby lake and the surrounding landscape, including a golf course that contrasts the natural scenery. The trail also includes a small scramble section where some hikers might find a rope helpful for navigating the ascent and descent. Throughout the hike, look for the diverse flora and fauna that thrive in this region.

This trail begins in the Distillery Bend portion of Beckley Creek Park and explores a short and flat section of the park past Floyds Fork Creek. This is a lovely quick escape into nature! 
If you wish to explore this wonderful area further, there are several interconnecting trails to the north and south. There is also an off-leash dog park nearby.

Waverly Park is a great place to enjoy being outdoors, with many features such as various hiking trails, playgrounds, picnic areas, fishing ponds, a dog park, and more. This beautiful loop trail is a shared-use trail and well-maintained. With its winding trail, it is especially popular for mountain biking.

If you’re staying at the Zilpo Recreation Area Campground, this is a great hike that ends at a spectacular overlook of Cave Run Lake. The trail is steep and gets the heart pumping with a decent amount of elevation over a short distance. The path can be hard to locate at times, and it's suggested to keep the map handy to help navigate.

Head out on this 1.8-mile loop trail near New Orleans, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 31 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking, running, and walking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This paved path travels in a loop through Berwick along LA-182 and the Lower Atchafalaya River. The trail is smooth, easy-going, and flat with a small hill on the lower east side. The trail is mostly lined with tall, lush trees, but there is no shade on the path, so plenty of sunscreen and water is recommended. A trail map is available at the parking lot and posts are placed along the route for navigation.

The Big Creek Trail winds through 7 miles of stands of mature mixed pine hardwoods and passes many scenic points of interest including several waterfalls. Hikers should be aware this trail is rugged and best suited for the physically fit. (

Users must have a Wild Louisiana Stamp to legally access this WMAs or other LDWF-administered lands if they do not have a Louisiana fishing or hunting license

Try this 3.0-mile loop trail near Haughton, Louisiana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 3 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This water trail is facilitated by the Assumption Parish Recreation District No. 2. For more information, please visit https://www.pierrepartveteranspark.com/
 
Water trail route guide signs are installed at one-mile intervals and at important self-navigation points. The signs contain the graphic identity for the associated bird themes.

Try this 2.9-mile out-and-back trail near Ville Platte, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 0 min to complete. This trail is great for camping and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are October through April. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 0.3-mile out-and-back trail near Rhinehart, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 6 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Part of the French Market District, Crescent Park is a 20-acre urban linear park that connects the community and visitors to the riverfront. This unique public space provides breathtaking views of New Orleans, native landscaping, bike paths, a dog run, and multi-use pavilions for all to enjoy.

Elysian Fields Entrance Approximately 2300 N. Peters (ADA Compliant) Follow Elysian Fields to Decatur Street and turn right.  There is paid public parking available in the left-hand side parking lot at 400 Elysian Fields.  Exit lot and cross the street to 2300 N. Peters.  The park can be entered using stairs and bridge across train tracks or using the elevator (in the concrete shaft) and crossing the bridge to the second elevator on the riverside.

For Piety Street Entrance Approximately 3360 Chartres Street From Elysian Fields turn left on Chartres and follow to approximately 3360 Chartres Street.  Make a Right into the free public parking lot.  Enter park using Piety Street Footbridge.

Bartholomew Street Entrance Approximately 3900 Chartres Street (ADA Compliant) From Elysian Fields turn left onto Chartres and follow to approximately 3900 Chartres Street.  Follow the ramp (on right) through the break in the floodwall.  Turn right at the top of the ramp into the free public parking lot.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Chartres Street at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with partial railings) and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

Leaving from the refuge headquarters, this out-and-back trail features signs with interesting facts about the local wildlife such as wood ducks, cottonmouths, white-tailed deer and woodpeckers. The trail joins with a boardwalk that takes hikers to a large bald-cypress tree and observation deck over the bayou. In that area, benches provide an excellent spot to bird watch or listen to the sounds of nature.

Check out this 0.4-mile loop trail near Dequincy, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 7 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This trail leads to the peak of Louisiana's highest point, Driskill Mountain. Upon arrival, visitors will encounter a locked gate near the church and cemetery, clearly marked as the designated trail. The trail consists of a double-track dirt road leading directly to the summit. 

Once at the top, hikers will be treated to a breathtaking view. During the spring and summer months, it's advisable to bring bug spray. Parking is available right at the trailhead near the church and cemetery.

Explore this 0.4-mile loop trail near Eunice, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 7 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This gravel and boardwalk trail winds through the swampy habitat along a pond, linking to other trails and the park road. Wildlife is plentiful with alligators, turtles, wading birds, and many other species of local birds to spot. The easy-going trail is a quick hike with impressive views of the landscape and river to the south.

First half of trail passes through forest of loblolly pine and water oaks. Second half goes through open field and up a short hill to a rail fence, turning right to end at a collection of battlefield monuments by the roadside.

The trail is only open Wednesday through Sunday. The hours of operation are 9 a.m. to 5 p.m with the trail being closed on Monday and Tuesday.

Check out this 0.8-mile loop trail near Natchitoches, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 18 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, mountain biking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This paved trail loops around open fields, along lush treelines, and passes by the Red River. The smooth path is excellent for walking, running, dog walking, and cycling, and it has great views of the flowing river. A paved parking lot at the trailhead features a trail map. Although there are plenty of trees along the trail, there is little shade, so plenty of water and sunscreen are recommended.

The Indian Creek Nature Trail is loop trail marked with red rectangle blazes painted on the trees. This is a well maintained trail with minimal rolling hills, views of the lake, pine/ hardwood forest, and Red Cockaded Woodpecker habitats (marked with double white bands painted in the trees). Great for hiking, bikes and trail running.

The Lafitte Greenway is a pedestrian trail extending from Louis Armstrong Park to Bayou St. John and connecting the French Quarter with the Lakeview neighborhood. The trail was officially opened in 2015.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the Basin Street Station paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 4 feet wide with many wider passing spaces. There is a painted dividing line and metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Discover this 6.7-mile loop trail near Elm Grove, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 8 min to complete. This is a popular trail for fishing, hiking, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 0.6-mile loop trail near Denham Springs, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 11 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This route tours the grounds of the Oakland Plantation in the Cane River Creole National Historical Park. Be sure to grab a site map which details the significance of the preserved sites. A cell-phone tour is available online and on the web app by calling 585-421-7340 or visiting https://www.nationalparks.org/explore/parks/cane-river-creole-national-historical-park-and-heritage-area

This route follows the Blue Trail taking the lower path on the Old Blue Trail. There is a mixture of shaded and non-shaded stretches as you pass through tall hardwoods with wildflowers blooming from the trail edges in the spring. There is a diverse variety of plant life and wildlife along the trail. Look out for snakes and bugs while on the trail.

Discover this 1.4-mile out-and-back trail near Baton Rouge, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 24 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

The prairie trail is located in front of the Visitor Center. Historically, Louisiana had more than 100,000 acres in prairie, most of which has been reduced to remnants along railroad tracks.  

Prairies are grasslands which provide important host and food plants for the entire life cycle of many species of butterflies and other insects. In the refuge prairie demonstration area, spring and summer bring the opportunity to see wine cup, primrose, a variety of sunflowers, including purple cone flower and Indian blanket and other native flowers. The Prairie Trail is a concrete trail approximately one-third mile.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of Shorty Payne Road at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement (with partial edge barriers and railings). It is typically at least 4 feet wide.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. The visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

The Rock Falls Trail is a trail through mature stands of mixed pine hardwoods. The waterfall along this trail measures near 17 feet and is reported to be the highest waterfall in Louisiana.  The tributary has a small watershed so best to visit after periods of good rain. 

Users must have a Wild Louisiana Stamp to legally access this WMAs or other LDWF-administered lands if they do not have a Louisiana fishing or hunting license.

This small community park offers a lot of amenities such as a walking trail, tennis center, swimming pool, ball fields, playground, and recreation center. 

Accessibility: This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers. There are 3 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot near the tennis courts. This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (less than 5%).

This trail begins at Duke Road and follows a power line until reaching the first left turn onto the hiking and horse trail. Despite lacking markers, the trail offers a relatively straightforward journey, with a few manageable obstacles, such as fallen trees and a small creek crossing. The predominantly dirt and sand path is occasionally overgrown in certain areas, making long pants advisable for the trek. Wild Azaleas are commonly seen in bloom during Spring.

Explore this 1.0-mile loop trail near Chalmette, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 17 min to complete. This trail is great for road biking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

White Lake is predominantly a freshwater marsh, comprising about 75% of its area. The remaining land is leased property consisting of a mix of cropland, wetlands, wooded areas, and campsites. The area is home to a variety of brush and tree species that grow on numerous levees and high ground throughout the region.

Try this 0.8-mile loop trail near New Orleans, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 14 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Get to know this 2.3-mile out-and-back trail near Slidell, Louisiana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 40 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Sam Houston Jones State Park was named after the state's 46th governor who helped put aside this land for the public to enjoy. 

There is an abundance of unique animal and plant species that thrive in this area which can be seen along this trail. Bird-watching is a popular activity to enjoy along this route.

The Aaron Trail passes through some old fields and the forest on the way to reaching Fresh Pond. There are a view short but steep climbs along the way.

At Fresh Pond keep an eye out for osprey, herons, beavers, and muskrats.

Hunting is not permitted within the sanctuary, so no need to wear orange during the fall.

This is a snowmobile trail along the Androscoggin River that is used as a hiking path in the summer. The trail is dirt and can be muddy following recent rain.

In the winter months, the trail is shared by snowmobilers along with snowshoers and xc skiers.

There are views of the upper dam and Wheeler Island.

This crushed gravel carriage road is a great way to see Acadia via bike or running.

Users will pass by Jordan Pond and beneath Cedar Swamp Mountain, Bald Peak, Parkman Mountain, Sargent Mountain, and Penobscot Mountain. Users will also gaze up on the Jordan Cliffs as well. Stop and rest at the Jordan Pond House at the end.

Begin at the Bearce Allen Preserve parking area on Austin Street. Follow the Blue Trail to the Yellow Trail to cross through the Bearce Allen Preserve to the NORGAL Preserve. Hunting is permitted, so wear blaze orange during hunting seasons.

The Coastal Rivers Conservation Trust maintains this trail.

Users will begin by the Tarn and climb up around Huguenot Head before reaching the summit of Champlain Mountain.

The trail will then descend towards The Bowl before climbing over The Beehive and back up and over Champlain Mountain. Stop and rest on the shores of The Bowl before finishing the second half of the hike.

The Clarks Pond Trail is the hub of an ambitious trail network envisioned by the South Portland Land Trust and supported by local citizens, businesses and the City of South Portland. This beautiful woodland trail follows the western and southern shores of the pond to emerge on Westbrook Street. By following sidewalks 6/10 of a mile, you can complete a loop hike.

The trail is rich with local history. From the 1930s to the 1950s, ice was commercially harvested from the pond to keep local ice boxes cool in the summer months (see video). The 1.7-mile loop is popular. Most visitors can complete the loop in about an hour. You may want to take more time to enjoy the scenery.

From Elmer Hart Lane, pass through blueberry fields and through the forest towards Little Medomak Pond. The trail is marked with blue flags in the field and blue blazes in the wooded sections. Please do not stray from the established path in order to protect the blueberry bushes. Parking is also available on Jackson Rd.

On a clear day there are views of the coast and the western mountains.

The Devil's Back Trail consists of several smaller trails. 

Included west side trails are Otter Creek Trail, Byles Point Loop South, and Byles Point Loop North. The trails are all well maintained and marked.

Keep an eye out for seals in the ocean!

Dogs should remain on leash from 10am-4pm. Outside of these hours dogs should remain under voice control.

This trail provides a quiet, relaxing hike through forests and fields on a mowed grassy path. There is an opportunity to observe different species of wildlife here, so you may want to bring a set of binoculars. There is a memorial monument overlooking the inlets and wetlands that drain into Wilson Pond.

Begin from the parking area on the west side of Bartlett Road. Travel through the mixed hardwood forest past wetlands, ponds, and streams. This area harbors a diverse array of wildlife. Hunting is permitted; visitors should wear blaze orange during hunting seasons.

The York Land Trust maintains this trail network.

This loop is mostly wooded with some viewpoints of the Sheepscot River. A train track borders the northern part of the property, freight trains can sometimes be seen passing by.

Along this loop there are stands of white pines, a spring, rocky outcroppings, and old stone walls.

Hunting is permitted, so wear blaze orange during hunting season.

This trail loops through the forest at the preserve offering a short, quiet hike. It travels through a fern and hardwood glade to the shore of Parker Cove. From there, there are views of nearby coves and Hutchins Island. During the summer, there is a children's story walk here that is put on by the local library.

This short hike leads to a popular waterfall just outside Monroe with a swimming hole beneath it. Do not attempt to reach the area above the falls as it can be very slippery and dangerous.

This is a fun place to bring kids and picnic by the water. 

The area is open from dawn until dusk daily. Remember to pack out all trash.

This is a steep trail to the summit of Mt. Cutler. The summit is wooded but there are some ledges with views on the way to the summit. 

This trail passes through private property but according to the Town of Hiram Mt. Cutler Park & ​​Conservation Area, hiking is allowed. When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.

Stellar views, cliffs, and wilderness.

A long and grueling hike that hikers should come prepared for.  Great for anyone that wants a scenic trek up to Katahdin from Roaring Brook, but does not wish to cross the Knife's Edge. The portion of the hike along Chimney Lake Trail can get very muddy, slippery and wet. The climb up Hamlin Ridge has many large boulders hikers will have to scramble along. There is a section of fairly streep scree along Saddle Trail. The views atop Mount Katahdin are beautiful from all 360-degrees.
