The "O" Trail is the most challenging trail on the east side of Bradbury Mountain State Park. The trail is rolling, narrow, and steep in some places. The trail also crosses some narrow wooden bridges through areas that are often wet. The trail will be most difficult for horseback riders due to how narrow it is.

This hike wanders along the coast to Otter Point. This is a beautiful and relaxing path with amazing views of the Atlantic Ocean.

This is a great place to take photos of the rocky coast during high tide each day.

Keep an eye out for rock climbers at the popular Otter Cliffs  climbing area along the route!

Begin on a wooded section of trail not far off of Peltoma Avenue. The Trail then turns and travels alongside the Sebasticook River before heading back inland.

The trails are not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is recommended. There are many side trails off of the main outside loop.

Pigeon Hill stands 317 feet above Pigeon Hill Bay with views of Acadia National Park and the Petit Manan Lighthouse which is the second tallest lighthouse in Maine.

The 180-acre preserve is home to an old silver mine from the 1800s and many glacial erratic boulders left behind during the last ice age.

This is an accessible gravel trail on the Pownalborough Courthouse Trails. 

The Lincoln County Historical Association maintains this trail network.

According to Accessible Nature (https://www.accessiblenature.info/?page_id=157#local): The trail on the historic Pownalborough Courthouse grounds is 1500′ of hard-packed gravel with no more than a 5% grade.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
According to the park website, this trail is accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers. All-terrain tires or adaptive equipment may be needed for the surface type.

Parking
There is 1 designated accessible parking space in the gravel parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is packed, crushed gravel and is typically at least 3 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
This is the most accessible portion of the Pownalborough Courthouse Trail: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/maine/pownalborough-courthouse.

The Rock Rings Trail loops through the forest off of the Old Plains Trail. This is fun terrain on a bike.

This trail is open year round for a variety of recreational activities. For current trail conditions visit: https://www.maine.gov/dacf/parks/trail_activities/rangepond_trail_conditions.shtml#trailconditions

The trail from Roaring Brook to Russell Pond is fairly easy, though it is long. There are a few small hills if you take the trail which is 7.2 miles (on the East side), the trail is a little steeper is you choose to take the 6.8 mile trail. Canoe rentals are on a first-come, first-served basis. There are also several lean-to and a bunk house for rent. This is a good place to stay and hike to the other ponds and lakes in the area. Moose are also a frequent visitor to the ponds in the area. 

Check the weather, there is one stream crossing which can be high after it rains.

The Nature Trail is a loop trail with marked educational information about the local flora and fauna. Begin from the parking area on Cape Road. There is an informational kiosk with brochures at the trailhead.

Education Stations:
1. Eastern White Pine
2. Stone Wall 
3. Eastern Hemlock
4. Nursery Tree
5. Yellow Birch
6. Lichens 
7. Striped Maple 
8. Watering Hole Habitat
9. Glacial Erratics

The Francis Small Heritage Trust maintains this trail.

The Snowshoe Hare Trail is marked in white. The trail uses the yellow Pondicherry Trail briefly to make the trail a loop. Hikers can begin from the main parking area off Depot Rd or South High Street. Trails are open from 6am-10pm daily.

Camping, fires, hunting, and bike are not permitted in Pondicherry Park.

This land and trail is owned and managed by Loon Echo Land Trust, a non-profit located in Bridgton, Maine. Donations to support the maintenance of the land & trails are welcome and can be made at the trailhead or online at LELT.org.

Hunting is allowed at Raymond Community Forest. Wear blaze orange during hunting season.

The Stonewood Trail links Sayles Field and Bliss Woods. A 0.3-mile trail connects the trailhead to the main trail. Look for a sign that says Bliss Woods.

The trail is mostly wooded, crosses small brooks, and has bog boards are in place to help cross over areas that are more sensitive and historically wet.

This property is a large open Hayfield with the Weskeg River on one side and the Saint George River on the other. It is an important area for migrating birds to stop, rest, and eat. Along the trail there are interpretive signs about local history and birds in the area.

Hunting is permitted, so wear blaze orange during hunting season.

Users will be rewarded with views from the summit of The Beehive of the coast and surrounding mountains before dropping down to the banks of The Bowl. The Bowl is a very picturesque Pond tucked onto the side of Champlain Mountain.

The trail going up The Beehive is exposed and walks along a cliff edge at times.

This area is not maintained for pedestrians. It is a newly acquired tract of land that will be developed for a network of trails in the future. Currently, there are a series of snowmobile trails that you can follow through the property. 

Purchased by LELT in 2019, the Tiger Hill Community Forest property provides public access for a variety of outdoor recreation activities and connects critical forest resources, including an abutting property at Cold Rain Pond that is owned by the State of Maine. The property is home to moose, herons, bobcats, and deer. Maintaining this undeveloped and connected landscape helps increase resilience to climate change. The Community Forest property was identified in 2016 by The Nature Conservancy as having the exceptional capacity to support wildlife species adapting to the effects of a changing climate.

This is a short loop hike to the Wilder Hill Viewpoint in Temple. The loop is about a half mile long and is on ATV trails with loose footing at times. The viewpoint has a memorial plaque, a picnic table, and good views of Mount Blue, the Western Maine Mountains, and the Presidential Range in NH on a clear day.

From the parking area near Taylor's Landing, follow the C & O Canal Path to the hiker and biker camp near the river.

This is a great place to bring kids on an introductory backing trip, as the path is flat, level, and a short distance from the parking area.

Anglers fishing in the Potomac River should be familiar with Maryland state fishing regulations.

A wonderful walk around the park with picnic tables and shade! Very flat elevation and family-friendly.

Accessibility: There are over 12 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Northview Drive at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. According to the park website, there is a playground here that was designed to be universally accessible.

Baltimore has a rich, storied history as a seaport. In lieu of a maritime museum, the city has revamped several historic ships and other seafaring attractions into museums that visitors can climb aboard and experience firsthand. The Inner Harbor has four historic ships: the U.S.S. Constellation, a sloop-of-war from 1854; the U.S.C.G.C. Taney, a Coast Guard cutter; a WWII-era submarine named the U.S.S. Torsk; and a lightship that went by many names over the years, but is now known as the Chesapeake. Tickets can be purchased at stands outside any of the ships, and if you plan to hop aboard several you can get a pretty steep discount.
This trail is on private property. Please head somewhere else unless you've been invited by the owners.

Start at the Cascade Falls Trail off River Road. Take Garrett's Pass to Cascade Falls trail. Before crossing the river at Cascade Falls, continue straight/right onto Ridge Trail. Take Ridge Trail to Old Connector to Morning Choice Trail to Log Trail to Barley and Hops Trail to Lewis and Clark Trail. Take Cascade Falls Trail again to return to Cascade Falls Trailhead. The trail is quite a bit rocky. It features waterfalls and several stream crossings.

Discover this 1.3-mile loop trail near Union Bridge, Maryland. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 23 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 0.7-mile loop trail near Port Tobacco, Maryland. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 13 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 1.9-mile loop trail near Nanjemoy, Maryland. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 42 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, horseback riding, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are December through May.

This loop explores the Davis Area of Patapsco Valley State Park, beginning from Woodstock Road. The area is popular with both hikers and mountain bikers, especially on the weekends, so an early start is recommended. The trail spends plenty of time in the woods in addition to stretches near the Patapsco River. 

Some areas are not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful for navigating.

This route is all downhill on the way to an overlook of the Patapsco River following the Buzzards Rock Trail. It provides great views on top of the Ilchester Tunnel looking down from the cliffs.

Be prepared for the hike back up hill on the way back! 

Parking is in a gravel lot on South Hilltop Road.

Get to know this 1.1-mile out-and-back trail near Perry Hall, Maryland. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 21 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through September.

Explore this 5.1-mile loop trail near Upper Marlboro, Maryland. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 44 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are October through June. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Parking is on the same side of the street as the Blacksmith shop, across from the visitors center. Cross the road and the bridge to start the Little Gunpowder Trail. Near the half mile point you will turn onto the Horse Trail which travels back towards Jerusalem Road and the start point. Use caution when crossing the road.

This gorgeous, well-marked trail winds through the beautiful scenery, passing by an old cemetery and the ruins of a house near the beginning. The route offers stunning views of the Loch Raven reservoir, with wide and narrow sections, mainly consisting of a dirt surface. Throughout the hike, you can hear birdsong. Limited parking is available on the street close to the trailhead.

The trail is nicely wooded, where you can enjoy some peaceful hikes. It has gently rolling hills along a stream with a couple of water crossings. You can also see lots of wildlife such as deer, herons, and foxes. 

At the starting point, there is a small lot to park, but if you go further up, you can find a proper parking lot. You can find this parking lot by simply searching 'Blockhouse Point Park', which is on  190 River Rd.

Hikers can enjoy views from the well-marked Bill Lambert Overlook, accessible from the Northern Peaks Trail. The trail steepens as it approaches White Rocks Overlook.

The A.M. Thomas Trail, named for Stronghold's first superintendent, Albert M. Thomas, is followed along the ascent to the top. The majority of this trail is uphill, and the terrain has rough areas.

There are a few benches along the trail where hikers can rest. The ascent involves 168 stairs. The trail becomes steeper after it reaches the top of the steps. It levels out slightly as it gets closer to the top, ending at a clearing that marks the top of Sugarloaf Mountain.

Try this 4.7-mile out-and-back trail near Upper Marlboro, Maryland. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 30 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This loop passes by the picnic area and fields in the Pickall Area of Patapsco Valley State Park. The path then enters into the forest and heads down towards the river. There are several spots to detour off the trail and walk along the banks of the river.  This is a lesser trafficked part of the park and a great place to spend a day exploring.

This loop begins by following a flat stretch of trail along Gunpowder Falls. Just shy of a mile in, you will begin to head uphill following a rocky path. The second half of the loop is mostly wooded but does cross Walker Run which flows into Gunpowder Falls. Parking is available along Gunpowder Road.

Quiet Waters Park is a great community park with lots of paved trails and numerous additional miles of offshoot unpaved trails. You can also find a dog park, and great water views of South River. The South River leads to the Chesapeake Bay and has numerous coves. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Quiet Waters Park Road at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt with some cracks and bumps. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

Follow the boardwalk around Rio Washingtonian Lake. Pass by storefronts, restaurants, a carousel, and vista points.

Accessibility:  

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.  

Parking  
There are 2 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.  

Surface  
The trail surface is smooth concrete or wooden boardwalk with edge barriers or railings and is typically 6 to 8 feet wide.  

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).  

More Info  
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Try this 4.7-mile out-and-back trail near Manchester, Maryland. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 0 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Discover this 2.4-mile loop trail near Westminster, Maryland. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 0 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, horseback riding, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Get to know this 1.0-mile loop trail near Salisbury, Maryland. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 19 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

The trail follows the river at points and wanders through the forest crossing some creeks. Some sections are not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is recommended to help navigate.

Deer hunting is permitted in the area seasonally, so remember to wear blaze orange during hunting season.

Check out this 1.1-mile loop trail near North East, Maryland. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 21 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through June. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 3.4-mile loop trail near Swanton, Maryland. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 29 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through October.

Explore this 2.3-mile loop trail near Montgomery Village, Maryland. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 48 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Washington Monument offers a well-maintained trail suitable for families and picnics. The hike up the hill may be slippery and muddy, however, it is not too strenuous. The monument holds significant historical value and provides scenic views from the top. Keep your eyes peeled for the flora and fauna that inhabit this area.

Explore this 2.2-mile out-and-back trail near Derwood, Maryland. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 52 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Wincopin Red, Orange, and White Trails meander along a natural dirt and rock path, providing beautiful views of the Middle Patuxent River. The trail winds alongside the riverbank as you walk, allowing for peaceful river views throughout the journey. The trail is rocky in some areas, making it essential to watch your step. You may even spot a majestic great blue heron along the river.

The Yellow Poplar Trail Loop starts from the parking lot off High Knob Road and takes you to Gambrill State Park. The first section runs along the road, where you'll find the visitor center and another parking lot. The trail then winds through a beautiful forest with ferns. Be prepared for steep sections with rocks and roots—sturdy footwear is recommended. Watch for squirrels, chipmunks, deer, and other wildlife.

Get to know this 1.1-mile loop trail near Amesbury, Massachusetts. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 21 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through November.

Check out this 1.1-mile loop trail near Bolton, Massachusetts. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 25 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and snowshoeing, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Start from the parking area on the south side of Eliot Street and follow the All Persons Trail through the marsh.

Mass Audubon Metro West maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 2 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the gravel parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is crushed gravel or wooden boardwalk with partial edge railings and is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some moderately steep (5-8%) sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Experience this 3.5-mile loop trail near Acton, Massachusetts. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 6 min to complete. This trail is great for camping and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are September through May.

Begin by parking along Notre Dame Road. There is an informational kiosk at the trailhead. Follow the loop trail around the perimeter of Clark Conservation Area. This open meadow parcel is lined by trees. There are benches along this route. Respect neighboring landowners by remaining on the unblazed trail.

The Town of Bedford maintains this trail.

The Eagle Rock Trail starts from Bray Street and follows red trail markers through the forest and over Eagle Rock. From the top of Eagle Rock the nearby states of New Hampshire and Maine are visible on a clear day.

The Tompson Street Reservation is the largest property owned by the Essex County Greenbelt Land Trust.

A short loop with the option to go further! There is interpretive signage along the way.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Neponset Street at the southwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete, smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is flat (1% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. According to the park website, there are wheelchair-accessible picnic tables and a wheelchair-accessible portable bathroom at the park.

Begin from the parking area on Francis Street. Wind through enormous boulders and past rocky outcroppings. North Brook weaves through the hemlock forest and numerous vernal pools provide wildlife spotting opportunities. Look for Blanding's turtles and marbled salamanders. 

The Town of Berlin and the Town of Clinton maintain these trails.

Check out this 2.7-mile out-and-back trail near Hampden, Massachusetts. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 28 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 2.2-mile out-and-back trail near Carlisle, Massachusetts. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 41 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Begin from the parking area on South Road. An informational kiosk is located at the trailhead. Follow the blue-blazed Kathy's Trail, then turn north onto the brown-blazed Wood Trail. Loop back to the parking area via the green-blazed Old Coach Trail.

The Minnechaug Land Trust maintains this trail network.

Mount Misery is a great place to meander around, offering various nature trails with different levels of difficulty. It is accessible to hikers of all ages and skill levels. It is dog-friendly and family-friendly, so it gets busy on weekends, but there is plenty of parking available at the trailhead. The trail goes through the woods, and you can enjoy some beautiful pond views.

Enjoy this trail that packs it all in! There are so many wonderful sights on this route, such as quickly getting on top of Devils Garden, then summiting Mount Norwottuck, and passing the horse caves and onto Rattlesnake Knob. There are great vistas from Norwottuck and Rattlesnake Knob, and the trail throughout the woods is beautiful and downhill or flat the rest of the way.

Begin from the parking area on Red Gate Lane. Travel through alternating forests and fields on the Lone Wolf Trail. Arrive at the Wachusett Aqueduct and return south into the preserve. Travel east on the Riding Ring Trail, then south on the Hickory Trail. Return to the Red Gate Lane trailhead.

The Southborough Open Land Foundation maintains this trail network.

Crocker Conservation Area in Fitchburg, MA moderate difficulty loop due to cart road hill. Dogs and bikes allowed! From parking area take Flat Rock Rd trail (red triangle), take left on Flat Rock Link (blue triangle), take a right into Big’s Bushwhack trail (white triangle), take a left on Lower Loop trail (blue circle), take a left on Cart Road (white circle) up the hill, take a left on Water Department Access Rd which begins paved and turns to a dirt road until you reach the parking lot.

Get to know this 0.7-mile loop trail near Marion, Massachusetts. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 14 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through June. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Park at the trailhead off the west side of Oblong Road Oblong Road. There is enough space for six vehicles to park. Ascend through the forest to meet the Taconic Crest Trail. The high point of this steep trail is wooded. 

The Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation maintains this trail.

This Massachusetts hike winds through dense pine forests in the Four Ponds Conservation Area, offering a shaded, tranquil escape with minimal elevation gain. The well-marked path features wooden boardwalks, occasional boulders, and dirt pathways. This park is ideal for quick nature walks or family outings, with this trail exploring the majority of the parks sights.

This beautiful trail features a nice view from King Phillip’s Overlook, a lovely spot to stop and have a snack. The trail passes through a variety of scenery, including fields, woods, and marshes.

The trails are well-marked and feature nice planked walkways to cross several streams. However, after heavy rain, the trail can get very muddy, and sometimes, the overflowing Charles River floods part of it, so come prepared.

Head out on this 1.3-mile out-and-back trail near Boylston, Massachusetts. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 33 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Saint Moritz Pond was created in the 1930s by damming up a stream in order to create a pond to be used during the winter during an annual winter festival. The pond is named after Saint Moritz, Switzerland.

Today, the area is popular with birders. Ducks and herons can often be spotted along the shores of the pond.

Try this 0.2-mile out-and-back trail near Dennis Port, Massachusetts. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 4 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Soapstone Hill offers a gorgeous view of the Quabbin and the water. The trail takes you through the woods, and it is steep in parts. It is not very well-marked, so prepare a map in advance. 

If you keep hiking to the North after reaching the top, there is the Federated Women’s Club Campsite. At the outlook you can take George Trail if you want to do a loop, but it could be overgrown and slippery with fallen leaves.

Quabbin Park and  Reservation in central Massachusetts is owned and managed by the Department of Conservation and Recreation – Division of Water Supply Protection.  Over 3 million residents in 53 Massachusetts communities are a part of the water supply system that includes the Quabbin Reservoir, Ware River Watershed, and Wachusett Reservoir.   As an unfiltered water supply, recreation activities are limited to hiking, fishing and bicycling on designated routes.  No dogs are allowed anywhere in Quabbin Park or Reservation.  When planning a hike here, please visit https://www.mass.gov/locations/quabbin-reservoir for full details on what activities are prohibited.

Discover this 4.3-mile loop trail near Leominster, Massachusetts. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 7 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This is a beautiful park and beach area for a short hike. Squantum Point has a rich history and its story is told on various granite blocks throughout the park. Views of Thompson Island, the JKF library, the Rainbow Swash, and the Boston skyline are plentiful. Dogs must be kept on leash at all times.

This is a short loop trail up to Tannery Falls and back down. There are several small falls along the brook, but Tannery Falls itself is more impressive at around 70ft.
The trail is very short but has a good bit of elevation change, and the footing can be slippery at times, so take your time. 
This waterfall is best enjoyed in winter or spring when the water flows most heavily.

This flat path leading to Thompson Pond is the on the ground of the former South Weymouth Naval Air Station. The base was officially closed in September 1997.

The path starts off Spruce Street and has some benches to stop and rest at along the way. It starts along the perimeter of a field before becoming more wooded and following along the banks of the pond.

Experience this 0.2-mile out-and-back trail near Ashby, Massachusetts. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 4 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through October.

Triphammer Pond Loop is a scenic trail located within the Triphammer Pond Conservation Area. This area features a 19-acre pond surrounded by woods, offering visitors a tranquil environment to explore. The trail is well-maintained and suitable for various outdoor activities, including hiking, and running. Along the way, hikers can enjoy views of the pond, forested areas, and interesting plant life. The terrain is generally easy to navigate, making it accessible for most visitors. The area also provides amenities such as picnic tables and benches, allowing for a comfortable and enjoyable spot for people to enjoy this area. 

The trails are not well marked in some areas, downloading the map ahead of time is recommended.

Explore this 0.9-mile out-and-back trail near Swansea, Massachusetts. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 17 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 4.8-mile out-and-back trail near Barre, Massachusetts. Generally considered an easy route. This trail is great for paddle sports, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

The aqueduct trail is open to all non motorized methods of travel such as hiking, running, biking, shoeshoeing, etc.

The trail closely borders private property, so visitors should remain on the established path at all times and be respectful of homes close by.

There are not any trash cans along the trail, so please carry out all trash.

Although hikers and runners are allowed, this trail is primarily meant for mountain bikers. This loop trail takes hikers through wooded areas, open fields, and wetlands, providing a tranquil outdoor experience. The well-marked trail is suitable for all skill levels, making it a great choice for families, birdwatchers, and nature enthusiasts.

A great loop in Anderson Park that is primarily used by mountain bikers, but also enjoyed by hikers and runners. The trails are mostly fun, flowing single track. There is a section known as "The Playground" that contains features such as berms, wood obstacles, and log rides for bikers who like more technical challenges. Overall, a fantastic trail located outside of Lansing with great opportunities to spot wildlife!

The Arlington Park Trail begins at the parking area located just southwest of the park. This scenic trail meanders through the park, which features the Little Traverse Bay Educational Gardens. It provides a tranquil environment for visitors to explore nature and learn about local plant life. This trail is an excellent spot for a leisurely walk or a peaceful retreat in the heart of the city.

Arcadia Dunes, the Grand Traverse Regional Land Conservancy's largest preserve, features over 15 miles of trail that wind through dunes, forests, and various other landscapes. Adjacent working farms have also been permanently protected, ensuring the longevity of this area’s rich agricultural heritage. 

Arcadia Dunes, a part of the Sleeping Bear Birding Trail, offers an amazing birding experience. To learn more about birding at Arcadia Dunes, read the Sleeping Bear Birding Trail‘s great birding site descriptions.

Hunting is allowed at this preserve. For a full list of rules, please visit https://www.gtrlc.org/recreation-events/preserve/arcadia-dunes/

Get to know this 2.4-mile loop trail near Portage, Michigan. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 41 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 1.6-mile out-and-back trail near Beulah, Michigan. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 31 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October.

Land Description:
Close to Petoskey, this
preserve offers a short
trail and natural oasis for
exploration. Enjoy a mix of
mature upland hardwood
forest and a swampy
corridor with a small stream,
while searching for the
natural springs.
Trails: A small parking area
and short trail lead towards
the springs portion of the preserve, looping through an upland forest.

This family-friendly out-and-back trail begins at the Nokomis Center parking area off Marsh Rd near the Meridian Historical Village. It circles around the southern park pond and gently meanders alongside Mud Lake Drain, offering a peaceful walk through the natural surroundings and scenic water views of Central Park South.

Enjoy this 6.4-mile loop trail near Shingleton, Michigan. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 14 min to complete. This is a very popular area for camping and hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through October. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

The trail begins at the parking area on West Kearsley Street and extends across the park, following the Flint River waterfront. This paved, family-friendly out-and-back trail is ideal for road biking and provides a scenic route right in the heart of Flint.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is smooth concrete and typically at least 10 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly flat (1% or less).

More Info
Natural stone benches are available along the route for resting, but they may not be accessible for everyone due to their short height and uneven surface.

This loop includes many of the trails at Chipman Preserve and follows the perimeter of the park's boundary. The trails at the Preserve are relatively flat, featuring mowed paths over prairies and savannas, woodlands, and an abundance of wildflowers.

You'll find numerous intersecting trails that meander throughout the park's 230 acres, allowing you to shorten and lengthen your trip if you choose.

Get to know this 1.3-mile out-and-back trail near Allouez, Michigan. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 29 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through August.

The Corey Marsh trail is part of the Corey Marsh Ecological Research Center. This trail is the main 1.5-mile Yellow Loop. Cross-country skiing is permitted, but no bikes, dogs, or horses. There are several other shorter trails, some finished and some not, that can be added to the main loop. 

Michigan State University maintains this trail.

This short trail makes a loop on the Fowlerville Community Park property. The trail is completely paved, and it is a common place to spot walkers, joggers, people pushing strollers, and children on bikes. The path circles around a large reservable pavilion and a couple of baseball fields at the northern end of the property.

The trail starts at the Edmore Staging Area off East Forest Street and ends at the Vestaburg Staging Area off East Avenue. This paved, point-to-point route meanders through farmland, passing Bass Lake, Curtic Center Pond, and the Vestaburg State Game Area. Great for road biking, it is part of a longer multi-community trail system, offering scenic views and opportunities for extended rides.

The Friends of the Fred Meijer Heartland Trail maintain this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 3 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 8 feet wide. Bollards at street crossings temporarily reduce the tread width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Take caution when crossing roadways; designated crosswalks are not always present. Expect traffic noise on portions of this route. 

Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting. Public restrooms are available near the trailhead.

Get to know this 1.2-mile loop trail near West Olive, Michigan. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 23 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Lakefront Loop at Warren Dunes State Park starts at the parking area off State Park Rd. and takes you through rolling dunes with scenic views of the park. The trail passes Mount Randall before looping onto the sandy shores of Lake Michigan, offering a mix of forested paths and open dune landscapes. A great option for hikers looking for a variety of terrain and stunning lakefront views.

This trail loops through the rolling, wooded hills of Brighton Recreation Area, offering views of Murray Lake. The path is a singletrack that winds through a mature oak-hickory forest. This is a popular spot for trail running and mountain biking, as the path has some rooty and rocky sections. In the winter, the trail is open for snowshoeing. The path can get very muddy during the spring thaw or after rain.

Enjoy this 3.3-mile point-to-point trail near Grand Rapids, Michigan. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 1 min to complete. This is a popular trail for running and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October.

This is a loop around a water reservoir on a wide gravel trail. The route has some small hills and inclines. 

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 2 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Platt Road at the trail's east end. 

Surface
The trail surface is gravel and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Check out this 1.4-mile loop trail near Caseville, Michigan. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 25 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October.

This short trail makes a loop through the Pinewood Park property. The trail is completely paved, and it is a common place to spot walkers, joggers, people pushing strollers, and children on bikes. There are numerous amenities that the path circles around, and there is plenty of parking available at the start/finish area.

The Pontiac Lake Hiking Trail offers a well-marked path through a scenic and wooded landscape. Along the way, hikers can enjoy beautiful views and a variety of wildlife. The trail features rocky terrain with steep inclines. After the initial inclines, the trail remains hilly. Keep your eyes peeled for various plants in the area.

Experience this 0.7-mile loop trail near Wayland, Michigan. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 12 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 5.2-mile loop trail near Atlanta, Michigan. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 58 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through February. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Robert Leighton Trail is a completely paved path traveling the length of Linear Park in Northville. The park and trail stay mostly tucked in the trees behind a series of neighborhoods between Ridge Road and 6 Mile Road. The trail is popular for commuting, dog walking, pushing strollers, bike riding, running, and walking.

Northville Parks and Recreation maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There is 1 designated van-accessible parking space with a striped access aisle in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting. Take caution when crossing roadways; designated crosswalks are not present.

Check out this 0.3-mile point-to-point trail near Cheboygan, Michigan. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 6 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This route begins at the parking area for Cooper Creek Park and Spencer Forest at the intersection of Morgan Mills Avenue and 17 Mile Road. This parking lot is used by both adjacent parks. You'll follow the Yellow Trail from Cooper Creek Park, crossing the road into Spencer Forest. You'll hop on the Purple Loop trail for a short distance to connect with Blue Line, which takes you to the edge of Spencer Forest and back, passing wetlands along the way.

This trail passes through the heart of Sylvan Glen Lake Park and offers access to the southern banks of Sylan Glen Lake. You can fish from the shores of the water while the path is a popular spot for walking, jogging, bike riding, pushing strollers, and dog walking. There is a parking lot on the eastern side of the property.

The City of Troy maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 3 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Water fountains and public restrooms are available near the trailhead. Benches and picnic tables are available along the route for resting

Discover this 10.0-mile point-to-point trail near Traverse City, Michigan. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 3 h 6 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and road biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 8.7-mile point-to-point trail near Hastings, Michigan. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a popular trail for birding and paddle sports, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

In addition to the wildlife and plant life, the Waterloo SRA Winn Loop offers picturesque views of the surrounding landscape, including scenic ponds and small creeks, making the hike visually appealing throughout the year. There are also occasional vistas where hikers can pause and appreciate the expansive views of the park's natural beauty. This trail is only open to bikes in the winter.

Check out this 0.8-mile loop trail near Temperance, Michigan. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 14 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Enjoy this 3.8-mile out-and-back trail near Marquette, Michigan. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 27 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through August.

Enjoy this 1.0-mile loop trail near Fertile, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 19 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 2.7-mile loop trail near Maplewood, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 4 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are September through October.

This is a wide paved trail on older asphalt. There may be some construction along the route. There are several road crossings necessary to fully navigate the trail, so please use caution.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There is 1 designated van-accessible space with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Sibley Memorial Highway at the trail's west end. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt with some cracks and bumps. It is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

Enjoy this 6.7-mile loop trail near Andover, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 8 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of County Parkway C at the southwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or wooden boardwalk (with partial edge barriers), and typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible restrooms at the southwest end of the trail.

Check out this 7.4-mile loop trail near Fern, Minnesota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 51 min to complete. This trail is great for camping and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through October.

Explore this 1.2-mile loop trail near Edina, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 26 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through March.

Head out on this 0.7-mile loop trail near Chaska, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 13 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Explore this 2.4-mile loop trail near Kabetogama, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 49 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Check out this 3.8-mile loop trail near Belle Plaine, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 9 min to complete. This trail is great for camping and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 1.2-mile loop trail near Lac qui Parle, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 21 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Head out on this 3.2-mile loop trail near Milaca, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 59 min to complete. This is a popular trail for cross-country skiing, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are August through February.

Get to know this 7.0-mile loop trail near Chanhassen, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 27 min to complete. This is a popular trail for cross-country skiing and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This is a very nice paved trail to walk or bike. It is dog and kid-friendly. There are wild raspberries and even a few grapevines along the trail. There’s a lot of milkweed, which is great for seeing monarch butterflies.

Accessibility: There is 1 unlined designated accessible space in the gravel parking lot off of County Road 75 Northeast at the east end of the trail. It is not van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a gate across the trail at the start and at street crossings and the estimated width to go through them is 4 feet. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section at about 0.3 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety.

Head out on this 1.0-mile loop trail near Grand Portage, Minnesota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 32 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through October.

This loop is paved and moderately busy with bikers, skaters, strollers, walkers, etc. The park is large with a variety of dirt trails as well for a more varied experience. During the winter months, most of this loop is a cross-country ski only trail. It is not open to hiking or snowshoeing during the winter months. 

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of James Deane Parkway at the east end of the trail. At least 6 of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement or boardwalk (with railings) and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) sections at about 0.9 miles uphill and 1.2 miles downhill when going counterclockwise. Hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the natural and potentially slippery surface type and grade. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Enjoy this 9.5-mile loop trail near Prior Lake, Minnesota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a popular trail for mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Try this 2.4-mile loop trail near Oakdale, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 3 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through November.

Prairie Loop begins at the parking area located off South Winthrop Street, near the Battle Creek Recreation Center. This trail loops through a beautiful prairie grassland, providing scenic views and passing by a pond along the way. It is a multi-use trail, making it ideal for hiking, cycling, and nature walks.

Riley Lake Park is a great urban park with a variety of amenities, such as a basketball court, fishing pier, pickleball courts, and picnic areas. This trail follows the park's outer edge and connects to the Minnesota River Bluff LRT Regional Trail. Along the way, you'll enjoy scenic views of the 300-acre Riley Lake.

The Root River State Trail runs alongside the beautiful Root River in Houston, Minnesota. Cyclists on the trail can enjoy views of the flowers and birds, especially the trumpeter swans. During the rainy season, the river can get quite high, making for some exciting views and a rushing water soundtrack that plays in the background of your ride. The trail itself is actually much, much longer that the route mapped here, but this route is great for a day trip.

Get to know this 1.0-mile loop trail near Eden Prairie, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 18 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

A smooth paved trail with unpaved off-shoot adventures along the way. There are beautiful and interesting art pieces along the way.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of West County Road E in the center of the trail. The trail surface is paved asphalt, concrete, or wooden boardwalk (with railings). It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. The visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

He Mni Can is the original Dakota name for Barn Bluff. This "double" loop will take you through the entire park, offering an adventure along the bluff. You'll also get to hike out to the Carlson Kiln and  a view of the Winter Wall. During the colder months, the North Trail can get icy. The area is often windy.

This is a family-friendly hike that takes you around the conservancy, featuring rolling hills and native grasses. This area is part of the Belwin Education Site, which showcases public educational tours around the land about science and outdoor spaces.

Visit https://belwin.org/events/ for more info on educational tours.

This area makes up just a portion of the Belwin Conservancy.

This is a paved, multi-use trail. It is a dedicated off-road trail with a smooth surface. There are several road crossings necessary to fully navigate the trail, so please use caution.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off County Highway 30. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

Try this 1.5-mile loop trail near Eagan, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 30 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This short loop in Seven Mile Creek County Park combines the first two numbered trails (1 and 2) to show off the paths in the lower stream area. Like most other paths in the park, this route is open to mountain bikers, horseback riders, trail runners, and hikers. Trail 1 is the most popular and scenic of the two combined trails. The trail follows both sides of Sevenmile Creek and features numerous wooden bridges used to cross back and forth over the water.

Experience this 15.3-mile out-and-back trail near Minneapolis, Minnesota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 4 h 43 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, mountain biking, and road biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This route takes you around Theodore Wirth Park on a nicely paved path that winds around Wirth Lake, offering nice water views along the way. The park was named after Theodore Wirth, who was superintendent of Minneapolis Parks from 1906 until 1935. It has a wide variety of amenities and several connecting trails, offering an all-day adventure.

Get to know this 2.4-mile out-and-back trail near West Albany, Minnesota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 6 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, horseback riding, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is beautiful short trail with plenty of wildlife (Alligators, blue crane, and more). The trailhead begins on Levee Road, and features pretty greenery and flora along the way. There are no tree markers for guidance, but the trail is usually well cleared. The best use time would be during spring/summer months during a time of dryness. This trail floods very easily, so please dress accordingly and exercise caution during any periods of rain.

Head out on this 0.3-mile out-and-back trail near Brooksville, Mississippi. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 5 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Discover this 0.2-mile loop trail near Madison, Mississippi. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 4 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day.

A set of two paved loops around Cogner Park. 

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of West Oak Grove Road at the start of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is asphalt or cement, and typically ranges from 3 to 6 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is from the 0.6 to 0.9 mile mark, the inner loop of the route. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep and very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections from about 0.2 through 0.6 miles when going in a clockwise direction. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Check out this 1.6-mile loop trail near Picayune, Mississippi. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 28 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are October through January.

Try this 0.5-mile loop trail near Natchez, Mississippi. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 9 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day.

The Hillside National Wildlife Refuge Trail in Mississippi is an expansive oasis for wildlife, offering diverse habitats including bottomland hardwoods and cypress/tupelo sloughs. This refuge is vital for over 225 species of migratory birds and large numbers of wintering waterfowl. It provides a rich environment for observing abundant wildlife.

The Johnson Creek Greenway trail stretches along a flat bottomland with minimal elevation gain. It begins at Johnson Creek near U.S. Highway 61 and runs eastward towards the City of Horn Lake, Mississippi. This 10-foot-wide natural surface trail is open year-round. 

The trail is ideal for biking and hiking and is part of the DeSoto County Greenways and Parks program. It starts at the intersection of Johnson Creek and Baldwin Road in DeSoto County, Mississippi, following utility easements to U.S. Highway 61 and back. 

This remote area is home to a diverse range of wildlife, including deer, foxes, coyotes, and many small animals. The adjacent wetlands support migratory birds, and you may even spot occasional bald eagles.

Discover this 2.4-mile loop trail near Wesson, Mississippi. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 49 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through May.

This is a short educational walk around Lake Perry and showcases over 20 different species of trees along the way. The trail is flat and family-friendly, making it a great choice for a peaceful walk in the woods. There are also camping opportunities at the trailhead for those who want to spend the night in a beautiful area.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers. 

Parking
There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces near the trailhead. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically 5 to 6 feet wide. 

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less). 

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Head out on this 1.0-mile loop trail near Lucedale, Mississippi. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 21 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This is a paved loop that goes around McMillian Park. This park has several baseball fields, a playground, a pond, and a fishing pier. 

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of McMillian Park Drive at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 8 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

The Natchez Bluff Trail is a scenic path that runs along the top of Natchez Bluff, offering breathtaking views of the Mississippi River. The trail then descends via a 200-foot wooden staircase to the base of the bluff. A portion of the path on the bluff's top runs parallel to several gorgeous Victorian-era homes on Clifton Avenue.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There is at least 1 designated accessible parking space on the street.

Surface
The trail surface is brick or concrete and is typically at least 10 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

Get to know this 2.1-mile loop trail near Natchez, Mississippi. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 44 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Check out this 4.1-mile out-and-back trail near Tupelo, Mississippi. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 20 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This moderate loop connects the Whisky, Zulu, and Yankee trails with the X-ray bridge.
 
Start at the Whisky trail entrance to your NW and follow until you reach Zulu trail signs (follow red arrows). Continue on Zulu until you reach the X-ray shortcut to your west (marked with X). Follow this shortcut across a bridge over the back bayou and on to Yankee trail. Stay left at the exit of Yankee to return back to the parking lot you started from.   Armadillo and box turtles are frequently found in this corner of the park.

Experience this 2.2-mile out-and-back trail near Lucedale, Mississippi. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 38 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This is primarily a mountain biking trail through a forested area, however, hikers are also welcomed. The route is not very well-marked and it is advised to download the route beforehand to navigate. There is an extensive network of other trails that visitors can connect to throughout this area as well.

Discover this 0.7-mile loop trail near Forest, Mississippi. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 13 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

A paved and meandering trail through the Strawberry Patch Park.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Saint Augustine Drive at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is asphalt or cement, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (all 3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

This section of the Natchez Trace is where you'll find the old and eroded "sunken" Old Trace. This is a hike along a natural corridor that was used by Native American tribes. As settlers arrived, this trail was utilized by travelers and wagons that eventually wore down this path into a "sunken" section.

This short paved trail loops around Teck Park Lake and cuts through a timber canopy, offering a quick and scenic route. The path is smooth and well-maintained, excellent for walking, running, and cycling in a relaxing setting. A small parking area is available at the park's entrance and the sidewalk continues north-south along Technology Blvd for longer routes.

This dynamic mountain biking trail weaves through the wooded terrain of Hattiesburg, offering a thrilling ride with well-crafted berms, smooth rollers, and exciting descents. Designed for a range of skill levels, the trail balances speed and technical flow, keeping riders engaged without overwhelming beginners. Towering pines and dense foliage line the path, creating a natural tunnel that enhances the sense of movement and immersion. With clear trail visibility and well-maintained surfaces, it provides a consistently smooth yet adventurous ride. Whether seeking a fast-paced sprint or a casual cruise through the woods, this trail delivers an exhilarating experience in Mississippi’s scenic outdoors.

This singletrack path is suitable for mountain biking, hiking, and trail running. Rated as a moderate trail, it offers a quick-flowing route between State Park Road and Group Camp Drive, making it accessible for individuals of all skill levels. The trail features a gentle descent of approximately 33 feet, with an average grade of -1.1%, and is open to both directions of travel. Trail goers can expect a well-maintained trail that winds through the park's scenic wooded areas, providing opportunities to observe local flora and fauna. Dogs are allowed on the trail but must be kept on a leash.

South Loop at the VNMP is a paved road with monuments along the way.  Great for walking, running, and biking.  Somewhat hilly route but beautiful and any traffic is moving slow and the road is one way and wide.

This full trail is not wheelchair or stroller friendly due to consistently steep (8% to 12% grade) and very steep (over 12% grade) up and downhill sections. The visitor center and USS Cairo exhibit are accessible for those with disabilities.

Get to know this 3.0-mile loop trail near Hernando, Mississippi. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 6 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This stretch of the Wolf River weaves through cypress knees and strainers in a meandering maze from Michigan City, MS to La Grange, TN. The put-in is at Indian Creek off MS-7, and the take-out is just past Yager Dr south of La Grange. There are many portages and tight spots that might be challenging for canoes.

This trail is wide and relatively flat traveling beneath tall, winding trees. Trail markers are placed at the trail junctions, making this trail easy to find and navigate. The wetland habitat is a magnet for wildlife, plants, and several species of mushrooms which can often be found on decaying fallen trees. Parts of the trail can become muddy and hard to traverse after heavy rain.

The 1000th Mile Trail interprets the ongoing efforts to remove invasive red cedars and restore a glade area. The trail begins with a 30-yard level concrete path to a bench overlooking the glade restoration area. From the bench, the trail drops to the bottom of the glade before continuing along a ridge to an old service road where it opens up to a scenic area of the lake. Once back in the wooded area, the trail follows the land's contour back to the trailhead. Hikers will commonly see birds such as eagles and turkey vultures, wildflowers such as western wallflower, and glade plants like prickly pear cactus. This trail also offers spectacular views of Truman Lake from the bluff.

Explore this 3.2-mile out-and-back trail near Kansas City, Missouri. Generally considered an easy route. This is a popular trail for mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through December.

Paddy Creek Trail is a rugged route that travels through a typical Ozark forest of hardwoods and pines with rocky outcroppings and seasonal waterfalls. There are several creek crossings over Paddy Creek and scenic bluffs overlooking the Big Piney River. This trail is considered one of the best trails in the state and is great for a first-time backpacking trip as the trail is well-marked and easy to navigate.

Bluff Ridge Trail offers visitors an opportunity to experience the park’s oak-hickory woodland. The north-facing slopes along Bluff Ridge Trail represent what most people think of as a typical Missouri woodland. Richer, moister soil found on the north-facing slopes near the trailhead supports large red oak trees. A highlight along the trail is a bluff outcropping overlooking a portion of the 55,600-acre Truman Lake.

Trail starts in the Bluff View Campground at the C Loop showerhouse. It is lightly trafficked loop and not well maintained but is still a nice, relatively easy trail. Mostly gravel until you start the loop. At the fork at the top of the hill you turn left as going straight goes into a subdivision.  There are a couple of overlook decks with benches that would provide nice views of the lake/river when there arent a lot of leaves on the trees

This trail in Castlewood State Park is absolutely beautiful, winding its way through stunning thick woodland. The trail begins from Kiefer Creek Road, which offers parking facilities. Additional parking and restroom facilities are located a short distance north of the trailhead. 

The path is well-marked and wide, with soft sand near the Meramec River. Be cautious of roots protruding from the ground towards the end of the trail.

Explore this 3.9-mile loop trail near Van Buren, Missouri. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 42 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are September through October.

Head out on this 1.0-mile loop trail near Knob Noster, Missouri. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a popular trail for birding, fishing, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This paved path winds around Cooper Park's sports facilities and open meadows. The trail is wide and well-lit, great for a jog or an easy bike ride. 

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 4 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is concrete or paved asphalt and is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

This scenic route follows the road around Dames Park, creating a wide, paved circuit through open fields, wooded borders, and community recreation areas. The gently rolling route offers a steady rhythm for walking, running, or biking, with views of sports fields, playgrounds, and picnic shelters along the way. Framed by a mix of sunlit stretches and scattered trees, the loop provides a spacious, well-connected path for extended outdoor activity.

Hickory Canyons is defined by its box canyons and sandstone cliffs. This forest is dominated by northern red oak, white oak, and sugar maple. There is also dry mesic sandstone forest along the upper slopes and around the trailhead. There, and also on the dry sandstone cliffs, are shortleaf pine, white oak, black oak, blackjack oak, scarlet oak, post oak, and mockernut hickory. Understory trees and shrubs on the dry sites include azalea, flowering dogwood, farkleberry, and ironwood.
 
The short trail offers good views of the area's distinctive bluffs and canyons. The trail from the parking area leads to a steep-walled box canyon. Across the road from the parking area is a more strenuous, one mile trail that traverses the steep terrain through the sandstone forest. It also crosses a scenic creek in a few locations.

The Sonya Glassberg Family Conservation Area is about six miles south of Eureka. The property helps to maintain and enhance the ecological and recreational values of the LaBarque Creek Watershed, which supports a high quality stream system and diverse plant communities. The woods are dominated by oaks, hickory, maple, and cedar with an understory of flowering dogwood and redbud. The area is mostly forested and there are several intermittent streams and a three acre fishing lake.

This scenic trail winds through the wooded hillsides of Huston Wyeth Park, offering a fast, flowing ride on packed dirt with playful terrain. The Goose Trail features smooth rollers, sweeping berms, and gentle elevation changes that keep momentum high and effort steady. Surrounded by hardwood forest and occasional blufftop glimpses, the trail provides a fun, approachable loop that blends speed with scenic rhythm.

Honey Run Trail is blazed in Yellow. This trail is actually three diverse trails in one. Starting at the trailhead along McCubbins Drive, the Uplands Flatwoods section of the trail goes through a natural community known as the upland flatwoods.
