Due to a soil feature known as fragipan, which restricts water movement below the surface, this rare community has pools of water on the surface half the year and soil that cracks due to lack of water the remainder of the year. As the trail drops off the ridge, it passes through woodlands before coming to a bottomland community and ending at the stream that runs through Honey Run Hollow. From this point the trail branches into two separate loops.

The South Loop runs through a bottomland woodland and loops around Honey Run Creek. Ozark sculpins and bleeding shiners, which are found only in the Ozarks, can be discovered in this creek. Depending on the time of the year, tall bellflower, spring beauty or river oats can be found growing near the stream bank.

The North Loop offers a variety of different communities from woodlands dominated by post oak and white oak trees to bottomland communities. Interspaced between these communities are numerous dolomite glades and views of the lake before the foliage comes out in the spring.

Check out this 6.6-mile loop trail near Fredericktown, Missouri. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 55 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, hiking, and horseback riding, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This segment of the Katy Trail heads from Starr Street in Huntsdale to the Missouri State Capitol. There are several road crossings along the way.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Starr Street at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (asphalt, cement, wooden bridge with railings) or gravel and typically at least 5 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 30 miles heading southeast. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep and very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections at about 3.0 and 30.8 through 31.6 miles when going southeast. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Discover this 10.4-mile point-to-point trail near Jefferson City, Missouri. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 3 h 2 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, road biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 0.7-mile loop trail near Belton, Missouri. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 13 min to complete. This trail is great for road biking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This scenic paved trail winds through the heart of Maryville, offering a smooth, accessible route that connects parks, neighborhoods, and community spaces. The gently rolling terrain passes open fields, wooded sections, and quiet residential areas, creating a varied yet steady rhythm for walking, jogging, or biking. With benches, shade trees, and wide views along the way, the trail provides a welcoming corridor through this vibrant small-town landscape.

The Mississippi River Greenway at Jefferson Barracks Park is a popular, fairly flat out and back trail along the Mississippi River. It is mainly asphalt but also includes brick pavement and concrete bridges at the start. This popular trail is shared by young and old walking, jogging, running, biking, strollers, and wheelchairs. It starts at the north end of Jefferson Barracks County Park and travels behind Notre Dame High School and River City Casino before ending at River des Peres.

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Bagby Road at the southwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with partial railings) and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide. There are metal bollards along the trail which reduces the width (temporarily).

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

This paved trail winds through open grassy areas and along the edges of a quiet neighborhood park, offering trail-goers a smooth, easy route ideal for walking, jogging, or casual biking. With flat terrain, nearby playgrounds, and shaded benches, the trail provides a relaxed, family-friendly atmosphere perfect for everyday outdoor activity and peaceful strolls.

Experience this 9.9-mile loop trail near Dora, Missouri. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 59 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, birding, and camping, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This paved route parallels the Northeast Parkway then the Northwest Parkway from Ashland Avenue to Karnes Road and back. The trail goes through north St. Joseph neighborhoods. It also connects to Corby Grove and Parkway.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
It is unclear whether designated accessible parking is available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved with mostly concrete and is typically at least 4 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be moderately steep (5-8%), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

This scenic trail winds through quiet oak-hickory forest and rolling terrain, offering trail-goers a peaceful route with a mix of shaded woodland and sunlit clearings. The natural-surface path features gentle elevation changes and occasional rocky sections, making it ideal for a relaxed hike or nature walk. With its secluded feel and opportunities to spot wildlife, the trail provides a refreshing escape into the wooded hills near the Lake of the Ozarks.

This scenic trail loops through the restored native grasslands of Rushin Prairie, following a mowed and natural surface path bordered by big bluestem, switchgrass, and wildflowers that shift with the seasons. The open terrain offers wide views under expansive sky, where butterflies drift and meadowlarks call from fenceposts. Subtle rises and gentle curves lead through a landscape shaped by wind, light, and the quiet persistence of prairie life.

Head out on this 2.4-mile loop trail near Asbury, Missouri. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 43 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

A well-maintained, well-shaded, paved path that is good for exploring the creek. Enough people around to feel safe but not crowded.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Northeast Barry Road at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete (with partial railings) and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms along the trail. There is a playground with some wheelchair-accessible features such as a firm and stable surface.

The South Pond Loop in Gateway Arch National Park offers an exceptional experience in St. Louis, MO. Starting at the commons area just south of the Basilica of St. Louis., this paved, family-friendly loop around South Pond features stunning views of the St. Louis skyline, the Mississippi River, and the iconic Gateway Arch. Immerse yourself in rich history as you enjoy this scenic urban trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
While there is no accessible parking available within Gateway Arch National Park, passenger drop-off/pick-up is available on 4th Street across from the Old Courthouse, between Market and Chestnut Streets. Accessible parking is available (first come, first served) on Market Street between Memorial Drive and 4th Street and on Memorial Drive between Walnut and Market Streets and Chestnut and Pine Streets. Accessible parking spaces are also available at Stadium East Garage, which offers a discounted rate for Gateway Arch visitors.

Surface
The trail surface is pebbled sidewalk and is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with one moderately steep (5-8%) sectionå that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Check out this 4.1-mile loop trail near Vienna, Missouri. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 46 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are September through April. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Tall Oaks Trail is blazed in yellow. Tall Oaks Trail leads through a wide variety of the natural communities. After following the shoreline of Crowder Lake, the trail leads through a mesic bottomland forest composed of sycamore, river birch, cottonwood and black walnut trees. Rising out of the bottoms, the trail traverses a mature woodland dominated by white oak and hickory trees and, at the summit of the ridge, an old field. The South Loop to Thompson River Trail can be accessed by white connector 2, referred to as the Steep Creek Connector (0.80 mile), or white connector 3, also known as the Northwest Passage Connector (0.80 mile). Additional trail mileage includes the 0.20-mile spur across Crowder Lake dam and the 0.40-mile spur from the campground.

Discover this 0.7-mile out-and-back trail near Warsaw, Missouri. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 17 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, fishing, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through June. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Ulysses S. Grant National Historic Site is a 9.65-acre United States National Historic Site located 10 miles southwest of downtown St. Louis. The site, also known as White Haven, commemorates the life, military career, and presidency of Ulysses S. Grant. Five historic structures are preserved at the site, including the childhood home of Ulysses' wife, Julia Dent Grant.

The National Park Service maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 4 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
According to the website, the Visitor Center and museum near the trailhead are universally accessible. The park offers assistive equipment and devices for loan, and braille brochures are available. Ask a ranger at the Visitor Center for more information.

According to the park website, all outbuildings on the property and all but one room on the first floor of the main house are accessible. A narrated video (captioned and audio described) is available for viewing, and rangers can provide a binder with photographs and interpretive text.

Public restrooms are available near the trailhead. Benches are available along the route for resting.

Experience this 0.8-mile loop trail near Warrenton, Missouri. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 17 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

This trail is very steep and rocky for the first half mile and less so for the second half. A short and vigorous hike through forest leads to Baker Point, with panoramic views. A perfect, easy hike for beginners or a quick out-and-back. Baker lake is beautiful and had lots of fish if you’d like to bring a collapsible pole.

Enjoy this 24.9-mile out-and-back trail near Hamilton, Montana. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 10 h 15 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and horseback riding, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 12.7-mile out-and-back trail near Cameron, Montana. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 7 h 0 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and horseback riding, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October.

The Continental Divide National Scenic Trail (CDT) is an epic long-distance hiking trail and one of the three national scenic trails that make up the "Triple Crown." The trail stretches approximately 3,100 miles across the United States, spanning from the Mexican border to the Canadian border.

This section takes you from Schultz Saddle to Johnson Lake through the Anaconda Pintler Wilderness.

Most northbound thru-hikers start their trips sometime between late March and early May.

Head out on this 4.8-mile out-and-back trail near Hungry Horse, Montana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 56 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Nestled at the base of Sinopah Mountain, Painted Teepee Peak, and Chief Lodgepole Peak, you'll find Cobalt Lake. This beautiful, peaceful lake is a great destination for a day hike or overnight trip. There is a backcountry campsite at Cobalt Lake. On the way, you'll cross several stunning footbridges. Rockwell Falls, a gorgeous cascade, is also a quick side trip - and worth it! The trail eventually climbs steeply out of the Two Medicine Lake basin towards Cobalt Lake. You can also opt to take the boat across Two Medicine Lake as part of your trip. This will shorten your hike. 

This route is not recommended as a winter hike. It can snow through the summer at higher elevations and depending on conditions. It is a good idea to keep an eye on conditions, especially if you are planning on backpacking the route. It is also recommended to download your offline map ahead of time since cell service in the park is unreliable.

This trail takes you through the heart of Custer National Cemetery in Little Bighorn Battlefield. Like most national cemeteries, Custer was established long after those who fought here were buried. Visitors can listen to narratives of soldier movements and war accounts via a self-guided cell phone tour; this information is available on placards throughout the monument.

Accessibility: This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete, typically at least 5 feet wide. This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less). According to the park website, accessible parking is available at the Little Bighorn Visitor Center. Wheelchairs are also available for checkout there.

This route takes hikers, walkers, runners, and mountain bikers from Davis Gulch Road up to the top of Mount Ascension. There are tons of paths you can take in order to do this, but the route shown here follows Davis Gulch Road to Eagle Scout Trail, Archery Trail, Easy Rider, 2006 and then up to the Summit.

Enjoy this 0.2-mile loop trail near Bridger, Montana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 16 min to complete. This is a popular trail for walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are June through September. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Head out on this 1.4-mile out-and-back trail near Dillon, Montana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 55 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through December.

Enjoy this 13.4-mile out-and-back trail near Philipsburg, Montana. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 27 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are May through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 0.9-mile loop trail near Nashua, Montana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 16 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Get to know this 12.1-mile out-and-back trail near Highwood, Montana. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 34 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Four Dances Rim Loop winds through ponderosa pines and rocky outcrops. The trail is wide and well-maintained, leading you through open sections with expansive views. As you hike, look for wildlife such as moose, bears, or foxes. The trail includes rocky, loose switchbacks. From the top, you’ll be treated to dramatic vistas of cliffs.

Begin the hike at the parking location at the intersection of Morrell Clearwater Road and Rice Ridge Road. The best way to do the first section of this trail is on bike, otherwise the beginning will be a road hike for roughly 3 miles. Once you get to the actual trail (which can be overgrown at times) there are places to hide you bike or lock it up among all of the Huckleberry bushes.

The initial ascent is pretty steep, you will climb a couple thousand feet in a hurry so make sure your boots are tight. Once you make it to the top of the trail; which is just below Sunday Mountain peak, you will go through a saddle with a gorgeous view of Grizzly Basin.

Continue along the trail and make your way through the upcoming small canyons and rock face traverses. Around 5.5 miles, be careful and watch your footing. This are is a rock slide scramble. The trail becomes very difficult to follow after descending from the pass - a few cairns are present but mostly you will rely on orienteering. Once you have passed the scramble it is all almost all down hill from there.

You have a small incline up through some lightly wooded areas that are awesome for seeing deer and wildlife at the right time of year, followed by a canyon descent essentially the remainder of the hike until you come to the spillway of George Lake. Camping along the lake is pretty easy, just find one of the many plentiful spots and set up.

Explore this 5.3-mile out-and-back trail near Victor, Montana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 50 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 6.8-mile out-and-back trail near Dillon, Montana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 46 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, birding, and camping, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Attracted to the colors of the canyon and the possibility of those colors yielding gold, Dr. Barry began exploring Bighorn Canyon in the 1890s. During his exploration, he happened upon the Trail Creek Valley. He never found enough gold to make himself rich, but the canyon and the surrounding environment offered all he needed to make another kind of fortune. He converted to operating a guest ranch. He used the natural opportunities of hiking, fishing, hunting, camping, and horseback riding to entice more clientele to his ranch.

You may visit Hillsboro in the Trail Creek Valley one of two ways: the first, a one-mile round trip hike begins by driving up the red dirt road between Trail Creek campground and Barry’s Landing to a closed gate. From there, a half-mile hike will take you to the abandoned site of Hillsboro ranch. Take some time to explore the buildings and learn how the Barrys ran the Hillsboro Guest Ranch. Don’t forget to stop at the corrals below the kiosk on your way back. The second option is a three-mile loop. You may start either in the campground or at the gate and walk to the ranch. The trail continues behind Eddy Hulbert’s cabin on the historic ranch road up to the park road. Follow the road to the Barry’s Landing turnoff back to where you began.

Explore this 6.9-mile out-and-back trail near Cooke City, Montana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 43 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, birding, and camping, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Montana State University foothills trails system offers some great opportunities to explore the national forest just outside of Bozeman, and just east of Hyalite Canyon. The Kirk Hill Trail begins on the foothills trails just outside of the National Forest. The full Kirk Hill Trail as mapped here takes you to Moser Jumpoff Road and back.

This loop begins just below the official Strawberry Lake Trailhead, off of Strawberry Lake Road. 

There is a good chance that you'll be sharing the trail with other hikers, bikers, dogs, and horses. Keep an eye out for others on the trail and remember general trail etiquette: horses and uphill traffic have the right of way, and dogs should yield to everyone else on the trail.

Get outside of Missoula city limits with the Maclay Flat Trail in Lolo National Forest. This is a family-friendly trail that is easy to complete. Along the way, the route goes through meadows and to the Bitterroot River, featuring mountainous views all throughout. The pathway is level and surfaced to accommodate wheelchair users.

Accessibility: It is unclear designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Forest Road 19155 at the west end of the trail. The trail surface is gravel. It is typically at least 4 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

This short trail makes a loop on the Maloney Ranch Park property. The trail is a common place to spot walkers, joggers, and children on bikes. The path circles around a playground, shelter, picnic tables, basketball court, and large grassy sports field. The path can also be accessed from a few different paved and unpaved spur trails leading to some of the nearby neighborhood sidewalks.

The Maud S. Canyon Loop starts at the parking lot off Saddle Rock Road and leads into Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest. The trail is well-maintained and well-marked, but be prepared for a steep ascent and descent with switchbacks and loose rock—sturdy footwear is recommended. Your effort will be rewarded with great views of Butte.

Check out this 1.5-mile loop trail near Whitefish, Montana. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 32 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through August.

The Numa Ridge Fire lookout is a historic staffed wooden lookout structure that was built in 1933. Nature writer Edward Abbey stayed at this lookout post in the summer of 1975. This hike begins near the Bowman Lake Campground and Ranger Station. You'll begin by hiking along the Bowman Lake Trail before climbing steeply up the Numa Ridge Trail to the lookout. You'll want to budget extra time to enjoy the incredible views before doubling back and returning the way you came.

The Old Yellowstone Trail (referred to by locals as the "Old Yeller Trail") can be split into two distinct sections: a North section and a South section. This northern portion of the route is entirely on a wide and smooth dirt road traveling up and down Paradise Valley. There are continuous views from both sides of the quiet road that can easily be driven using a 2WD highway vehicle.

Walk through the interpretive center and climb the boardwalk to see Captain Clark's signature only lasting evidence of the Lewis and Clark expedition atop Pompey's Pillar. The pillar was used to record the passages of trappers, military, railroad workers, and settlers with carvings all throughout the 1800s. 

Even if the gates are closed, you may visit Pompey's Pillar during daylight hours. Park at the closed gates and walk 3/4 of a mile to the start of the trail.

Get to know this 12.4-mile out-and-back trail near Gallatin Gateway, Montana. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 35 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, fishing, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are June through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 23.0-mile out-and-back trail near Hamilton, Montana. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 9 h 9 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 12.7-mile out-and-back trail near Hamilton, Montana. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 9 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 13.1-mile loop trail near Ririe, Idaho. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 25 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, hiking, and horseback riding, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are June through September. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This is a paved loop around the baseball fields at Community Park. This park also features a playground. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of East 25th Street at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 8 feet wide. The estimated grade is flat (1% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Enjoy this 10.4-mile out-and-back trail near Kooskia, Idaho. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 52 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through September. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

The trail circles the lake, features a park on the water, with swimming. The trail itself is a mixture of concrete sidewalk, wide asphalt trail, gravel, stairs, narrow dirt track and uneven rock. 

Dogs may be allowed on some of the surrounding trails, but are not allowed to enter the Dierkes Lake Park itself.

Dogs ARE allowed on the trail, but they are not allowed within the sidewalked areas or swimming hole. Leashed dogs are allowed to be walked from the parking lot to the trailhead across an open grass area.

Check out this 2.9-mile out-and-back trail near Alpine, Wyoming. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 57 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Enjoy this 25.2-mile out-and-back trail near Melba, Idaho. Generally considered a challenging route. This trail is great for birding and off-road driving, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

The Huckleberry Trail in Mary Minerva McCroskey Memorial State Park is a short loop that offers views from up above Skyline Drive in the southern portion of the park. The route climbs uphill to a pretty good viewpoint before circling around the viewing area and dropping back down in elevation to the parking area.

Enjoy this 5.8-mile loop trail near Idaho Falls, Idaho. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This trail is great for off-road driving, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

You will be accessing this trail from the Lily Marsh Trailhead. This trail is short, and good for families. The route starts on the Fox Run Trail, then turn right at the Lily Marsh Trail. You will cross a bridge over the north end of the marsh and then continue south along the beautiful Lily Marsh. 

You will leave the marsh and climb to an open area with views of Payette Lake and then continue back into the forest, ending at the Fox Run Trailhead.

From approximately December to April, the park is closed to hikers and bikers. During this time the park is open to snowshoers and cross-country skiers. No dogs are allowed in the park during winter access season, except on Rover’s Round About (a dog loop for skijoring or snowshoe walking).

This trail connects to the Fox Run Trail on both sides, if you wish to extend
your trip.

This short trail makes a loop on the Midway Park property. The trail is a common place to spot walkers, joggers, and children on bikes. The path circles around some baseball and softball fields and a playground. The park itself also features pickleball courts, a splash pad, picnic shelters, and a soccer field.

Head out on this 8.3-mile loop trail near Macks Inn, Idaho. Generally considered a challenging route. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through August. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This trail is shared with mountain bikers.

Trail start by the Mike Harris Campground and goes to the Oliver Peak. After hiking for about 2.5 miles you get to a intersection where the main trail follows to the right and another side trail  goes to the left - take this one to the peak. Then at about 3.8 miles you will have to get off the main trail and hike up to the peak. This section is difficult to follow since the trail is washed out - it is recommended that you use the uploaded GPS track to help you get to the top.

This route takes you along One Spoon Trail, which is a great hike with some steep climbs and really fantastic views. If you're not familiar with the area, there is no river or water on the trail—the river is a few minutes from the trailhead. It's excellent for a cool-down afterward, but bring lots of water in the summer as there are some exposed sections of the trail.

This is considered a rest day section of the Pacific Northwest Trail. Before and after Bonner's Ferry are incredibly remote stages and require several days of challenging hiking without the opportunity to access services or re-supply. Rest up here, eat a lot, and fill your backpack with essential items before pushing on.

The next chance for re-supply is Metaline Falls, which is several days away.

Check the PNT's official site https://www.pnt.org/ for all relevant and important information. Several permits are necessary before hiking and camping along this trail.

Experience this 8.4-mile out-and-back trail near Plummer, Idaho. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 55 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 5.3-mile out-and-back trail near Bonners Ferry, Idaho. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 3 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are July through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a fun ride or hike through some historic buildings, forests, and along the shoreline. There is beautiful scenery in this bird and wildlife refuge. Dogs are not allowed in the trails in the park, but dogs are allowed in the parking lots only on a leash.

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Green Canyon Road at the south end of the trail. The trail surface is gravel, a natural surface (dirt, grass, rocks), or paved asphalt. It is typically at least 5 feet wide. There is a double track along some of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate.

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type.

Get to know this 1.1-mile out-and-back trail near Boise, Idaho. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 22 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Off the highway there is a dirt road, not suitable for low clearance cars, that goes for about four miles to the top of a hill near where a fence and gate reside. Sign reads "No Motorized Vehicles" at the fence. There is descent into the valley that winds up along the valley floor. Usually very mild grass lands in the bottom of the valley leading up, but there are some rocky patches as the trail winds through a dry creek (may be wet depending on time). Mostly mild climb up the valley with some hills. Great for hiking, backpacking, mountain biking and even e-biking. Wouldn't recommend a hike or backpacking unless you can drive four miles to the valley mouth.

Proceed cautiously on this 67.6-mile loop trail near Lowman, Idaho. Generally considered a highly challenging route, it takes an average of 32 h 48 min to complete and should only be attempted by experienced adventurers. This is a popular trail for backpacking, birding, and camping, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are June through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 7.5-mile out-and-back trail near Fairfield, Idaho. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 50 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, horseback riding, and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Head out on this 2.1-mile out-and-back trail near Ketchum, Idaho. Generally considered a challenging route. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are June through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Experience this 4.7-mile loop trail near Island Park, Idaho. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 27 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, cross-country skiing, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

This backpacking loop, popularly known as the Alice-Toxaway Loop, is an amazing trail through Sawtooth National Recreation Area and Sawtooth Wilderness Area in central Idaho. It offers beautiful natural features at nearly every turn. From craggy sawtooth peaks to numerous alpine lakes - Alice Lake, Twin Lakes, Toxaway Lake and Farley Lake - the trail takes you through dense forests with all manner of animals. 

Most hikers choose to explore this area over 2-3 days. This loop is also known as the Tin Cup Hiker Loop. You'll begin at the Tin Cup Hiker / Petit Lake trailhead, traveling along several trails on your trip including: Petit Creek, Alice Lake, Yellowbelly, and Petit Lake Cutoff Trail. 

To get to the trailhead, follow highway 75 south from Stanley, Idaho about 15 miles to the Pettit Lake turnoff on the right.  Follow this graveled road, bearing right at the intersection to the Pettit lake campground. Just past the campground is the large parking area for the trailhead. The trailhead has restrooms and permits available for groups 7 people or smaller. Groups larger than 7 must contacting the Stanley Ranger Station for a large group permit.

Get to know this 1.0-mile loop trail near Belleville, Illinois. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 19 min to complete. This is a popular trail for walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Experience this 20.1-mile loop trail near Chandlerville, Illinois. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This trail is great for birding, camping, and horseback riding, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through October.

Experience this 0.7-mile out-and-back trail near Savanna, Illinois. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 18 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October.

Discover this 6.6-mile loop trail near Princeville, Illinois. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 20 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October.

Head out on this 2.5-mile loop trail near Lacon, Illinois. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 57 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November.

Check out this 10.2-mile loop trail near Anaconda, Montana. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 49 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 1.0-mile out-and-back trail near Ponca, Nebraska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 18 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through March.

Enjoy this 1.6-mile loop trail near Melbeta, Nebraska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

The trail parallels the Big Blue River. There is a crossing of Highway 136 at about 1.2 miles into this paved route.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the small paved parking lot off of South 6th Street near the south end of the trail. They are not van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is asphalt/cement and typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for a steep downhill section (8 - 12%) at about 1.8 miles when going north. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety.

Explore this 0.6-mile loop trail near Bellevue, Nebraska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 18 min to complete. This trail is great for camping and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Try this 1.9-mile out-and-back trail near Union, Nebraska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 33 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This is a paved trail around a man-made lake. The path is wide and in great condition with several benches along the way to stop and relax. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Himebaugh Avenue at the southeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete, smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep sections at about 0.2, 2.7, 3.4, 4.6, and 5.1 miles when going counterclockwise. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

This large loop through Fontenelle Forest shows off some of the best that the property has to offer. From forests to meadows to rivers to lakes to marshes and everything in between, this loop has a little bit of everything. There are some rolling hills at the start and the finish, but the middle miles through the wetlands are all pretty flat.

Check out this 1.1-mile loop trail near Pierce, Nebraska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 19 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 2.8-mile loop trail near Bennington, Nebraska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 59 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through November. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Travel on a network of paths, including the Hackberry, Hickory, and Ridge trails, in this large forest preserve. You will walk through a protected deciduous woodland known for its birdlife, including over 240 species like the Pileated Woodpecker. The route ascends and descends the bluffs overlooking the Missouri River floodplain. This trail system is open year-round, but be prepared for snow-covered, icy, or muddy ground on the hills during the winter and spring months. There is an admission fee for Fontenelle Forest.

An excellent visitor center, free admission. Trails are well-groomed and informational. This is a destination hike with great history.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Southwest 75th Road at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, crushed rock, or a natural (mowed grass) surface, and typically at least 4 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) sections at about 0.6 and 1.8 miles when going clockwise. Hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. 

There are benches along the route for resting. According to the park website, the Heritage Center and Education Center are wheelchair-accessible.

Discover this 2.2-mile out-and-back trail near Blair, Nebraska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 41 min to complete. This trail is great for road biking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Get to know this 0.7-mile out-and-back trail near Fairbury, Nebraska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 13 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Experience this 21.2-mile out-and-back trail near Gering, Nebraska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 55 min to complete. This trail is great for cross-country skiing, road biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Murdock Trail in Lincoln, Nebraska, is a rail trail offering a generally flat surface of crushed limestone and some paved sections. It follows a former railroad line, connecting different parts of the city. You can access the trail at various points, including its connection with the John Dietrich Trail around 48th and Fremont Streets. Parking is available at trailheads and nearby park areas along the route, making it easy to hop on and explore.

Enjoy this 2.9-mile loop trail near Chadron, Nebraska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 13 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through January. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a wide-open paved trail with nice views of the creek for the entire journey. The terrain slopes gently toward the south and is sparsely populated. The adjacent properties are mostly undeveloped agricultural parcels and the scenery is rural in nature. 

Haworth Park has a wide range of activities including camping, playground, softball, and a marina.

Accessibility: There are 7 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Payne Drive at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

The West Loop in Platte River State Park offers a mix of everything. There are sections that are tucked in the trees, open views of the Platte River and Jenny Newman Lake, sections through meadows, rocky and rooty pieces of single-track trail, and smooth sections of double-track. There are lots of trail intersections where you can turn to lengthen or shorten this loop, too.

The Prairie View Trail runs from the Visitor Center to the eastern boundary of Scotts Bluff National Monument. At the boundary, the Prairie View Trail connects to the City of Gering's Monument Valley Pathway. 

There are two trailheads. One trailhead is located in the southeastern corner of the Visitor Center parking lot. The other trailhead is located at the western end of U Street in Gering.  

The Prairie View Trail is the only trail in Scotts Bluff National Monument that allows for bicycling. As you travel east, this trail offers some of the best views of Saddle Rock. For traveling west, look for Mitchell Pass, Eagle Rock, and Sentinel Rock.   

About 1/2 mile from the visitor center, the trail crosses a large ravine. Notice how juniper and other shrubs are found only within the ravine in this area. The ravine offers shelter from the wind and sun and has more abundant moisture than the surrounding windswept prairie.   

Some of the more common plants you are likely to see along this trail include Rocky Mountain juniper, soapweed yucca, little bluestem grass, buffalo grass, and side-oats gramma grass. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Old Highway 92 at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.5 and 0.8 when going east. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. According to the park website, the visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

This nature trail meanders into serene woodlands, following the gentle flow of a creek. The shaded path offers a peaceful escape, surrounded by tall trees, lush greenery, and the soothing sounds of nature. Ideal for walking or birdwatching, the trail provides a quiet, scenic retreat perfect for enjoying the beauty of the creekside forest.

Primarily used as mountain biking trails, this loop is considered difficult and combines River Run, Otoe Coaster, Tomahawk, and East Bound and Down. River Run is a downhill only double-black diamond trail that is very technically demanding. Tomahawk is also downhill only and is rated as black in difficulty. For hikers, this terrain is considered moderate. The trail system at Platte River State Park offers a variety of terrain, from forested bluffs and open fields to gullies. The trails are fast flowing singletrack and some sections include features such as jumps, a large step-up, and high speeds.

Try this 1.4-mile loop trail near Republican City, Nebraska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 25 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This trail can connect to the Jamaica North Trail. It can icy in the winter and features a bridge which goes over a train line. 

Accessibility: There are at least 16 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of South 13th Street at the southeast end of the trail. 4 of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. Please avoid parking here during school hours. 

The trail surface is paved concrete with some wooden bridges with railings and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

Check out this 1.6-mile loop trail near Lincoln, Nebraska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 29 min to complete. This is a popular trail for running and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October.

You got it. Here are a few descriptions for the Schwer Park trail, 300 characters or more, focusing on the park experience and access:

Explore the walking trail at Schwer Park in Papillion, located at 702 West Centennial Road. This park is home to a 7-acre fishing lake with a trail going around it, perfect for a walk or enjoying the outdoors. Kids love the popular Splash Pad and playground area. The park also offers convenient full-service restrooms and a large pavilion, making it a great community green space for everyone to enjoy the lake and park amenities.

This trail runs along Fremont Street through a residential area before encircling Mahoney Park. The park offers athletic facilities, restrooms, and water, creating a convenient hub for outdoor activities. Nearby connections to the Murdock Trail and 84th Street Trail expand options for exploring Lincoln's scenic pathways and parks.

The City of Lincoln maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 3 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Public restrooms are available near the trailhead. Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting. 

Take caution when crossing roadways; designated crosswalks are present. This trail has little shade, so wearing appropriate sun protection is recommended.

Enjoy this 2.0-mile loop trail near Bennington, Nebraska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 41 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through October.

This is a fantastic short hike along loose dirt trails with some tricky slopes. The route is clearly marked, and you can expect great views and interesting formations. It's best to go earlier in the day to avoid the heat. Some sections of the trail tend to get quite muddy after rain. There are toilets, camping, and parking available at the trailhead.

This Trail is Omaha's first approved off-road trail system in the city limits. These trails are primarily single-track though there are also some short sections of double-track connectors. A good mix of terrain can be found here -- everything from tight switchbacks through pine trees, to wide open grassland climbs, followed by speed-building swooping descents.

Discover this 1.8-mile out-and-back trail near Gering, Nebraska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 44 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through January. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Discover this 3.2-mile out-and-back trail near Pleasant Dale, Nebraska. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 2 min to complete. This trail is great for fishing, hiking, and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Walnut Creek Lake is part of the Papio Missouri River Natural Resources District and is a worthwhile location for a walk, a bike ride, fishing, RV camping, or a picnic.

The Walnut Creek Lake Trail is three miles long, wide, has a concrete surface, and is nice and smooth! Signs advise hikers that it is about a one-hour walk. The trail has a few moderately steep hills in some areas.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Gold Coast Road at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete or wooden bridge (with railings) and smooth. It is typically 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) and the steepest sections are at about 0.2 and 1.3 through 1.7 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There is a wheelchair-accessible fishing pier with level access.

Explore this 0.6-mile out-and-back trail near Lewellen, Nebraska. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 19 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 2.8-mile loop trail near North Las Vegas, Nevada. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 50 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This route starts at the Hidden Falls Park South parking area and takes you along Amargosa Trail, a well-maintained trail through the Sloan Canyon National Conservation Area. The trail is challenging and steep, with beautiful scenery along the way. The effort is worth it when you admire the sweeping views.

Right outside the visitor center is another one of the famous Valley of Fire formations.  From the Visitor’s Center, take a very short hike to a viewpoint of Balanced Rock.
You will often see big-horned sheep in this area! This trail is popular among families, and the unique rock formations provide great picture opportunities whilst on route.

Discover this 5.8-mile out-and-back trail near Boulder City, Nevada. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 57 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Hikers can enjoy expansive vistas of Lake Tahoe by trekking the Castle Rock Trail. You can witness vistas of the Carson Valley and the vast Desolation Wilderness along the way.

There is an incline on the trail up to the summit. You'll need to do some rock climbing to get to Castle Rock's bottom ledge. There is also some climbing involved to reach the summit.

From the trailhead, follow the trail westward, which leads gradually uphill. The path winds through thick patches of aspens and evergreens before passing by the alternative trail. The trail turns south and heads toward the magnificent Echo Cliffs. The Cliffs have a sheer drop of almost 1,000 feet. As the trail snakes to the west of Echo Cliffs, a side trail leads to a small seep. Water flows from the seep in the spring.

Once past Echo Cliffs, the trail heads west, and the grade becomes steeper as it travels across a slope. The trail flattens out as it heads toward the backside of Cathedral Rock. This is the easiest and most enjoyable part of the trail and you forget that you're 8,000 feet above sea level.  

Save your energy for the last quarter mile of the trail, as it's steep. When the trail divides, go right on the unmarked footpath.   About a half-dozen switchbacks leads to the top of Cathedral Rock. The view becomes more spectacular with every step. On the far northeast side, there's a place to sit and admire the view. Mt. Charleston Lodge lies 1,000 feet below, and farther to the east, you can see the desert floor. To the north is Mummy Mountain; to the NW is Mary Jane Falls, and to the west is Charleston Peak.

If you eat lunch, you may have a visitor or two. This is the only place in the world you'll have the opportunity to see the Palmer Chipmunk. As hard as it is, resist feeding them. By providing food to them, they become dependent on humans for their food. In the winter, the chipmunks must rely on their food-gathering skills or perish. Watch children closely at the top; the drop-offs are more than 500 feet at the edges.

This is the upper and middle section of the Clear Creek Trail between Spooner Summit Trailhead and Jacks Valley Road Trailhead. A section of this route crosses through private land so please be respectful and stay on the trail.
This trail is shared with Mountain Bikers and horseriders, so keep an eye out for each other.

This is a fun route-finding adventure around a former Pauite winter camp, featuring rock shelters and rock art. The BLM has posted signs in front of significant sites. A brochure may be available at the trail register and may also be found online. For more information on Crystal Wash: https://lincolncountynevada.com/exploring/rocking/rock-art/crystal-wash-rock-art-site/

Damonte Ranch Park is right next to the Damonte Wetlands. It is a short short walk around the park which offers basketball, a playground, lots of green area and a covered BBQ area. Recommended for all ages and connects right to the big loop around the wetlands. Some trees and little shade other than the covered seating area. Dogs are allowed on leash.

Park Hours:
5:00 a.m. - 10:00 p.m., April 1 - September 30
6:00 a.m. - 7:00 p.m., October 1 - March 31

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Steamboat Parkway at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There is a wheelchair-accessible bathroom at the west end of the trail. There is a playground with some wheelchair-accessible features such as a firm and stable surface.

Explore this 8.4-mile point-to-point trail near Coyote Springs, Nevada. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This trail is great for off-road driving, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.
This trail is closed. We'll update this page if and when it reopens.

This one-of-a-kind route features a strenuous hike through a beautiful canyon to hot springs pools. There are eight fixed ropes if you go to the river; some are challenging, especially when coming back up. While dogs are allowed in this area, bringing them on this trail is not advisable due to the amount of scrambling required, which could be difficult for most dogs.

Your first obstacle is navigating a large boulder with what looks like a significant drop-off.  You'll see some steps in the rock wall to your right. There is a strap here to help you down the steps.

A short distance after this, the wash opens up as several washes come together. Keep walking down, and you'll come to the next rope. This goes down the left side of the rock wall, and you'll need to use the rope as intended and walk down backward while moving down the rope. There's a dry fall that some slide down. A blue arrow painted on the rocks to the left of the chute shows you how to walk around and down this dry fall.

After you have cleared these obstacles, you arrive at what once was the Upper Goldstrike Hot Springs pools, which have since dried up. A few pools farther down still have water, but you'll see the remnants of the pools that no longer have any source for filling.

This is an adventurous scramble in Hidden Canyon, with a section of class 3 hiking over boulder fields. The beginning section follows a gravel wash that eventually ascends until reaching the peak. There are beautiful views of the desert landscape once you reach the summit. There is no shade, and it is suggested to bring plenty of water and sun protection.

This short hike ascends the hill via an easy trail leading to a saddle between two high points with a stunning overlook of Lake Mead and the Hoover Dam in the other direction. The trail is dirt and lacks any significant features other than the overlook and is surrounded by a multitude of power lines and towers.

This trail is only accessible in winter. No trail exists in summer as it requires traversing a pond, navigating over boulders, and pushing through thick brush.

Winter ascents of Incline Peak follow a snow-covered trail that climbs gradually through forested slopes with intermittent meadow openings. Expect steady elevation gain. The route may be well-packed early in the season, but deeper snow later often requires snowshoes or microspikes. As you climb above treeline, the terrain opens, revealing sweeping views of Lake Tahoe and surrounding peaks. It is important to know that the trail enters avalanche terrain. A winter ascent takes about 4–6 hours depending on snow travel and breaks, and successful hikers commonly bring layers, proper winter gear (insulated boots, gaiters, poles), and navigation aids. The payoff: sweeping Tahoe panoramas framed by snow-blanketed ridgelines and quiet, remote wilderness.

Head out on this 9.1-mile loop trail near Reno, Nevada. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 5 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through May.

This trail starts at the parking lot off Kingsbury Grade and winds through forests, meadows, and alongside a stream. A highlight of the hike is Nevada Beach, offering stunning views of Lake Tahoe and the surrounding mountains. Some sections near the marsh can be wet, so avoiding them after heavy rainfall is best.

Travel north/south along the irrigation channel.

Clark County Parks and Recreation Department maintains this trail. 

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces near the trailhead, but some may be available in commercial lots nearby.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 7 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Take caution when crossing roadways; designated crosswalks are present. Expect traffic noise on this route. When sharing the roadway with motor vehicles, the use of reflective materials, flagging, or lights is recommended. 

This trail has little shade, so it is recommended that you wear appropriate sun protection. Benches are available along the route for resting.

This popular equestrian trail begins at the Horseshoe Equestrian Trailhead on Old State Route 163 and travels counterclockwise around the high point. A spur trail at 0.2 miles from the trailhead leads to the Dam Overlook. The trail continues southeast and descends to the river's edge, parallel to the paved Riverwalk Trail. This route has great views of the Colorado River, Davis Dam, and Laughlin.

Try this 3.3-mile loop trail near Overton, Nevada. Generally considered an easy route. This trail is great for birding, camping, and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This loop combines Molly’s Trail and Landmine Trail, offering a fun ride or hike through Nevada’s desert landscape. The trail features a mix of singletrack, rocky sections, and open stretches, with some quick climbs and technical spots. It’s a great route for mountain bikers and hikers looking for a relaxing outing, while enjoying the desert views along the way.

One of the highlights of the trail is the viewpoint near the end of the hike, where visitors can take in a panoramic view of the Cathedral Gorge area, including the rugged cliffs, winding ravines, and distant mountains. The landscape is especially stunning during sunset, when the rocks glow with warm colors and the shadows of the formations stretch across the desert floor.

The Ophir Creek Trail Short Option features a creek crossing filled with large boulders from a 1983 rockslide. A trail has been carved through these rocks, and makeshift bridges help hikers cross when the water is rushing. Along the way, you'll find spots to rest with views of Slide Mountain. The trail is surrounded by diverse flora and fauna.

Experience this 10.6-mile point-to-point trail near Overton, Nevada. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 3 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Rancho San Rafael’s trails wind through the parks meadows and wetlands, whilst offering views of Reno’s skyline and surrounding hills. Watch for cottontails darting through brush or raptors soaring above dry washes. This pathways are well maintained and well marked and make for a great convenient walk, popular with dog walkers, hikers and joggers, with close proximity to the cities amenities.

Check out this 11.5-mile out-and-back trail near Orovada, Nevada. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 17 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, birding, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through November. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Experience this 6.5-mile loop trail near Blue Diamond, Nevada. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 33 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, mountain biking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are September through June. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 1.4-mile out-and-back trail near Baker, Nevada. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 45 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

The South Fork Overlook is located at the California Trail Interpretive Center.  This is a short trail that travels through an exposed desert area to a littler viewpoint of the South Fork. This trail can be extended by adding on the California Trail Overlook. The California Trail Center is open Wednesday-Sunday from 9am-4:30pm.

This route starts at Thomas Canyon Campground and heads south, winding along Thomas Creek on a steady and challenging incline. It takes you along the Ruby Mountain Wilderness, where you'll see stunning waterfalls, creeks, scenic surroundings, and beautiful wildflowers. The area can get muddy and has steep sections, so sturdy, waterproof shoes are recommended.

This route features canyon views, wooded climbs, and a well-marked trail.

With the White Rock Mountain Loop, you will see typical desert plants like the cholla cactus lining the trail.  On the mountain's west side, hidden from the Scenic Drive, is a hidden forest of juniper and pinyon pine.  It's a great contrast to the barren east side.

High clearance is not necessary to reach this trailhead, although it is recommended as it travels a dirt road to access the trailhead.

This is a fun trail with optional scrambling opportunities to several gorgeous viewpoints of the colorful Whitney Pocket formations. Part of the trail follows old roads and use paths; other parts are off-trail or cross country.

Explore the woodlands, wetlands, and history of this conservation area. Notably, the trail that bisects the area is built atop the old bed of the Chester and Derry Electric Railroad that operated from 1891 to 1928.

There is limited parking along the side of Faith Drive near the start of the trail.

The Derry Conservation Commission manages this trail.

The Beaman Hill trail is a good trail to explore the landscapes of the region. Passing by the Second Connecticut Lake and Connecticut River, as well as the East Inlet Flowage, the scenery of this path is quite interesting. It is a multi-usage pathway, so be aware that bikes or car may share the way as well.

Beede Falls is well-known for its sizable, sandy pool, ideal for a dip on a hot day. The trail leading to the falls has graded gravel steps and wooden railings. The lower falls descend broad, sunlit ledges for twenty feet with ease. 

The main falls, which have a width of roughly 35 feet, descend a smooth granite face in a breathtaking horsetail pattern and empty into a pool that is 50 feet wide. The pool is knee- to calf-deep.

The trail is not well marked in some areas, downloading the map ahead of time is helpful for navigating.

Explore the Boisvert and Normand Nature Preserve via a network of loops and out-and-back trails. Begin from the parking area on Currier Road, where there is an informational kiosk. Weave through the forest and enjoy the pollinator garden, forest, and views of the Soucook River.

The property has a conservation easement with Five Rivers Conservation Trust and is a certified tree farm.

The Clark Pond Loop Trail begins at a gate on Bog Road. Enter the forest and take a left onto the Dancy Trail. During winter months, the Dancy Trail is reserved for snowshoeing. Passing two benches along the way, you'll soon find yourself along the western shore of Clark Pond. Head back via the Norman Trail, which during the winter months is ski-only.

Experience this 4.6-mile out-and-back trail near Peterborough, New Hampshire. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 2 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 2.7-mile out-and-back trail near Hooksett, New Hampshire. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 50 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 1.9-mile loop trail near Weare, New Hampshire. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 49 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through April.

Try this 1.4-mile out-and-back trail near Portsmouth, New Hampshire. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 26 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Head out on this 3.9-mile out-and-back trail near Charlestown, New Hampshire. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 43 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

The out-and-back trail is fairly level with a few moderate inclines.  Much of the trail winds through hemlock and pine forest along the river with a view of the river. Follow the yellow blazes to the End of Trail sign and return to make a loop with white blazes back to the yellow-blazed trail and then to the parking area. A small parking area is available on the south side of Olde Bridge Lane in Epping. In Google maps, the location is 62 Old Bridge Lane, Epping, NH

This loop summits five peaks on either side of Franconia Notch:
1) North Kinsman
2) Mount Lafayette
3) Mount Lincoln
4) Little Haystack
5) Mount Liberty

Expect incredible views along the way on a clear day. You will pass the AMC Lonesome Lake Hut which is open during the summer months. Anyone wishing to stay there needs to make reservations through the AMC ahead of time, but hikers are welcome to stop in.

The hike to Little Sugarloaf begins with a gradual ascent through the woods, winding past several boulders. As you approach the top, the trail becomes steeper, leading you to the wooded summit of Little Sugarloaf. From here, you're treated to a breathtaking bird's-eye view of Newfound Lake, with Plymouth Mountain and Peaked Hill visible.

The ravine’s floor is strewn with enormous granite boulders and deep crevices forming the famous “Subway” route—an adventurous passage beneath house-sized rocks. From the base, the walls of the ravine rise sharply toward the crest of Mount Adams, culminating in the steep headwall climb that demands careful footing and sure hands as hikers scramble over talus and ledges.

The summit of Mount Adams provides spectacular views of the Presidential Range and the surrounding wilderness area, with wide open vistas, unlike some of the other summits in the White Mountains. Lower sections of the trail can be muddy seasonally.

The trail is not well marked or maintained in some areas.

When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.

This hike offers wonderful views while crossing over the Carters.

The trail can become very muddy and slippery after rainfall, with some sections turning boggy and taking weeks to dry out.

The loop is also suitable for shoulder seasons and winter use, but snowshoes or traction devices are recommended. There is approximately a one-mile road walk along this route.
