This is a loop trail with good views towards the southern Presidentials. You get multiple summits with Avalon offering the best views. Mt. Tom and Mt. Field are wooded, and offers more obstructed views through the trees. 

Keep your eyes peeled for a good chance to spot wildlife. 

Plan for extra time is trail is wet as it can slippery and slow to navigate. Microspikes are really a must during the wintertime.

This loop highlights the diversity found in Pawtuckaway State Park. Start by hiking past Mountain Brook Pond. The trail is mostly wooded but has a few awesome viewpoints and overlooks along the way. The forest is also dotted with small cliffs and large boulders that are popular with rock climbers. The summit of South Mountain has a fire tower you can climb up for a rewarding view.

The Wapack and Cliff Trail leads to the North Pack Monadnock via a mountain laurel grove and a brook crossing. The trail begins with a steep climb as you go through a field of boulders, then opens onto broad, level ledges. There are a few additional rocky spots on the trail.

The trail stays in the forest until it reaches North Pack Monadnock's peak. At the summit, you can see vistas through the woods. Two viewpoints on the Cliff Trail offer expansive views towards the south.

Explore this 13.7-mile out-and-back trail near Enfield, New Hampshire. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 4 h 15 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 1.0-mile out-and-back trail near Center Sandwich, New Hampshire. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 54 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this ridgeline trail in Milton, which meanders through dense forest and offers awesome views of the Branch River. 
This and many nearby trails are great for dog walkers, trail runners and hikers. 

If you enjoyed this trail, there are around seven miles of other trails that meander through 400 managed acres of forests and fields and along the Branch River, connecting the adjacent Plummers Ridge lands of Branch Hill Farm, McKenzie’s Farm, and the New Hampshire Farm Museum.

Check out this 0.8-mile loop trail near Milford, New Hampshire. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 15 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through August. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Begin from the Lyndeborough Parking Area on Purgatory Falls Road. Parking is limited at this starting point. Head south into the forest to eventually reach the viewpoints of Purgatory Falls. You will have the opportunity to observe  waterfalls before retracing your steps to the parking area. The trail is marked by yellow rectangular blazes (some older white blazes may still be visible). 

The trail is not well marked in some areas, downloading the map ahead of time is helpful for navigating.

Begin from the parking area on the west side of Calef Highway (Route 125). Follow Rabbitat Road west. Turn right to head north on Cottontail Trail. Continue counterclockwise on Cedar Swamp Trail and Tibbetts Road to rejoin Rabbitat Road. Enjoy the wooded setting.

The Barrington Conservation Commission and Trails Committee maintain this trail.

Begin on an old railroad grade before entering onto wooded trails.

After departing from the railroad grade it's a combination of single track and forest service roads closed to vehicle traffic.

This is a peaceful setting that is a good place to walk the dog. The trails are very popular with mountain bikers.

This trail follows former Boston and Maine Railroad lines. The trail is mostly flat and features a surface of stone dust or packed earth, perfect for an easy outing. You will journey alongside the beautiful Contoocook River and pass through forests of pines and hardwoods. Parking is limited, so an early start is recommended.

This trail can be accessed from Squam Lake Road, where roadside parking is available. The parking area is very small, so arriving early is recommended. The trail leads to the summit of Red Hill, with a fire tower, via the Eagle Cliff Trail in the Squam Lakes Association Trail System. Be prepared for steep, rocky sections with ledge climbing. Your effort will be rewarded with stunning views of the lake and the Squam Mountain Range.

This trail branches off the Woodland Loop, passing through a damp hemlock forest with mossy rocks and thickets of giant rhododendron, a plant with large clusters of pale flowers and evergreen leaves. 

This Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy in New Hampshire, and is an excellent place for walking, hunting, observing wildlife, and cross country skiing. Camping, fires, pets, or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve.

Rump Mountain, is one of the Maine 3500 footers Mountains. 
No cell service, so it is recommended to download the card from the app. Nice bushwack up to Rump with nice views looking south. Some herd paths but plenty of scrambling and cutting through alders & going through bogs. So roads to get there might be gated, make sure not to trespass.

Skookumchuck Trail is a scenic and less crowded route to the summit of Mt. Lafayette. The trail starts from the parking lot that serves the north end of the Franconia Notch bike path. After following a brook, it climbs steeply on stone steps, then eases as the trail climbs to meet the Garfield Ridge Trail.

This trail starts at the Tucker and French Parking lot off Marshall Road and takes you to Tucker and French Family Forest. The parking area is small and only fits around five cars, so an early start is recommended.
The trail follows the French South Trail through the forest and loops around Mill Pond. Along the way, you will pass the mill ruins by the creek. Don’t forget to bring bug spray to protect against mosquitoes.

Check out this 20.8-mile point-to-point trail near New Ipswich, New Hampshire. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 10 h 41 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Andover Loop trail is a combination of  sections from the Sussex Branch Trail, the Hillside Park/Goodale Trail, and trails in the Kittatinny Valley State park.  There are several other alternative parking spots around the loop that can be used to start the loop

The trail is well blazed, and it really good shape and pretty frequently used.  There is one small section along Limecrest Road that you have to leave the former rail trail to walk along the road for a stretch to avoid private property.

Enjoy an easy, paved walk with amazing views at Bayshore Waterfront Park. This flat trail runs right along the beach, looking out over the beautiful Sandy Hook Bay. On a clear day, you can see the New York City skyline in the distance! It's a fantastic place to watch for shorebirds like ospreys and gulls. A breeze often comes off the water, and bringing bug spray is a good idea in warmer months.

Explore this 0.9-mile out-and-back trail near West Windsor Township, New Jersey. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 16 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This trail travels a short loop through the forest and provides a quick, easy hike. Along the way, there are different tree and plant species to observe. It passes by a pond, where there is an opportunity to see different bird species. There is an informational kiosk at the trailhead with a park map.

Enjoy sweeping views of Barnegat Bay from this paved route that encircles the peninsula's tip. Playgrounds, picnic areas, a spray park, bocce courts, horseshoe pits, a bait station, and a covered pavilion are available for public use. The 100-foot pier is a popular location for fishing and crabbing.

Accessibility: This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers. There are at least 6 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot. The trail surface is paved asphalt, concrete, or wooden boardwalk with edge railings, typically at least 5 feet wide. This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

Begin from the parking area on the west side of Old Turnpike Road. Proceed northwest through the open fields via unmarked trails. You will pass through farmland and habitat for various wildlife, including raptors, coyotes, and foxes. 

This trail is maintained by the Hunterdon County Division of Parks and Recreation.

This is a peaceful woodland trail, running alongside streams. It is easy to connect to the short and easy Holly Grove Trail, or can be made into a much longer and more challenging hike by continuing on onto other neighboring trails.
This trail is great for a family outing or a good escape into nature. 
Its worth downloading the trail map, as navigation can be tricky at certain times of the year.

Travel around Elmwood Park on a paved pathway. Parking is available off Elmwood Avenue. 

This trail is maintained by the Town of East Orange.

Accessibility:  

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.  

Parking  
There are 2 designated accessible parking spaces on the street near the trailhead.

Surface  
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically 12 to 14 feet wide. 

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).  

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Begin from the parking area at the Swarswood State Park day-use area. From the canoe launch, travel northeast along Swartwood Lake through the hemlock trees and weave around the picnic areas and campground. Turn back and retrace your path once you reach Route 622.

The New Jersey Division of Parks and Forestry maintains this trail.

The Grand Loop passes by the notable encampments in the Jockey Hollow area. The loop is mostly wooded and crosses some small creeks. Interpretive signs are in place along the way highlighting the historical significance of points of interest. Near the Stark Brigade Monument, there is a large open field with a good view.

The worst winter in a century ravaged the Continental Army during its 1779 encampment at Morristown. One soldier reported that those who had experienced Valley Forge but not Morristown, “know not what it is to suffer.” Learn more about Morristown NHP and America's 250th Celebrations at America's National Parks™: americasnationalparks.org/americas-250th

The worst winter in a century ravaged the Continental Army during its 1779 encampment at Morristown. One soldier reported that those who had experienced Valley Forge but not Morristown, “know not what it is to suffer.” Learn more about Morristown NHP and America's 250th Celebrations at America's National Parks™: americasnationalparks.org/americas-250th

Begin from the trail entrance at the end of Woodland Road. Travel south into the woodlands on the Blue Trail. Cross Great Brook. Continue west on the Blue Trail and then turn right to create a counterclockwise, lollipop-style loop with the Red Trail. 

The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service maintains this trail network.

Begin from the parking area at 247 Southern Boulevard. Travel south past the Visitors Center and then west to loop through the woodlands on the Orange Trail. This trail is a mix of standard terrain and boardwalks. Trails are open from sunrise to sunset year-round.

The Morris County Park Commission maintains this trail network.

Begin from the parking area on the north side of West Park Avenue (Route 14). Near the trailhead, there is an informational kiosk and picnic area. Loop clockwise through the fields on either side of the access road. This sandy trail highlights yellow beach heather, prickly pair cactus, and cedar trees.

Monmouth County Parks maintains this trail.

Begin from the trailhead on Andersen Road. Follow the Green Trail, Blue Trail, and Orange Trail through the heart of the forest.

The Hunterdon Land Trust manages the preserve through a partnership with Holland Township, Hunterdon County Open Space Trust Fund, State of New Jersey Green Acres, Phillipsburg Riverview Organization, and Victoria Foundation.

Try this 8.1-mile loop trail near Elwood, New Jersey. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 30 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Check out this 1.5-mile loop trail near East Brunswick, New Jersey. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 29 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are August through December.

Head out on this 3.0-mile out-and-back trail near Seaside Park, New Jersey. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 53 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Try this 1.5-mile loop trail near Blairstown, New Jersey. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 34 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Summer Hours (July through August):
Wednesday – Friday, 10am – 4pm

This NJ Audubon Society Property is a fully staffed nature center and education center on 13 acres in Franklin Lakes. It has a historic home, many beautiful wildlife enhancements and native plants, and nature trails. They are not miles-long hiking trails, but are wonderful nature trails that you can go through slowly.  A large deer-enclosure fence has been installed, so you can see the seldom-seen native plants coming back to life, without excessive deer browsing.

Nice paved loop through the Overpeck Park along the riverfront. Nice playgrounds, tennis courts, baseball courts, and soccer courts dot the park as you walk along.

Accessibility: There are 12 designated accessible spaces in the large parking lot off of Challenger Rd. at the start of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is asphalt, brick, or cement, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.3 and 1.7 miles when going counterclockwise. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the moderately steep sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

The Patriots' Path from Speedwell Lake provides a hiking experience on various surfaces. There is a little paved stretch near Speedwell Lake, but the majority of the trail is made of crushed stone, gravel, or dirt. 

The trail meanders alongside the South Branch of the Raritan River and the corridors of the Black and Whippany Rivers. The trail is exceptionally breathtaking in the summer when fireflies are present. The trail's diverse wildlife, such as foxes, snakes, and birds, contributes to the overall natural atmosphere.

Check out this 1.1-mile loop trail near Lakewood Township, New Jersey. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 21 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, road biking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Explore the meadows and forests of the east parcel of Prostak Farms. Begin from the parking area off Stanton Mountain Road. Proceed clockwise as denoted on the map if you'd like to tackle the steeper section of the trail first. Follow the path and take in open views from the open hilltop. 

This trail is maintained by the Township of Clinton.

Experience this 0.5-mile loop trail near Southampton, New Jersey. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 9 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This park has basketball courts and a great place for kids to play.

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Hunter Street at the start of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is asphalt or cement, and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the route for resting.

Check out this 4.8-mile out-and-back trail near Shawnee on Delaware, Pennsylvania. Generally considered a challenging route. This trail is great for camping and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 4.8-mile out-and-back trail near Millville, New Jersey. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 30 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, fishing, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Travel around Elmwood Park on a paved pathway. Parking is available along the park's perimeter.

This trail is maintained by Essex County Department of Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Affairs.

Accessibility:  

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.  

Parking  
There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces near the trailhead.  

Surface  
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically at least 5 to 6 feet wide.  

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

A beautiful paved walk from Borgata to the Brigantine bridge. Great for a morning or afternoon adventure.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Borgata Way at the southwest end of the trail. They are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is a boardwalk (with edge barriers and railings) or paved asphalt. It is typically at least 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

Get to know this 6.2-mile out-and-back trail near Byram Township, New Jersey. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a popular trail for camping and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October.

Loop around Wild Duck Pond on the pathway that hugs its shores. Begin from the parking area on the northern side of the pond, accessed via East Ridgewood Avenue. Circumnavigate the pond, passing pavilions, playgrounds, and public amenities like bathrooms.

Accessibility:

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking  
There are 2 designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface  
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically at least 10 feet wide.

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

More Info  
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Head out on this 2.9-mile loop trail near Farmington, New Mexico. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 0 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, mountain biking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through December. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

There is gentle terrain to begin the hike. The trail climbs to a ridgeline via a steeper section as you continue. Additionally, the trail is rough and covered in pebbles with sharp edges, making footing a little tricky and slick in certain areas. You may see the waterfall tumbling down in a brief slot canyon portion where the trail leads. Along the trail, there are areas with shade. There is a chance that hikers will see animals, including mountain lions, bobcats, and snakes.

The Bisti Badlands Trail is an amazing area to explore the unique landscapes and formations of New Mexico. There are no trail markers and the path is unclear, so make sure to download the offline map beforehand. This hike is recommended for adventurers with great navigational skills as there are several areas with no trail. The rock formations are breathtaking, and there are plenty of opportunities to take stunning photographs. Be sure to bring plenty of water and sunscreen, as the desert sun can be intense.

Head out on this 13.3-mile point-to-point trail near Questa, New Mexico. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a popular trail for camping and off-road driving, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are June through September.

Visitors have reported that the directions can be hard to follow and do not go all the way to the start of the trail. You will need to continue going west on Loop Road until the turnoff on the right (north) to Picacho Peak Rec Area. The parking lot is on Burke Ranch Road.

The Canyon Loop Trail is one of the trails at Picacho Peak inside of the Organ Mountains Desert Peaks National Monument. From the trailhead (32.32631, -106.89155) walk down 0.2 miles until you will reach the intersection with the trail that goes to the peak, but you do not go there, so here turn to your right and take the trail that goes near the arroyo. On the next mile, you can walk by the arroyo or on the trail, you will enjoy the sandy way and the beautiful rocks of the canyon. The trail is well marked and also has several post signs indicating the direction. 

At about a mile this trail turns to your left and continues by the side of the mountain for about another mile. In this section, you will enjoy a beautiful vista of Picacho Mountain to your left, Robledo Mountain in front of you, and the beautiful Organ Mountains to your right. At about mile 2, you will arrive to an intersection with another trail that goes to the peak, turn to your right and continue on the side of the mountain for about 0.2 of a mile, then turn to your left (you will see a post sign here) and walk down until you reach the Box Canyon, then turn to your left again. 

Box Canyon goes around the mountain, and most of the time you will walk by the sandy road, which is a very nice experience. Stop for a moment and enjoy this beautiful area, you will love it. At about mile 3 do not walk by the Box Canyon trail, continue walking to your left by the arroyo around the mountain, you will see a posted sign there. Then you will arrive at the same intersection you arrived at the beginning of the walk. 

Turn to your right and walk up until the point you started. Following the posted signs. This trail is near the 5 miles long, be prepared to enjoy a stunning landscape view with arroyos, rocks, beautiful flowers, and desert plants, and do not be afraid of the cows, they are very peaceful.

Head out on this 9.9-mile loop trail near Lamy, New Mexico. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 41 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, horseback riding, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

The Descansos Trail, located in the Box Recreation Area near Magdalena, NM, begins at the parking area off US-60 and leads to Gramont Peak. This challenging hike features rugged terrain and limited shade, so it's important to come prepared with plenty of water, sunscreen, and protective gear. The trail offers a rewarding experience for experienced hikers.

This short, paved loop trail is accessible to wheelchairs and strollers, offering an easy walk with plenty of informative signs and labeled plants. The trail is dog-friendly (with leashes and waste clean-up required) and features shaded areas near the parking lot. Restrooms are available when staff is present, making it a comfortable and informative option for visitors.

This hike is absolutely beautiful, but it can also be quite challenging. Fortunately, the trail is well-marked and maintained throughout the entirety of the hike. Caution is advised in sections of loose rock, and proper footwear is recommended. At the end of the trail, hikers will reach an intersection where they can turn around and return the way they came. It is important to bring plenty of water as the trail is exposed and it can get quite hot.

Head out on this 3.2-mile loop trail near Edgewood, New Mexico. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 6 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are August through September.

Check out this 33.4-mile point-to-point trail near Angel Fire, New Mexico. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This trail is great for camping and off-road driving, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through March. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

The trail begins at Juniper Campground and makes its way to the edge of the canyon where it switchbacks down to the canyon floor (>550' elevation change). The trail provides excellent bird's eye views of Tyuonyi as well as a foot route from the campground to the visitor center. A somewhat strenuous trail at any time, it can be exceedingly difficult in summer as there is little shelter from the sun along the trail. Be sure and always carry plenty of water.

***You can return the way you came, or, if the shuttle is running, you can ride the shuttle back to the campground.***

This route showcases beautiful scenery with varying terrain, ranging from areas with lots of rocks to flat land. While the trail is multi-use, it is especially popular among mountain bikers in the area. There are several windy sections on this somewhat exposed trail that meanders through the hills. The trail has a smooth flow and is perfect for running, offering great views.

This adventurous and challenging route makes for a great multi-day backpacking trip that travels through the heart of the Gila Wilderness. It is suggested to park at the TJ Corral lot to start. The river crossings are relatively easy and there are many camping spots along the river. The trail leads to Jordan hot springs and there is camping just beyond the final river crossing. The last section of the trail features a slot canyon that leads back to the beginning. 

Protect our hot springs! In order to conserve this delicate habitat for the creatures that call it home, and for the health and enjoyment of future visitors, please always camp AT LEAST 200 feet away from springs. Pack out all trash, use a wag bag or bury human waste at least 6 feet deep and 200+ feet away from water, know and follow current fire regulations, use established fire rings, stay on trail, avoid making loud noise, and leave the habitat (including animals, plants, rocks, etc.) untouched.

Experience this 9.4-mile out-and-back trail near Questa, New Mexico. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 5 h 12 min to complete. This trail is great for camping and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

To access the trailhead, you will need to drive into the main entrance of the Valles Caldera National Preserve. The first unmarked trail on your left after entering the park is where the start of this trail begins. This trail follows the Jemez River after passing the Missing Cabin and travels by interesting volcanic formations. Some parts of the trail may be marshy.

The Chili Line trail is an easy walk that follows the Rio Grande along the former railroad route through White Rock Canyon. The narrow gauge railway was part of the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad that connected the Santa Fe Railyard to Antonito, Colorado, in the 1880s.

The route is mostly level, with the first half wide and open. As the trail approaches Otowi Peak, it becomes narrower, and the trail meanders through basalt boulders. Buckman Mesa and Otowi Peak loom overhead to your right as you head north, and there are many magnificent views of the Rio Grande along the way. With so many cottonwoods lining the river, the scenery is spectacular in the fall.

The turnaround point is at the fence of the San Ildefonso Pueblo border.

Experience this 3.8-mile loop trail near Gallup, New Mexico. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 29 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 11.1-mile out-and-back trail near Carlsbad, New Mexico. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 5 h 19 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through October. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Try this 7.8-mile out-and-back trail near Gallina, New Mexico. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 37 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Explore this 2.4-mile out-and-back trail near Las Cruces, New Mexico. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 58 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are August through May.

The path to Petaca Point is a peaceful walk that follows the west rim of a dramatic gorge. This trail offers incredible, sweeping views down to the Rio Grande and up to the surrounding snow-covered mountains. It's a mix of singletrack and remnants of an old road, passing through an expansive meadow and sagebrush landscape. Since the trail has very little shade, it is important to bring sun protection. The trail is generally easy to follow, and people enjoy the solitude it provides. This trail is an extension of the popular West Rim Trail and is not often used, making it a good choice for a quiet day outdoors.

Discover this 6.4-mile out-and-back trail near Red River, New Mexico. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a popular trail for off-road driving, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are July through September. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Check out this 6.7-mile out-and-back trail near Jamestown, New Mexico. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 31 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through November.

This is a nice, short paved trail to impressive mission ruins. If you want to explore the ruins, those trails are gravel. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of County Road B076 at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. According to the park website, this trail is wheelchair-accessible. There are wheelchair-accessible restrooms. There is a wheelchair available for loan at the visitors center.

Enjoy this 11.6-mile out-and-back trail near Glenwood, New Mexico. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 11 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Explore this 3.7-mile loop trail near Alto, New Mexico. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This trail is great for hiking and off-road driving, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through January.

This trail is relatively close to Albuquerque (1hr 15min to trailhead). San Pedro Parks is a small wilderness area located in the Santa Fe National Forest. It's unique in that there are no major peaks or cliffs or steep parts. When you arrive at the center of the park it is beautiful mixtures of open meadows and thick woods.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot on Singing Arrow Avenue Southeast at the start of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is asphalt, cement, or packed dirt, and typically at least 3 feet wide. The most accessible portions of the trail are the paved section from 0.0 through 0.1 and 0.4 through 0.6 miles. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved section. There are benches along the route for resting.

The Tramway Trail provides stunning views of the lower Sandia Mountains on the eastern slope. It also connects with the La Luz trail, which you can take to reach the mountain top. The trail is well-marked, but be aware that there is little shade at the start, so it's best to go during cooler months. Additionally, the trail can get steep in certain places and there are many rocks, so be careful with your footing.

Get to know this 0.5-mile out-and-back trail near Nageezi, New Mexico. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 10 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Starting from Overlook Park, this trail takes you along White Rock Canyon Rim Trail, an enjoyable trail with great views of the valley. The trail is somewhat rocky, so sturdy shoes are a must as you hike this trail. The route ends at White Rock Canyon Viewpoint, rewarding you with stunning panoramic White Rock Cayon area views.

Rensselaer Plateau Alliance's second community forest has recently been opened just outside the village of East Nassau at the end of gravel Hayes Road. The 353 acre property was acquired from Mary and Kevin Albert and funded by the US Forest Service and by a donation from the Albert family. There are all sorts of things to see on this trail: rivers, cascades, old homesteads, rock walls, foundations, wells, all different tree types.

There are many many places for additional trails as well.  Currently there are three trails exist: the Cascades Trail (ORANGE), the Orchard Trail (YELLOW), and the Homestead Trail (BLUE).

The falls can be viewed from the parking area or you can cross the road to get a closer look. Please use caution when crossing the road. You can also connect to other trails close by for a longer trip.

Accessibility: There is parking in a partially paved parking lot on the east side of the trail, but it is unclear if there are any designated accessible spaces. The trail crosses a paved two-lane road from the parking area to a packed gravel viewing area. There does not appear to be a marked road crossing, so please use caution. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (6% or less).

Enjoy this lovely trail past stunning waterfalls and creeks. 

Look out for other trail options in the area, which have tons of beautiful trails to explore. 

• Purchase of a daily vehicle use fee required. Empire Pass card also accepted. Machine takes both cash and credit cards.
• This route crosses over into the neighboring Mohonk Preserve. Access to their property requires the purchase of a day pass or season pass.

The Ridge Trail leaves from the main parking area. The trail is generally well defined and marked with orange diamonds or orange ribbon in a few spots. The trail starts out rocky as it winds its way around a flattened stone fence but quickly joins up with what was probably an old cart path used by the neighboring farm.

Right before that intersection there is a junction for the loop the trail makes but it is not well marked from this side. At approximately 0.75 of a mile the trail makes a sharp left onto a less wide but still well defined path through the woods. 

One does have to cross four tributaries to the Poestenkill but they are narrow and stepping stones can be found to cross over dryly. The trail comes to the Poestenkill opposite the southern terminus of the Creek Trail and then climbs a ridge alongside of the stream. While glimpses of the falls can be seen from the trail, hemlocks block a clear view.

For more information, please visit https://www.rensselaerplateau.org/barbervillefalls.

Explore this 5.9-mile out-and-back trail near Westbrookville, New York. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 45 min to complete. This is a popular trail for cross-country skiing, hiking, and horseback riding, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Begin by heading up County Road 3 before arriving at an intersection with an old building. Follow the wide path heading uphill to the summit of Bearpen. The summit is an open meadow with good views of the surrounding area.

There is private property near this trail so please stay along the marked path.

This loop covers two peaks over 3,500 feet starting from the Biscuit Brook Parking Area. 

Begin up the Pine Hill-West Branch Trail then detour onto the herd path leading to the summit of Fir Mountain and over to Big Indian. This is not an official DEC trail and is not marked so downloading the map ahead of time is recommended to help navigate.

After reaching the top of Big Indian, head back down the Pine Hill-West Branch Trail. Both summits are wooded and have canisters marking the top.

Leave No Trace: The guidance found in the seven Leave No Trace principles aides in understanding how to minimize your physical imprint upon sensitive ecosystems or cultural resources. Learn more at https://lnt.org/

Protect vulnerable ground-nesting birds. PLEASE: Stay on marked trails and leash dogs to protect wildlife.

This trail has great scenery and has easy to follow the trail markers. The park offers a free map at the entrance to carry along. 

Along the way you will cross over the top of Black Rock, cross over creeks, and pass Upper Reservoir and Sphagnum Pond. Bug spray is recommended during the spring and summer months!

Begin with a hike uphill towards a viewpoint where there are sweeping views of Sleeping Beauty and the surround lakes and mountain. From here, continue to Bumps Pond. Sit and relax along the banks of the pond before hiking back downhill to the parking area.

Anglers should be familiar with New York state fishing regulations.

This trail leads to a beautiful cascade waterfall that is a great place to have lunch or a family picnic.

Begin on Sagamore Road and follow the path through the forest to the banks of South Inlet. There is a DEC sign on the street for the trailhead. Anglers fishing in the stream should be familiar with New York state fishing rules in place.

This loop follows around the border of Central Park. There are many opportunities to enter the park and other landmarks surrounding it.

The route passes by the Central Park Zoo, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Guggenheim Museum, Conservatory Garden, American Museum of Natural History, and Dana Discovery Center.

Plenty of shade and ruins along this beautiful creek-side path. Very easy and family friendly.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Crow Hill Road at the north end of the trail. The trail surface is paved bridges (with railings), gravel, or natural (dirt, fallen leaf) surfaces. It is typically at least 4 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the mostly unpaved surface type. There are benches along the route for resting.

This route starts at Hannum Rd and takes you along a well-maintained trail with some challenging and enjoyable elevation changes through the Chautauqua Gorge State Forest area. This area is more than 500 acres and offers a wide variety of outdoor recreation, such as cross-country skiing, snowshoeing, hiking, biking, primitive camping, fishing, and hunting.

Enjoy an easy walk with world-class views at Cranberry Pond. This paved trail loops around the pond and offers stunning glimpses of Lake Ontario. But the real stars of the show are the birds. Braddock Bay is a globally important area for bird migration. The unique geography of the lake concentrates birds here, making it one of the best places to see them.

Explore this 2.5-mile out-and-back trail near Brewster, New York. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 46 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through November.

The parking area is on the other side of the road from the start point of the trail.

The trail passes through an open meadow and past a swamp area before entering the forest. There are some bog bridges in place to cross through wet areas and small wooden ladders to climb up some steep sections of the trail.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 2 designated accessible parking spaces with a striped access aisle in the paved parking lot off West Strand Street. The trail can be accessed using a sidewalk to the south of the parking lot. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved (with partial edge barriers and railings) or gravel. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Discover this 1.6-mile loop trail near Huntington, New York. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 28 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through November. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Try this 3.9-mile out-and-back trail near New York City, New York. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 25 min to complete. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 2.6-mile out-and-back trail near Wells, New York. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 3 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October.

Experience this 10.0-mile point-to-point trail near Hurley, New York. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 8 min to complete. This trail is great for cross-country skiing and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November.

Try this 1.5-mile loop trail near Old Forge, New York. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 30 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 0.8-mile out-and-back trail near Montrose, New York. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 20 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The loop begins with a steep climb and eventually reaches a high point before turning back towards the starting point on the second half of the loop. There are some small streams and large boulders alongside the trail.

The trail is mostly wooded and is marked with blue diamond-shaped blazes reading Osgood Trail.

Enjoy this 5.0-mile out-and-back trail near Bolton Landing, New York. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 43 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a gentle and picturesque hike with highlights including a winding river, wooden and stone bridges, giant tulip trees, rolling meadows with tall grasses, a sycamore grove, oriole birds, and easy gravel paths with occasional horse riders.

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are designated accessible spaces in the parking lot off of Old Sleepy Hollow Road at the north end of the trail. The trail surface is gravel. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.1, 1.6-1.8, and 2.2 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade.

Start of the trail is on an ATV road of some sorts but very wooded and secluded and turned north onto a nice single foot path. After crossing the road north, you come to a lean to (camping by permit only).

The trail is not well marked or maintained in some areas, downloading the map ahead of time is helpful for navigating.

This is a relatively gentle Catskills hike that takes you to the "Bearpen" Roundtop mountain, not to be confused with Roundtop in Kaaterskill Wild Forest. This is a great hike for snowshoeing, and the summit section may require some bushwhacking, as the trails are under-used and overgrown. Old unmarked logging roads and snowmobile trails zigzag through this area, so be mindful of your recording to ensure you are on the right track. Just past the summit there is a ledge with nice views.

Get to know this 1.1-mile out-and-back trail near Saratoga Springs, New York. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 19 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through July.

Explore this 1.1-mile loop trail near New York City, New York. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 20 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

The Sylvan Trail heads north looping through the forest. The park is very popular with birders and the park publishes a birding checklist. The trail is close to the golf course at points, so expect to hear and see a few other people.

Woodpeckers, thrushes, warblers, and nut hatches can all be spotted in the woodland area.

Make sure to sign in at the trailhead register. The trail is marked with red disks. In the first section, you will cross several small creeks and pass around a marsh area. At the trail split, an old road (now a snowmobile trail) continues to the left, while the path you want to take bears right. After passing two cabins used by the fire observer, you begin a strenuous climb. After another mile, the climb becomes more moderate. 

There is a fire tower at the end of the path for everyone to enjoy the panorama to the north.

During the winter months do not park by the gate, park across the street at the trailhead for the Boreas River Trail. There should be a little plowed-out area.

The French Louie Trail runs from the trailhead on Military Road past Pillsbury Lake to Whitney Lake. Along the way there are some backcountry shelters for backpackers to camp at. Anglers should be familiar with NY fishing laws.

Sections of the trail are not well maintained, downloading the map ahead of time is recommended.

This hike covers 1.8 miles of the 5.6-mile Forney Ridge Trail in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.  The hike is from Kuwohi parking lot to Andrew's Bald, which has views of the Great Smoky Mountains. Kuwohi Observation Tower is open year-round.

The Forney Ridge Trailhead is at the end of the parking lot at the end of Kuwohi Road.  The first mile or so of the trail proceeds downhill through woods.  Portions of the trail here are very rocky, which can make for difficult hiking.

The trail then heads uphill through woods to Andrew's Bald, which is 1.8 miles from the trailhead.  Andrew's Bald is one of several "balds" in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, which are so named because they are mountaintops that are not covered by trees, but are instead covered by grass, rhododendron, and mountain laurel.  From Andrew's bald, there are panoramic views of the southern half of the park, including Fontana Lake.  Wildlife sightings, including black bears, are also possible.

Hikers can return to Kuwohi to complete the 3.6-mile hike or continue down the Forney Ridge Trail.  The Forney Ridge trail continues nearly four more miles down the ridge, however, making for a very steep return trip.

Experience this 0.8-mile loop trail near Huntersville, North Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 15 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Great for cyclists and families. Fully paved with a few small hills.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Kelly Road at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete (with partial railings) and smooth. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). There are painted dividing lines and metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) but there are steeper sections at about 0.1 and 1.7 miles when going east. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the east end of the trail.

Betty Place Trail (#298) is a short and family-friendly route located next to the West Fork Shut-In Creek. Enjoy a glimpse into the past when traveling next to former homesteads on the way. There are several small creek crossings that make for a scenic place to rest and admire the forest scenery.  Half-way, the trail connects with the Bluff Mountain Loop trail for those who wish to extend their route.

This trail to David Falls begins at the Catawba Falls Trailhead and follows a natural path upstream through Pisgah National Forest. The route winds beside the river, crossing roots, rocks, and small streams shaded by oak, poplar, and rhododendron. Mossy boulders and the steady sound of rushing water guide the way as the trail climbs into a narrower, steeper valley. At its end, the forest opens to David Falls, where a clear cascade tumbles over rock ledges into a cool pool below. With its blend of creekside scenery, forest shade, and waterfall views, the trail provides a rewarding mountain hike.

This park has varying hours of operation. Typically, it is open on weekends, as well as Thursday and Friday afternoons. It's recommended to check the park's website before heading out to confirm its opening hours. For more information, please visit https://www.rowancountync.gov/Facilities/Facility/Details/Dunns-Mountain-Park-18

This peaceful loop trail at Marvin Efird Park winds along a natural surface path through shady hardwood forest and open grassy edges. The route circles past picnic areas, a community garden, and quiet stretches of woodland where deer and songbirds are often seen. Seasonal wildflowers and ferns brighten the understory, while tall oaks and pines provide steady shade along much of the way. With its mix of natural scenery and community spaces, the loop offers a relaxed and refreshing walk through this small-town park.

This trail is fully paved and heads from the southern end of Southern Community Park to the Morgan Creek trail in the north.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Dogwood Access Drive at the south end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges) and smooth. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

There are painted dividing lines and metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) but there is a steeper section at about 0.3 miles when going northbound. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Head out on this 13.0-mile point-to-point trail near Laurel Springs, North Carolina. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 25 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Cates Farm Park, a former pickle farm, now offers this family friendly loop to hike, bike, and run.  After parking, head towards the old barn to see a bit of history about the property.  From there, follow the trail west to an old cedar grove and loop back around to the barn.  Add the Wildflower loop for a bit more distance.

This is a convenient short hike near the road, perfect for families with kids or dogs. The trail is well-marked and usually not too crowded, offering beautiful views and wildlife. There are a couple of small sections that are a bit overgrown, but they are not difficult to navigate. In the spring, there are many beautiful flowers along the trail to observe.

This trail is a lovely creek-side walk for the the first couple miles, then a mile by the Yadkin River, and then back through the forest. You’ll need to cross the creek a few times, and while there are rocks to step on, your feet may get wet. At the second creek crossing, follow a short trail that goes 40 feet to the right for a simple way to cross. After a mile or so you’ll take a left off the road to the Horne Creek trail - you’ll see an outhouse and picnic grounds. 

Once you reach the Yadkin, the trail becomes narrower, and a bit overgrown. You’ll reach a point where the Yadkin River is apparently fordable in the right weather. You can choose to extend your trip by walking further along the River on the Bean Shoals Canal Trail or cut to your right, taking either the Yadkin River Trail or a cut through the forest back to the road.

John Neal Falls is a hidden gem accessible from Tanasee Gap Road. After parking at the trailhead, follow a gradual incline on FR9999, passing a steep trail shortcut before turning left onto the main path. Continue downhill toward Parker Creek, crossing it to follow a scenic, sometimes swampy route. The trail leads to an unnamed tributary where the falls are located, just a short walk up from the creek. Return by reversing the route.

This rugged route in the Fires Creek Backcountry begins at Bristol Horse Camp and climbs toward Julie High Top along Bristol Trail #76. The natural surface path winds through dense hardwood forest, with stretches of rhododendron and mountain laurel lining the way. The climb is steady, crossing rocky ground and narrow ridges that gradually rise toward the summit. Along the route, small streams and mossy boulders break up the woodland, while deer and wild turkey are often seen in the understory. Near Julie High Top, openings in the canopy reveal sweeping views of the surrounding Nantahala Mountains. With its mix of shaded climbs, ridgeline passages, and mountain overlooks, the trail offers a classic backcountry experience.

You can begin the Gateway Trail at South Battleground Avenue at Quarry Road or at Galilee Church Road just off of Highway 161. 

This trail is wide, traveled, and well-marked. You should see lots of wildlife, trees and water areas.  The trail is mostly crushed gravel with a fair amount of shaded areas. You will get a great view of Crowders Mountain. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the large partially paved parking lot off of Quarry Road at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement, wooden boardwalk (with railings), or gravel. It is typically 4 to 8 feet wide. There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) but there are steeper sections from about 0.9 through 2.9 miles when going south. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. 

All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface types and grade. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the north end of the trail. According to the trail website, this trail is wheelchair-accessible.

Lake Lynn is a man-made lake in North Raleigh with a 2-mile greenway running around the lake, consisting of paved surface and boardwalks.

The easy walk around Lake Lynn is a pleasant loop and you're sure to see wildlife, including ducks, geese, herons, turtles and other aquatic life.  It's very popular, so don't expect to find solitude.  The mixed-use trail accommodates walkers, joggers, dogs (must be on a 6-foot leash), bicyclers, and roller-blades.

Head out on this 3.6-mile out-and-back trail near Raleigh, North Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 17 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, fishing, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 0.4-mile loop trail near Winston-Salem, North Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 7 min to complete. This trail is great for road biking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

In order to reach this trail head, it is suggested to travel to the dead end of Cold Springs Creek Road and take a right- you will be led up a gated road. The hike is mostly along a forest road bed that connects to a small and primitive trail leads to the falls. Little Fall Branch Falls is a beautiful, yet unassuming, cascade that makes for a peaceful area to relax and soak up the natural surroundings.

This route starts at the trail entrance off Nut Hill Rd, offering panoramic views of the mountains from the very beginning. You will go by Lookout Mountain along a nice trail with enjoyable hills through a lush green forest with lovely wildflowers. Other trails connect to the route if you want to extend your journey.

This trail is moderate with difficult sections. Trailhead is in parking area off Lookout Road. The trail crosses the Old Trestle Road and climbs steeply to end at exposed rocks below the summit of Lookout Mountain with outstanding views of Montreat and the Seven Sisters. Please stay on the marked trail; this mountain has many visitors and several old trails have been closed due to severe erosion problems.

Please be advised that the Montreat Trail System is on private property. Posted rules are strictly enforced. Traffic is often congested and parking is limited, especially on weekends. It is recommended to park at Anderson Auditorium and walk to the designated trailhead. More information can be found at: https://montreat.org/visit/wilderness

Discover this 5.0-mile out-and-back trail near Cherokee, North Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 7 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through November.

This is a short hike through a dense forest to a limited view of Newt Falls. It is suggested to not travel to the base of the falls due to slippery rock and tough terrain to navigate. While this hike is short, there are many other trails in this section of Pisgah National Forest to check out and add to a day hike.

This trail is considered one of the most difficult trails in North Carolina and the United States.  There are plenty of places to filter water so you do not have to worry about bringing a lot to begin with. There are a dozen stream crossings as well as the brush can be somewhat thick so pants are advised.

South Graham Municipal Park has two outdoor basketball goals, two lighted tennis courts, two sand volleyball courts, three open-air picnic shelters, a sandstone walking track (.28 mile), a nature trail (.38 mile), a wooded picnic area, restrooms, and a playground.

While visiting the nature trail, the creek meandering along the trail is the Little Alamance Creek (LAC). The City of Burlington, the City of Graham, and NC Department of Transportation formed a partnership committed to restoring the health of the LAC Watershed. Community engagement, education, and outreach programs play an important role in improving water quality and in the revitalization of the LAC Watershed. Learn more the LAC and how you can get involved at Little Alamance Creek Healthy Streams Cooperative. 

Well-behaved, leashed dogs (short leash and in hand) are welcome in the parks, on walking tracks, and along the trails. Please help keep the parks clean by cleaning up after your pet.

This is a tobacco-free, smoke-free, vape-free park.

Enjoy this 7.0-mile out-and-back trail near Topton, North Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 10 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through December. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This trail features a mix of gravel and natural paths, with minimal signage but easy to navigate. The path is easy-going and smooth but can become a little muddy after rain. It's a short, enjoyable hike managed by the Spencer Parks and Recreation Department, winding through old-growth hardwoods and teeming with bird life.

Enjoy this 13.2-mile out-and-back trail near Morganton, North Carolina. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 20 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Tobacco Barn Ridge and Fox Trot trails at Northeast Park form a scenic woodland route with rolling hills, quiet ridgelines, and stretches of dense forest. Trail-goers will enjoy a mix of shaded canopy, natural surface tread, and occasional clearings that offer a peaceful backcountry feel. With gentle climbs and a tranquil setting, these trails are ideal for hikers looking to explore the park’s more remote and rustic terrain.

This trail starts at the parking lot off Gorges State Park Loop Road, where restrooms and a picnic shelter are available, and leads to an overlook with a wooden platform that offers beautiful views of Upper Bearwallow Falls in Gorges State Park. It’s a short hike through a shaded forest but be prepared for steep sections with loose dirt - sturdy footwear is recommended.

Head out on this 15.5-mile point-to-point trail near Glen Alpine, North Carolina. Generally considered an easy route. This trail is great for paddle sports, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

This peaceful paved loop at the Whiteville Recreation Center circles open grassy fields and clusters of shade trees, creating a relaxed neighborhood walk. The smooth path passes near playgrounds, picnic areas, and sports courts, blending community activity with natural scenery. Birds and squirrels are often active along the tree line, while the open layout provides wide views across the park. With its simple design and welcoming atmosphere, the loop offers a pleasant stroll for all ages.

Discover this 2.3-mile loop trail near Bismarck, North Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 40 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This family-friendly trail begins at the arboretum's main parking area. It offers a peaceful and educational experience as it winds through an area planted with over 50 species of trees, shrubs, wildflowers, and grasses. It provides a wonderful opportunity to learn about the local flora while enjoying a relaxing walk through the park’s scenic landscape.

Enjoy this 15.3-mile loop trail near Grassy Butte, North Dakota. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 7 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

From the parking area, follow a short two-track road to the singletrack trailhead. After about a mile, cross the trail’s only water feature and reach a fork: go right for the 5-mile loop or left to add 3 miles. The trail features rocky sections and tight turns but remains manageable, with open terrain typical of North Dakota. Complete the 8-mile loop for a solid, scenic workout.

This trail begins at the Chalet Trailhead. You'll travel through open prairies and woods. This route also features that park's oxbow wetlands. You'll even get to cross the wetlands on a boardwalk. There is a wildlife viewing blind for checking out birds, turtles, and other wildlife living in the oxbow.

Experience this 1.0-mile loop trail near Carpio, North Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 28 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The trail starts at the main parking area by the Visitor Center and is accessed from the Matah Trail at the preserve boundary. It winds through the bottomland forest on preserve property and follows an old jeep track that is still used for scientific studies. Hikers are asked not to disturb areas marked with paint or flags, as studies are still in progress. This trail is groomed for skiing.

This trail starts at the parking area just east of the Guardhouse. This family-friendly loop promotes health and fitness, providing a pleasant place to bicycle, walk, jog, or cross-country ski during the winter. The route meanders through tree and shrub plantings that support a diverse bird population and features 16 stations equipped with exercise apparatus and posted instructions. Portions of the trail offer scenic views along the eastern shoreline of Lake Sakakawea.

Enjoy this 4.3-mile loop trail near Mandan, North Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 37 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through October.

This paved trail heads around the baseball fields at the Elmwood Parks. There are two road crossings along the route, both at 13th Avenue West.

Accessibility: There are at least 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot south of 13th Avenue West by the start of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is smoothly paved asphalt or cement, and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (all 3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most users with wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the route for resting.

Head out on this 1.3-mile loop trail near Fargo, North Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 24 min to complete. This trail is great for snowshoeing and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October.

Explore this 6.7-mile loop trail near Mandan, North Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 24 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October.

The trail at this historic site offers a unique journey through the remnants of an early 19th-century trading post and a Mandan village, with over 2,200 visible surface features like house ruins and graves. The path immerses visitors in history while providing views of the Missouri River and surrounding creeks. Open May to September, it’s a free and fascinating experience for explorers and history enthusiasts.

Fort Mandan State Historic Site charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://www.history.nd.gov/historicsites/mandan/

Visit the reconstruction of Fort Mandan - the original being famous for the place where the hospitable Mandan and Hidatsa peoples housed Lewis and Clark in 1804-1805. Fort Mandan is where Lewis and Clark became friends with such historical figures as Sacagawea, Toussaint Charbonneau, and Sheheke-Shote.

The visitor center offers guided tours at regular intervals each day. 

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 4 designated accessible parking spaces in the paved parking lot off 8th Street Southwest, 2 of which are van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

Surface
The trail surface is gravel or natural (dirt, leaves, roots) and is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

Check out this 0.5-mile loop trail near Bismarck, North Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 9 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This paved loop heads around the Hillside Park starting at the Aquatic Center.

Accessibility: There are at least 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of East Boulevard Avenue at the start of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (asphalt or cement), and typically at least 4 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the western loop, where the slope is estimated to be mostly gentle. There are steep (8-12%) uphill and downhill sections on the eastern loop between about 0.25 to 0.75 miles when going clockwise. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Get to know this 0.4-mile loop trail near Bismarck, North Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 8 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 4.5-mile out-and-back trail near Hazen, North Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 24 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October.

Head out on this 1.1-mile loop trail near Kenmare, North Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 27 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

A spectacular scenic vista awaits your exploration at the end of the North Unit Scenic Drive. Explore interpretive waysides along a short accessible sidewalk and take in the views of the meandering Little Missouri River surrounded by tall cottonwood trees and impressive buttes. 

Aptly named, Oxbow Overlook represents a type of meander that is occurring in the river. Oxbows and oxbow lakes are common along this free-flowing river where natural flood cycles constantly shift the river's course. Be sure to look for wildlife amongst the surrounding buttes.

Enjoy this 2.1-mile loop trail near Hensler, North Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 49 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Discover this 5.0-mile out-and-back trail near Fargo, North Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 29 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This loop heads around the open grass space and by the baseball diamonds at the Rendezvous Park. It also connects to trails that head to the Eagle Run Park and 40th Avenue West Park.

Accessibility: There are at least 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of Lakeside Way at the start of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is asphalt or cement, smooth, and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and picnic shelters along the route for resting.

The Riverside Greenway starts at Riverside Park and runs north to downtown Beulah at 1st Street Southwest and south to Cottontail Drive. 

Accessibility: There are do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Highway 49 in the middle of the trail at Beulah Riverside Park. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 10 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is from 0.0 miles to about 1.1 miles on the portion north of Riverside Park. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less), except for steep (8-12%) sections at about 1.4 miles and 1.6 miles uphill when going south. Trail goers using wheelchair/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

The trail starts at the main parking area of the West Side Trails and loops just west of Lake McDonald, near the Canada and United States border. Open to hiking, biking, skiing, and snowshoeing, it winds through forest, grassland, and wetlands. Watch for moose, deer, pine martens, ruffed grouse, and a wide variety of vegetation along the way.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Riverside Park Road at the northeast end of the trail.
