Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved or dirt/grass and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved section in the first quarter-mile when heading counterclockwise. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Trail starts at the main parking area. According to park maps, this hand-built blue-level intermediate cross-country trail is a true singletrack, offering a technical ride with tight turns. While not as steep as Dragonfly Trail, it provides a similarly challenging experience through its narrow, winding path.

White Butte is considered the North Dakota High Point. It is on private property but open to the public with a suggested donation at the trailhead. To park, you'll look for a large green highway sign off of Highway 85 indicating "White Butte—Highest Point in North Dakota". 

There is a parking area at the trailhead. At the trailhead, you can leave a donation in the secure and clearly marked red receptacle, and be sure to secure the gate.

This trail starts at the parking area just east of the Guardhouse. This family-friendly loop is great for cross-country skiing and jogging as it wanders through tree and shrub plantings that support a diverse bird population. The trail also offers easy access to the Trooper Challenge Loop and the deTrobriand Loop.

Enjoy this 1.1-mile out-and-back trail near Akron, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 23 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Try this 0.8-mile loop trail near Berea, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 14 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 0.4-mile point-to-point trail near Chillicothe, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 10 min to complete. This is a popular trail for running and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Get to know this 46.1-mile point-to-point trail near Peninsula, Ohio. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 14 h 45 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Burning Lake Trail consists of two different loops in the northeastern portion of Pickerington Ponds Metro Park. This route begins by following the outer and longer path through some meadows and woodlands before hopping on the shorter inner trail that passes through a fairly small wetland ecosystem. 

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 4 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically 8-10 feet wide. A painted dividing line along most of the trail reduces the width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Situated just a 15-minute drive west of downtown Columbus, the Prairie Oaks Metro Park is a beautiful nature oasis. The park is ideal for walking, fishing, picnicking, bird-watching, boating, and wildlife viewing. There are miles of trails weaving through the open prairies and grasslands.

One popular trail here is the Darby Creek Greenway Trail. The section within Prairie Oaks Metro Park is actually just several miles of the trail. The route extends south into Battelle Darby Creek Metro Park as well, however, the two sections do not connect.

This trail is wide, well-maintained, and ideal for families. You might even get a chance to see one of the bison!

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of County Highway 7 at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is gravel or a wooden bridge with railings. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. There are benches along the route for resting.

Check out this 3.9-mile loop trail near West Portsmouth, Ohio. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 47 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Check out this 0.4-mile loop trail near Batavia, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 8 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 1.4-mile loop trail near Cincinnati, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 27 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Try this 0.5-mile loop trail near Germantown, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 11 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This scenic trail in the Gilliland Nature Preserve winds through 80 acres of prairie and woodlands, offering a mix of wetland, prairie, and forest habitats. Along the mowed grass trails, visitors can enjoy informative signs and an observation tower for great bird-watching and wildlife viewing. Parking is available nearby at South Shore Sportsman’s Club, 5380 Club Island Road. Trails are well-maintained, providing an immersive nature experience.

This short paved trail loops around the Cedar Ridge Picnic Area. The path is well-maintained, smooth, and easy-going. It is excellent for walking, running, and cycling and it passes under a thick timber canopy, offering plenty of shade on hot days. This area of the park has plenty of parking and amenities are available at the trailhead.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 11 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

More Info
Wheelchair accessible restrooms are available near the trailhead. Picnic tables and benches are available near the trailhead.

Experience this 1.6-mile loop trail near Sullivan, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 29 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through June.

Experience this 1.1-mile loop trail near Spencer, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route. This is a popular trail for running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are November through December.

Enjoy this 1.4-mile loop trail near Minster, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 24 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 1.2-mile loop trail near Millbury, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 21 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This short trail loops through the woods directly behind the Narrows Reserve Nature Center. Starting from the parking area near the canoe launch, the path can be taken in either direction. It is easy-going and easy to follow, and it has a sight hill, which is doable for all levels of hikers. The beginning of the trail has great views of the river, while the rest of the trail is nestled in a dense forest.

This is an all dirt trail that runs through the forest above the paved all-purpose trail.  The trail ends at the all-purpose trail.

Hikers can access the trailhead from the parking area near the Chestnut Lodge. If you're looking for a much longer hike, you could easily add any of the nearby connecting trails to this one and alter the route so you can visit one of the ponds in the area.

Explore this 1.1-mile loop trail near Athens, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 26 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are August through November.

Discover this 6.8-mile out-and-back trail near Greenfield, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 10 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through March.

Get to know this 5.7-mile loop trail near Lucas, Ohio. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 12 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, horseback riding, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This paved out-and-back path is a popular trail for those living in the neighborhoods bordering the Preston Trails Park property. There is no official parking lot for this trail, so you will have to utilize roadside parking at either the southern or western trailhead in order to access the path. In the wet season, you can here Sycamore Creek flowing on the eastern border of the park.

Head out on this 1.7-mile loop trail near Westlake, Ohio. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 29 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Starting just east of the Red Lock parking area, this trail winds through the Jaite Mill Historic District, offering scenic views of the Cuyahoga River from the start. It is a great route for walking or hiking while providing convenient proximity to historic sites and nature along the way. Some parts of the trail can be strenuous due to slight elevation changes, so plan your gear accordingly.

Resilience is the longer of the two loop trails offered in the preserve. Both trails leave the trailhead along the same route, continuing together through the eastern section of the ridgetop’s woodlands. When the two trails separate, Grasshopper Ridge Trail completes its loop in the ridgetops’s meadows whereas the Resilience Trail continues to wind through a mosaic of forest types. The woodlands include mature oak and hickory forests that haven't been disturbed for 80 or more years. Wildflowers here include perfoliate bellflower, black snakeroot, and wild comfrey. The trail also passes through younger successional hardwood forests, and stands of Virginia Pine that are reclaiming the open fields. Resilience Preserve has bountiful vernal pools left behind by the property’s earlier coal mining and reclamation activities. Look for salamander larvae with their external gills, wood frog and American toad tadpoles, and other aquatic life.

Rhododendron Cove is a well-marked trail that begins with an initial incline that leads up to a dry ridgeline. From the top, you are rewarded with stunning views of the Hocking River Valley. The trail meanders through a landscape dotted with unique rock formations. You will find pitch pine, sourwood, mountain laurel, blueberry, and deerberry along the trail.

The Brown Trail in Sugarcreek MetroPark is the main equestrian loop. There are actually several paths marked with "brown" trail markers, but they all intersect at some point and can be combined to create different distance loops. Hikers and runners can also use this trail, but it should be noted that this is loop is primarily meant for horses.

This short trail loops around the Sycamore Fields multi-use fields on the Three Creeks Metro Park property. The trail is a common place to spot walkers, joggers, and children on bikes. The path also connects to some of the other paved trails on the park property, including the Alum Creek Trail.

The City of Columbus Recreation and Parks Department maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 6 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 6 feet wide. Bollards at the trailhead temporarily reduce the tread width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

More Info
Public restrooms are available near the trailhead. This trail has little shade, so wearing appropriate sun protection is recommended.

This route is the outer loop that runs around Wick Park and makes for a really fun walk or jog. During the winter when the trees are bare, this route feels a little lack-luster, but most of the year it's a really lovely walk. This route is only partially paved; there's an inner loop that can be done which is fully paved.

This short trail winds from the parking area through tall prairie grasses and wildflowers, leading to an observation blind overlooking a 35-acre "pothole" wetland. The wetlands and prairie sanctuary provides a glimpse of Ohio's landscape before settlement. The preserve, ideal for birdwatching, attracts migrating shorebirds and grassland nesting birds while offering habitat benefits such as flood reduction and water purification.

This is a great walk on the many paths around Acacia Reservation. The park has many interpretive signs about local wildlife and plants.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Cedar Road at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 2.4 and 3.0 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

Check out this 6.6-mile loop trail near Canadian, Oklahoma. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 22 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and horseback riding, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through December.

The Bear Trail, located within Natural Falls State Park is a popular hiking path that offers visitors a chance to experience the park's natural beauty. The trail is fairly short and features a series of steps and a bridge that crosses over a creek, leading to a scenic overlook of the park's waterfall. Hikers can enjoy views of the lush forest, diverse plant life, and the cascading waterfall. The trail is well-maintained and suitable for most visitors, making it a great spot to check out when visiting this area.

Explore this 10.8-mile loop trail near Cheyenne, Oklahoma. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 52 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and horseback riding, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This short loop near the parking area loops around the retention pond. The path is mostly dry dirt and cut grass. The parking area is not well-marked but there is plenty of space for vehicles and trailers. This area has no amenities but has shady trees around the water. There are many trails linked to the south for extended ventures.

Buffalo and Antelope Springs Trail takes you to Chickasaw National Recreation Area. The trail starts at the Travertine Nature Center parking lot, where you'll also find restrooms, a picnic area, and Little Niagara Falls. It leads through a shady forest, alongside the creek, and past a pond. The trail is wide and offers benches for resting.

Get to know this 0.7-mile out-and-back trail near Wilburton, Oklahoma. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 20 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are August through November.

This is a short hike around the Clayton Lake State Recreation area near the Clayton Dam. This is a scenic area that makes for a great place to get a quick walk in or simply enjoy the lake.

There are several fishing piers located here as well as boat launches for those who wish to explore the park via water.

The Crab Eyes trail is home to a remarkable rock formation resembling "crab eyes, two big parallel stones poised atop a narrow granite column. This formation offers breathtaking views of Charon's Garden Mountain, Elk Mountain, Mt. Lincoln, Granite Mountain, Twin Rocks Mountain, and Sunset Mountain. 

The hike starts on the edge of a creek bed and ascends a verdant mountain. The trail also goes via a tunnel, requiring hikers to climb several boulders. There are creek crossings along this densely forested and well-shaded trail. The final ascent along this trail resembles a staircase to the slabs. Hikers can slide up to the middle of the ridge and wedge themselves between two horizontal slabs to reach the peak. They can carefully walk on the exposed outer slab or crab between the slabs.

Explore this 2.0-mile loop trail near Ardmore, Oklahoma. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 38 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This route highlights the main, outer loop at Elmer Thomas Park. There are several gravel inner trails to shorten or lengthen your journey.

Accessibility: This paved (asphalt, cement and wooden bridge) trail is typically at least 6 feet wide. The inner trails are gravel and dirt, trail goers using mobility equipment or a stroller may need some assistance if going that route. There is often a painted center dividing line along the path and bollards at road crossings which reduce the width. The slope is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% grade or less) except for moderately steep sections at about 0.6 and 1.2 miles when going counterclockwise. Mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance there. Benches are placed along the way for a rest.

There are 2 designated wheelchair-accessible parking spaces with access aisles at the paved trailhead lot. There are several other accessible parking spots around the park.

Try this 6.9-mile out-and-back trail near Muse, Oklahoma. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 21 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The trails here offer a great way to get outside for a walk or bike ride through different parts of town. As you travel along these routes, you might think about Enid's early days, famously part of the Cherokee Strip Land Run of 1893. The trails provide a nice, easy way to enjoy the outdoors in the "Queen Wheat City".

Get to know this 2.6-mile out-and-back trail near Lawton, Oklahoma. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 49 min to complete. This trail is great for road biking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Nestled in the picturesque hills of Eastern Oklahoma, Greenleaf State Park is a charming and family-friendly destination that offers breathtaking scenery. The park boasts Lake Greenleaf, which is surrounded by nature hiking trails, family recreation facilities, and camping grounds. While primarily designed for overnight backpacking, the 18-mile loop is also a popular spot among day hikers, who can equally enjoy the stunning views along the trail.

The Salt Plains National Wildlife Refuge's Harold F. Miller Auto Trail offers a scenic driving tour of the Refuge's wetlands, with views of several marshes and the opportunity to see a variety of shorebirds, wildflowers, and trees. It begins near the Wildlife Refuge headquarters and connects to State Highway 11.

Get to know this 1.8-mile out-and-back trail near Norman, Oklahoma. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 37 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are December through March. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Get to know this 2.2-mile out-and-back trail near Stillwater, Oklahoma. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 40 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are October through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This trail begins at the campground, offering intermediate-level hiking and an exciting horseback route. Initially heading southwest away from the lake, the trail winds through open and grassy areas before transitioning into wooded sections to the south. As you curve back toward the northwest, enjoy scenic views of the lake shoreline before zig-zagging south and completing the loop with a northeast turn.

This trail may be short in distance, but it has steep inclines in some sections which make it quite challenging. Navigating through the trail can be difficult as it is not very well marked. However, the serene forest environment and lots of wildlife make the trail enjoyable. There is a scenic seasonal creek halfway through the trail where one can stop and take a nice break.

Explore this 5.7-mile loop trail near Meeker, Oklahoma. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 57 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, horseback riding, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are July through November.

This route takes you on a short hike on an easy trail to Osage Lake, where you can also enjoy some nice views of the dam and the water. It loops around through the woods along a stream back to the start, where you may see a wide variety of wildlife, including bison. Some areas can be overgrown, and you may cross a creek in some places, so it's best to have long pants and waterproof shoes.

Explore this 2.8-mile loop trail near Tulsa, Oklahoma. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 51 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Head out on this 2.1-mile loop trail near Tulsa, Oklahoma. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 37 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through October. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

The Quanah Parker Trail is a short and easy hike with a nice view from the top. It's a relaxing and family-friendly trail with some beautiful lake views. The trail is well-maintained and follows a paved and gravel path through the campground. In the beginning, there are many intersecting trails, so it's important to follow the map closely.

This lighted asphalt walking trail winds through the wood with a large covered picnic pavilion, restrooms, park benches, picnic tables, barbecue pits, and paved parking. Featuring some of the largest trees in Noble and traversed by Berry Creek, the park’s unique topography makes it a community pride and a popular spot day and night. Riley Park is one of two significant historical sites in Noble, housing the abandoned Santa Fe Railroad Bridge from 1887, which facilitated the land run of 1889. The original stone and brickwork of the bridge remain, showcasing the construction styles of the late 1800s.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt (with bumps and cracks) and typically at least 5 feet wide. 

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with a moderately steep (5-8%) section that may require assistance or need to be avoided..

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Ruby Grant Park offers a series of walking and jogging routes that travel through beautiful open areas with many recreational opportunities offered. There is also a children's play area which is great for the whole family to enjoy together, as well as a large dog park for pet owners. The path features a wide, multi-use concrete path that accommodates bicyclists, runners, and walkers.

Short hike to historic Mysterious Viking Hieroglyphics

The hike begins at the Runestone Loop Kiosk to the right of the gift shop.  Follow the path about 0.03 miles to a junction.  Turn left and proceed town the stairs.  At 0.10 miles you will enter the building containing the RuneStone.  When finished reading about the runestone, continue on the trail, up the stairs and across the bridge to return to the trailhead kiosk by the giftshop.

Enjoy this 0.9-mile loop trail near Woodward, Oklahoma. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 18 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are August through March.

Check out this 3.9-mile loop trail near Leonard, Oklahoma. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 26 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are December through May.

Travel around South Lakes Park.

The City of Oklahoma City maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 3 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically 5 to 12 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

More Info
Public restrooms are available near the trailhead. Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Get to know this 1.5-mile loop trail near Ada, Oklahoma. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 29 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

AmberGlen Park has a half mile of paved pathways that loop around wide-open grassy areas, ponds, and shady picnic areas. The park offers a scenic and traffic-free area for outdoor recreation in a dense urban environment. There is no parking lot, but street parking is available on every side of the park.

The City of Hillsboro maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
Street parking is available near the trailhead, but there do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces nearby.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or wooden boardwalk with edge railings and is typically at least 5 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Public restrooms are available near the trailhead. Benches are available along the route for resting.

One of the highlights of the Ancient Forest Loop is the sense of history that permeates the area. This forest is home to some of the oldest trees in the region, some of which have been growing for centuries. As you walk, you'll notice the wide trunks and thick bark of the ancient trees, many of which have witnessed the passage of time through centuries of weathering, storms, and growth.

The Bandersnatch Trail in Ashland, Oregon, offers a scenic escape through the hillsides outside of town. The trail offers a steady climb as it leads it way up to stunning panoramic views of the Rogue Valley and surrounding mountains. As you make your way up, the landscape transforms from dense forests and creeks into more open ridge lines. This trail is perfect for those looking to immerse themselves in nature and enjoy the sights of the region. This trail is great with its convenient location close to town.

Discover this 10.2-mile loop trail near Bend, Oregon. Generally considered an easy route. This trail is great for running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October.

Starting from the Bessie Butte Trailhead, this route takes you on a quick and exciting hike with a challenging incline to Bessie Butte. Once at the top, you will be rewarded for your efforts with stunning 360-degree panoramic views of the surrounding area. This trail has limited shade, so start early or bring sun protection.

Bob and Crystal Rilee Park is an uncrowded neighborhood gem with multi-use trails that weave throughout the Pacific Northwest forest. The singletrack travels through fields of flowers in the spring, and there are a few options for routes within the park. This loop covers the perimeter of the trail network. Parking is on NE Parrett Mountain Road. The lot is adjacent to a private home; please be mindful of staying on public property.

The McDonald Research Forest has an extensive network of multi-use trails and dirt roads. This route follows the 543 Road to the Bonzai Trail, a flowy singletrack trail that makes a loop over to the Section 36 Trail. The route has a long steady climb and a shorter, steep climb. The trails cut through the forest and follow several creeks throughout the loop.

Bronson Creek Park is a scenic oasis in a densely populated area, offering wetlands, forests, and a paved loop trail. There are benches along the trail and opportunities to see a variety of waterfowl and other wildlife. Bronson Creek flows through the park, and the trail crosses over it on a bridge at the southern end.

Accessibility:  

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.  

Parking  
There is no public parking for this trail, but commercial parking may be available nearby with designated accessible spaces.  

Surface  
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically at least 10 feet wide.  

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).  

More Info  
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Enjoy this 30.1-mile loop trail near Detroit, Oregon. Generally considered a challenging route. This is a popular trail for backpacking, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are June through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Enjoy this 3.1-mile loop trail near Maupin, Oregon. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 12 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through May.

A half-mile-long stroll along the riverfront is home to public art, fountains, and the Saturday Market. 

This short stroll along the Corvallis Waterfront is a perfect place to enjoy the long summer evenings after a meal downtown. There are plenty of signs telling the story of Corvallis, and there are tons of local restaurants and shops to explore.

Mostly used for mountain biking, this trail was built with berms and flow lines by the local MTB community. It's suitable for all skill levels. A paved gravel road leads to the top, followed by a downhill ride on your mountain bike.

As you approach the summit, you can either follow the road or stay on the trails. The views at the top are somewhat limited due to dense tree cover, but the best vantage point is near a small electrical shack close to the upper trailhead sign.

Head out on this 29.6-mile out-and-back trail near Diamond, Oregon. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a popular trail for birding, mountain biking, and scenic driving, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This trail begins at the parking lot off Sulphur Spring Road, where restrooms are available, and takes you to Dimple Hill in McDonald Research Forest via Patterson Road 600. Parking can be busy, so it's best to start early. The trail follows a wide logging road and is well-maintained. While there are steep sections, your efforts will be rewarded with views of Mount Hood, Three-Fingered Jack, and the Three Sisters.

Explore this 26.8-mile loop trail near Estacada, Oregon. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 11 h 35 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Explore this 1.8-mile out-and-back trail near Vernonia, Oregon. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 39 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and snowshoeing, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This trail follows Granite Creek into the North Fork John Day Wilderness up to where the creek flows into the North Fork John Day river. A bridge across the river connects to the North Fork John Day Trail.  A well marked mining access road can be used as a bypass on the return trip. The road is public, but off the road are private mining leases.

Head out on this 11.3-mile out-and-back trail near Dufur, Oregon. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 12 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The trails south of Crooked River Ranch offer miles of multi-use, year-round recreation through the pine forest. This route starts from Northwest Lower Bridge Way and makes a clockwise loop using a series of wide dirt paths. The area is popular with equestrians. Carry water and sun protection when recreating here, and avoid the hottest times of the day.

As a summer-season hiking and winter-season snowshoeing trail, this route has tons to offer outdoor enthusiasts. You'll start at the Teacup Nordic Snopark area, immediately taking the first trail on the left, also the only non-cross-country ski trail in the area. You'll slowly descend through stunning forests with creeks, streams, waterfalls, and views of all the surrounding mountains and buttes, in addition to Mount Hood's ever-looming presence.

Explore this 18.9-mile loop trail near Bend, Oregon. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 7 h 48 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, birding, and camping, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are July through August. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Explore this 39.3-mile out-and-back trail near Blue River, Oregon. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 19 h 28 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Scouters Mountain Trail offers a diverse experience for outdoor enthusiasts.  As you venture along the trail, you'll be treated to a variety of flora and fauna, as well as several points of interest.    

The trail is home to a wide array of plant life, from towering trees to delicate wildflowers. Keep an eye out for native bird species flitting through the branches, and you might even spot some small mammals scurrying about.    

Along the way, several viewpoints offer stunning views of the surrounding landscape. These points of interest provide excellent opportunities to take a break and immerse yourself in nature's beauty.    

While the trail offers a rewarding experience, it's important to be prepared for some obstacles. There may be uneven terrain and other natural challenges, so wear appropriate footwear and tread carefully.    

Overall, the Scouters Mountain Trail is a great place to connect with nature and enjoy the great outdoors.

Try this 2.5-mile out-and-back trail near Clackamas, Oregon. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 44 min to complete. This is a popular trail for road biking, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Sweet Creek Trail heads uphill following the creek. You will pass several waterfalls and cascades along the way, including Annice and Sweet Creek Falls. There are a few spots where you can easily access some pools that are fun to swim in during the warmer months of the year. The falls are most impressive during the rainy spring season.

This beautiful park was built on top of active landslides and unstable coastal rock formations. The park roads were built in the 1930s before the nature of the coastal geology in the area was fully understood. Because of this, the park often experiences geological emergencies that cause the park to close for periods of time for repair. For more information, visit the park page: https://stateparks.oregon.gov/index.cfm?do=park.profile&parkId=136 .

Check out this 1.0-mile out-and-back trail near Lake Oswego, Oregon. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 31 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October.

Experience this 2.1-mile out-and-back trail near Cascadia, Oregon. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 41 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through November. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Check out this 12.5-mile out-and-back trail near Dufur, Oregon. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 7 h 4 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Virginia Meissner Trail  meanders through the lush forests, offering beautiful views of the surrounding natural landscape outside of Bend. The trail is perfect for those looking to enjoy a peaceful hike, with sections that weave through dense trees and open areas with scenic outlooks to the surrounding mountains. It's a great spot to explore and is suitable for a variety of outdoor activities, including hiking and cross-country skiing in the winter months.

The Youngs River was originally discovered by Lieutenant William Broughton of the Vancouver Expedition in 1792, who named it in honor of Admiral Sir George Young of the Royal Navy. It would be another fourteen years before the spectacular Youngs River Falls would be discovered by Sergeant Patrick Gass, a member of Lewis and Clark’s Corps of Discovery.

Located just ten miles south of the city of Astoria, Oregon, Youngs River Falls is a popular summer recreation spot for swimming. Here, the warm waters of the Youngs River tumble over a rocky 54-foot drop to a pool below, the deepest point of which is between five to seven feet and surrounded by dense forest. From the parking lot, a short 0.25-mile trail leads downhill from the parking lot to the base of the waterfall. The waterfall can also be seen from the parking lot.  

Admission to the site is free and is open year-round for day-use only. Dogs are welcome but must be kept on a leash. Climbing and cliff jumping are not permitted.

Alpha Pass: blue blazes. This trail is at the northern end of McConnells Mill State Park and is part of the North Country National Scenic Trail. This trail begins at the Alpha Pass scenic vista and follows the east bank of Slippery Rock Creek. There is an exit to the Point Parking Area or the trail follows the creek to the Old Mill.

Check out this 0.7-mile loop trail near Glen Mills, Pennsylvania. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 12 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Thsi is the second longest hike, and the first difficult one. There are quite a few creek crossings, most are bridged. There are no campsites along this trail, but you do come within a short trot of one. Elevation gain is mild. Views are nice, especially in the late spring and fall. Dogs are welcome.

Get to know this 3.8-mile loop trail near Blakeslee, Pennsylvania. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 12 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, mountain biking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Explore this 2.7-mile loop trail near Doylestown, Pennsylvania. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 53 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Welcome to Natural Lands’ ChesLen Preserve.

The preserve is open sunrise to sunset, free of charge, for all to enjoy. Closed Thursdays.

ChesLen Preserve is part of Natural Lands' 23,000-acre network of nature preserves. The conservation non-profit is member supported and works to save open space, care for nature, and connect people to the outdoors in eastern Pennsylvania and southern New Jersey. 

Land for life, nature for all. 

https://natlands.org/visit/

Check out this 2.3-mile loop trail near Cooksburg, Pennsylvania. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 2 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping, cross-country skiing, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through December. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Begin from the parking area on the corner of Valley Forge Park Road (Route 23) and North Inner Line Drive. Travel along the mowed trails through meadows that host a multitude of native plants and wildlife. To protect this delicate environment, dogs are prohibited from April through August.

The National Park Service maintains this trail network.

In December 1777, the exhausted and ill-supplied Continental Army marched into Valley Forge to begin a legendary winter encampment. Over the next six months, General George Washington transformed the army from a collection of disparate militias into a cohesive and disciplined fighting force. Learn more about Valley Forge NHP and America's 250th Celebrations at America's National Parks™: americasnationalparks.org/americas-250th

Discover a quiet escape on the loop around the Gunter Valley. This trail is perfect for a relaxing hike, following the shoreline of a former reservoir that is now drained. The path offers a unique chance to see the landscape's transformation and imagine the deep lake that once filled the valley to supply water to nearby towns. It’s a great place to enjoy the outdoors and connect with the changing history of the land.

This loop explores the Hickory Creek Wilderness Area which was established in 1984. The 8,663-acre area is dominated by northern hardwoods and wildlife such as deer and bears call this area home.

The trail is known for its rustic characteristics, and as a result, it is not well-marked in many areas. Downloading the map ahead of time is recommended.

Enjoy this 0.5-mile out-and-back trail near Alburtis, Pennsylvania. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 11 min to complete. This trail is great for fishing, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 6.6-mile out-and-back trail near Ohiopyle, Pennsylvania. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 56 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Head out on this 2.9-mile loop trail near Sewickley, Pennsylvania. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 19 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November.

This route provides a really nice hike on a mostly gravel trail. Starting at Bogart's Bridge offers ample parking. It's also a good place to run, with a beautiful creek, wildlife, and old buildings.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 2 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Fish Hatchery Road at the trail's south end. 

Surface
The trail surface is gravel or paved asphalt and is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

Lowries Run Slopes is a 16-acre property owned by Allegheny Land Trust. The property was set aside to protect green space in an area with more more development.

There is no dedicated parking area, so hikers are asked to park at Bruster’s Ice Cream Shop. Please stop by the shop and let them know you're hiking before setting off.

The McDade Recreation Trail extends the length of Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area. The northern start point is at the Milford Beach Boat Launch and the southern point is the Hialeah Trailhead.

The trail is crushed gravel and is best for mountain bikes. Traditional road bike tires are likely too skinny.

Check out this 4.7-mile loop trail near Edinboro, Pennsylvania. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 58 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and skiing, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through October.

This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through July. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

From the Coast Guard Park, head towards Beach 11 and follow the sandy path through the woods with views of Lake Erie. The trail ends near the jetty that leads out to Erie Harbor North Pier Light.

Be sure to walk out on the pier if the surf is not too powerful. The original light was built in 1830s but was destoryed, the current light was forged in France and brought the U.S.

The area is rich with wildlife, and visitors often report seeing everything from wild turkeys to mink along the water's edge. In early summer, the state flower, mountain laurel, blooms in beautiful clusters throughout the forest. This trail offers a truly special opportunity to experience the untamed beauty of central Pennsylvania's mountains and streams.

Enjoy this short but pleasant trail as it meanders through the woodland to a stunning waterfall. 

The land to the right side of the stream going down is private property and trespassing is not allowed. Please use the trail head to the left of the wooden sign (not the dirt road). Stay to the left of the stream to remain on public land.

Begin from the Schreffler Road Trail trailhead on White Oak Road. Proceed east into the forest. Turn right to head southeast on the Preserve Line Trail before joining the Matter Trail. Emerge on White Oak Road and connect your route. Stay aware of cars when traveling on the road.

The Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources maintains this trail.

This trail offers a wonderful opportunity to immerse yourself in nature and enjoy the beauty of the surroundings. As you wander along the path, prepare to be captivated by the picturesque views of the park's landscape. You'll be treated to tranquil waters, lush forests, and perhaps even glimpses of local wildlife.

This flat gravel trail starts at the Riverfront Park and takes you along the Schuylkill River with lovely views. Along the way, you will pass by Schlegel Park, William Penn State Forest, and end at Gibraltar Park. There are several sections where the trail crosses the river on unique bridges, making for an excellent break point from which to enjoy the views.

Get to know this 2.5-mile out-and-back trail near Clinton, Pennsylvania. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 59 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. This paved path loops around Westinghouse Park and offers a relaxing walk or bike ride. There are more than 175 trees representing over 35 different species along the way. In addition to the path, there is also a playground, pavilions, and picnic tables. There are no restrooms or other facilities at this park.

This hike travels through the woods, along Wissahickon Creek, and has some inclines and rocky areas. The trail is not marked in some spots, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful. The area is very popular, especially on weekends with nice weather. An early start is recommended to beat the crowds.

This short, level loop winds through the forest and is perfect for families and pets. It’s open year-round, making it ideal for summer activities like running and hiking and winter adventures such as snowshoeing. 
This area is also shared with mountain bikers, and there are miles of trail in this park if you enjoyed this trail and would like more options.

Discover this 1.0-mile loop trail near South Kingstown, Rhode Island. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 18 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November.

Get to know this 0.8-mile loop trail near West Greenwich, Rhode Island. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 16 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This trail network loops through the park and passes through forest, open meadows, and a swamp. There are two 19th century quarries and a diverse variety of native and introduced plant species to observe along the way. There are numerous trails here to add in for a longer hike. There is an informational sign with a map at the main entrance.

This enjoyable loop takes you around the Big River Management Area along a mix of densely forested, open meadows and a couple of ponds. It's a multi-use trail popular with hikers, runners, and bikers, with some sections being more rocky and rooty than others. Some trail junctions are not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful for navigation.

Begin from the parking area on Black Hut Road. There is an informational kiosk at the start of this route. Head into the forest, traveling clockwise past historic stone walls. Take caution when walking along Black Hut Road to connect your footsteps. Be sure to wear blaze orange during hunting season.

Experience this 1.4-mile loop trail near East Greenwich, Rhode Island. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 29 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through July. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Enjoy this 1.7-mile loop trail near Lincoln, Rhode Island. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 37 min to complete. This is a popular trail for running and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Begin from the parking area north of Putnam Pike. Loop around the mature pine forest on the east side of Hawkins Pond, following green blazes. There are ample wildlife viewing opportunities along this route. This trail bisects the orange-blazed Skeeterville Trail.

This trail is maintained by the Glocester Land Trust.

Start at the parking lot for the Diamond Hill Management Area on the west side of Diamond Hill Road (south of the Ice Cream Machine and north of Austin Drive, across from the playing fields on the east side of Diamond Hill Road). Proceed along the path starting from the information board following the yellow blazes and staying within state property. Cross over Final Flow and proceed onto Double Track Climb until it intersects with White Climb.  Bear left at that intersection, then left again at the next intersection and onto Final Flow. From that point follow the route as indicated in a clockwise manner.  Be sure to enjoy the route along the Genglenator.  After reaching the west end of the route (turning right after the first intersection after Just The Tip), turn back towards the East, being sure to take in the flat open rocky area atop Catamint Hill.  As you continue East there are a number of opportunities to cut the route short if you so desire along one of the many paths connecting the northern (west to east) and southern (east to west) segments of the route.  If you follow the full trail, you'll turn left back towards the parking lot when you return to the intersection of White Climb and Double Track Climb.

HIkers are reminded to wear blaze orange during hunting season.

Begin from the parking area on Pardon Joslin Road. Follow the Blue Trail south into the preserve. Turn onto the Yellow Trail and then loop back to the parking area. The refuge is open from sunrise to sunset. Kettle pods are found throughout the preserve.

The Audubon Society of Rhode Island maintains this trail.

Tillinghast Pond's first trail, highlighted by an old farm, a cemetery, and a boulder garden.

The Flintlock Trail takes its name from a 19th century cart path that connected Plain Road to small farm, back in the woods. The trail is blazed yellow, and accessed via the Pond Trail, from the south end of the parking lot.

Heading east from the trail junction, note the parallel tracks worn in the ground by a century of horse-and-wagon traffic.  The old trail is even clearer where it passes through a gap in a stone wall, indicating that the land was once pastured.  About a half mile down the trail, a historic cemetery tells the story of the Ellis family, who farmed the area before the Civil War.  

Just past the cemetery, the trail winds through the old farmstead, which The Nature Conservancy partially opened up for songbird habitat in 2010.  Previous owners of property lived here into the late 1980s, before it was abandoned.  The trail turns left at a small farm pond, which was re-engineered as a family swimming hole in the 1970s.

Leaving the clearing, the trail passes through a grove of majestic white pines along a wide path covered with soft needles.  A side trail offers a look at a larger, secluded pond, which beavers help maintain today.  After a half-mile on this wide lane, the trail curves left into the woods, slipping past a red maple swamp.  

Climbing out of the lowlands, the Flintlock Trail emerges into open woods, where slow-growing oaks are giving way to more vigorous white pines.  At the top of a hill, hikers have a choice: check out more of the old pasture to the right or turn left and explore a boulder garden. Either way, this mile-long segment ends where Flintlock rejoins the Pond Trail. Continue straight ahead to complete a 3-mile loop, or turn right for a longer hike around Tillinghast Pond.

Enjoy this 1.8-mile out-and-back trail near Middletown, Rhode Island. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 42 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Head out on this 0.4-mile loop trail near Charlestown, Rhode Island. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 7 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Travel around the Grills Preserve via the Orange Trail. As this preserve is open to hunting, visitors must wear 200 square inches of solid daylight fluorescent orange from the second Saturday in September until the last day of February and from the third Saturday in April to the last day in May.

The Westerly Land Trust maintains this trail.

Experience this 1.2-mile loop trail near Hope Valley, Rhode Island. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 25 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Just 10 minutes from downtown Providence, this forested trail provides scenic views of the former town reservoir.

The Lime Rock Preserve is unique for its variety of habitats including woodlands, streams, open water and calcareous ledges. The Moshassuck River and the Manton Reservoir are both highlights along the trail. The 130 acre Preserve is an excellent place to watch the seasons change, take in the views of the pond, look for birds like migrant warblers, or look for animal tracks in the snow.

Ledges of dolomitic marble produce a special calcareous soil that nurtures 30 rare plant species - more than any other site in Rhode Island. Beautiful ferns and wildflowers grow along ridges of recrystallized limestone. 

An abandoned electric rail-bed on western edge of the property provides scenic views of the former town reservoir.

This trail loop through a mostly coniferous forest. It is a good mid summer trail offering shade with some boggy areas in the middle of the loop.

The bioreserve has over 50 miles of trails and some areas are not well marked. Downloading the map ahead of time is recommended to help navigate during your visit.

The Moraine Trail winds through rolling woodlands shaped by ancient glaciers, offering hikers a glimpse into both natural history and quiet forest beauty. The path follows rocky ridges and shaded valleys, with moss-covered boulders and stone walls adding character along the way. Wildlife is plentiful, from songbirds to deer, and seasonal wildflowers brighten the understory.

Head out on this 1.7-mile loop trail near Exeter, Rhode Island. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 37 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 7.2-mile loop trail near Coventry, Rhode Island. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 33 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

The Oakland Forest and Meadow Trail is a short loop trail open dawn to dusk that goes through a 10-acre meadow and 20 acres of old-growth beech forest. It is an excellent spot for wildlife viewing or a quiet stroll through the forest. The trail can be accessed by a small gravel parking lot at the end of Carriage Drive in Portsmouth. Dogs are not allowed here on the trail because of Oakland’s unique and delicate ecosystem, Bicycles or motorized vehicles are also not allowed.

This loop is newly constructed to be wheelchair-accessible. You can continue onto a forest trail at the north end of the loop. 

Accessibility: This is the most accessible portion of the Richmond Heritage Trail https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/rhode-island/richmond-heritage-trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Kingstown Road at the south end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. 

The trail surface is stone dust or a wooden boardwalk with edge barriers. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

A wide farm road leads to a 35-acre meadow, brimming with wildflowers and dragonflies.

The features a shady, upland forest of oak and black birch, featuring lively birdsong almost year-round. Soon the path slopes gently but steadily downhill, past mountain laurel, ferns, and chipmunk burrows. At the bottom of the hill, a side trail on the left leads to a stone fireplace.  The cabin that once accompanied it has long since disappeared.

Straight ahead, the trail breaks out of the forest and a large, open field suddenly comes into view.  A mile-long grassy trail loops around the field, maintained under a contract with the Audubon Society of Rhode Island. The trail and the habitat were both enhanced in 2008, when The Nature Conservancy heavily thinned the pines on the east and north sides of the field.  A healthy shrub community of blueberry, huckleberry, and bayberry has filled in the gaps between the remaining trees, providing cover and food for a host of songbirds. 

The wide, flat trail invites leisurely exploration, and four evenly spaced benches offer opportunities to enjoy the show. Turkey vultures often glide overhead during the day, and a dozen or more deer will come out to feed in the evenings.

Begin from the parking area at the end of Shore Road. Follow the paved pathway around Sabin Point Park and enjoy views of the Providence River. There are two fishing piers.

The City of East Providence maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
It is unclear whether any designated accessible parking spaces are available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is smooth concrete and is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Begin from the parking area at the end of St. Dominic Road. Follow the paved South County Bike Path, also known as the William C. O'Neill Bike Path, east into the woodlands. Continue to the outlet on Fieldstone Drive, where parking is also available.

The South Kingston Recreation Department and Narragansett Parks and Recreation Department maintain this rail trail.

This trail is closed. We'll update this page if and when it reopens.

This peaceful trail winds through the heart of the ACE Basin on a flat, natural-surface path surrounded by salt marsh, tidal creeks, and maritime forest. It offers a quiet, immersive experience in one of the Southeast’s most ecologically rich landscapes. Trail-goers may encounter egrets, herons, and otters along the water’s edge, with sweeping views of spartina grass and moss-draped oaks creating a serene backdrop for walking, wildlife watching, and reflection.

Broxton Bridge Plantation is a private campground and equine trail riding area. The trails offer beautiful views of the Salkehatchie River and go through pine and hardwood forests. Green and white arrows mark the route. There is a fee per horse. Please visit their website for current fee rates and additional information: https://www.broxtonbridge.com/trail-maps

Get to know this 0.2-mile loop trail near Chapin, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 4 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, fishing, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. This paved concrete trail winds through the woods and along the river.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Naples Avenue at the north end of the trail. One of them is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete or wooden bridge with railings. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The entire trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Daniel Island Trail runs for about 1.5 miles along the scenic Wando River, featuring boardwalks, wide paths, old cemeteries, and beautiful views. Daniel Island boasts over 400 acres of open green spaces and parks, including Athletic Park, Etiwan Park, Governor’s Park, Waterfront Park, and Silo Park. This trail offers a picturesque route through a richly endowed natural area.

The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a short and easy hike located off of the Trekker Trail and Archer Loop. There are beautiful views of Lake Frances on the loop portion. The route begins at the adventure centers and heads north. For those who wish to extend their route, you may connect to the Archers Loop. For a longer version of the trail, check out https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/south-carolina/trekker-trail-fern-forest-and-archers-loop

The trail is in pretty good condition and offers some nice views of the river. However, it can be quite challenging for casual hikers due to a couple of steep inclines and declines. There are camp areas along the way and it's mostly easy to access the river for water or fishing. That being said, this trail is very challenging and includes lots of steep and gradual elevation gains, slippery rocks, and numerous blow-downs which make it more technical.

This is a fun trail where you can enjoy beautiful surrounding views on 40 Acre Rock. The trail is generally well-marked, but near the Beaver Pond, it's not very well-marked, so download the map before you go. There are some slick mud sections along the way so wearing proper hiking boots would be helpful. The trailhead is at 40 Acre Rock Upper Parking.

Head out on this 6.3-mile loop trail near Pauline, South Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 25 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Managed by SCDNR & The Nature Conservancy, this route follows the Green Trail around the Peachtree Rock Preserve.  This preserve takes its name from the unusual rock here, but Peachtree Rock Preserve is noteworthy for other reasons, as well, including the rare opportunity to see moisture-loving and sandy-soil plants growing in the same area. The area includes a swamp tupelo-evergreen shrub bog and a longleaf pine ecosystem. More than 245 plant species have been documented in the preserve.

Check out this 3.0-mile out-and-back trail near Slater-Marietta, South Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 17 min to complete. This is a very popular area for camping, fishing, and hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers. 

Parking
There are 4 designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles on a concrete pad in the gravel parking lot. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically 6 to 8 feet wide. 

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less). 

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

This beautiful botanical Garden is full of a diverse array of native plants. There is a lot of history to learn about this area, and it is on the National Register of Historic Places. 

The gardens are open from dawn until dusk every day of the year.

For more information on the area, please visit the Kalmia Gardens website at https://www.kalmiagardens.org/

Get to know this 1.7-mile loop trail near Edgefield, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 35 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Get to know this 0.4-mile out-and-back trail near Mountain Rest, South Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This trail is on DOD land. You must have military ID or you can obtain a Marrington Patron Pass at the Outdoor Adventure Center. It takes four-weeks to process a background check for the pass. Additionally, the trail is subject to flooding. 

Marrington Plantation has several trails with the Red loop being the main trail and the Blue trails being shortcuts (rarely used).  There are also Yellow trails, that are technical sections for mountain bikes, and an Orange trail that is tight and twisty.

There is an admission fee to enter, but it is included for guests of The Inn.

This is a registered National Historic Landmark that is full of beautiful sights to see in the area.

Right along the Ashley River, there are old stableyards, a restaurant, Inn, and farm located here.

For more information, please visit the park website at https://www.middletonplace.org/visit/tours-and-packages/

Gorgeous river and boulder field, excellent waterfall.  

Awesome hike alongside a beautiful boulder field w/ the river running through it and in some cases under huge boulders. The trail is mostly level except for the approach to the falls which runs uphill fairly steeply. The steep terrain on both sides gives that isolated feel as you go. The right turn to the falls is not clearly marked but you can see a well worn path that parallels the small river.

Managed by SCDNR & The Nature Conservancy, this route encompasses the Red and Blue trails of this preserve. This preserve takes its name from the unusual rock here, but Peachtree Rock Preserve is noteworthy for other reasons, as well, including the rare opportunity to see moisture-loving and sandy-soil plants growing in the same area. The area includes a swamp tupelo-evergreen shrub bog and a longleaf pine ecosystem. More than 245 plant species have been documented in the preserve.

The Shot Pouch Greenway is a multiuse trail connecting Dillon Park and Swan Lake-Iris Gardens in Sumter, providing a safe route for cyclists and pedestrians to access local amenities. The entirely paved trail ensures a smooth surface and features new steel bridges on Haynsworth Street and in Dillon Park. Winding through woods and meadows, the trail offers scenic views of Shot Pouch Branch and the surrounding landscape. Dillon Park includes a dog park, golf and disc golf courses, lakes, a playground, and various sports fields. Swan Lake Iris Gardens boasts multiple gardens, pavilions, a playground, and a Sensory Trail for the sight-impaired. Parking is available at Dillon Park and Swan Lake Iris Gardens.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are several designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or wooden boardwalk with edge barriers, typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

Start this trail by following the FSR and stay right at the first clearing. The FSR ends, and a narrow, overgrown trail picks up at the far end of the second clearing. 

The trail gets very steep as you approach the falls. Then, enjoy this stunning secret-feeling waterfall and a break before returning back to the trail. 

In full summer, the trail may be hard to follow with the overgrowth- bring a GPS or download the map before you go.
This trail is closed. We'll update this page if and when it reopens.

Check website for park opening times as this area is gated: https://www.scfc.gov/state-lands/harbison-state-forest/

A spur trail off of Midlands Mountain Trail, this trail incorporates views of the Broad River, moderate elevation changes, and a natural rock garden. 

This trail is shared with cyclists and hikers.

Explore this 0.2-mile out-and-back trail near Patrick, South Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 7 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This short park loop is a nearly mile-long, well-maintained paved trail that circles the open soccer fields and baseball diamonds. Parking is plentiful, and amenities are available at the north parking area. The trail is mostly exposed to the sun, but the northeast end passes under a timber ticket that surrounds a creek.

The City of Mauldin maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 24 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Take caution when traveling through the parking lots to connect the paths. Public restrooms are available near the trailhead. Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Check out this 5.3-mile loop trail near North Charleston, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 34 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Try this 1.1-mile loop trail near Madison, South Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 21 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 7.1-mile loop trail near Custer, South Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 55 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This fun bike path takes you through a variety of scenery. First you will pass farm fields before dipping into the forest. The path ends up following the Big Sioux River. This path eventually ends near the Brandon Valley Intermediate school. 

There is a parking lot for this bike path of of West Holly Boulevard. It is next to the river. 

Heads up! During the winter and spring months, or seasons of heavy rain, this trail is subject to heavy flooding that may cause sections of the route to become impassible.
