This route starts from SD Highway 244 and takes you on a steady and challenging incline with some steep and rocky sections past Elkhorn Mountain and to Black Elk Peak. The summit's views are fantastic and well worth the effort it takes to get to the top. A unique rock lookout point gives you 360 views of the forest with mountains on rock formations.

There are several road crossings along this trail that starts from the Bramble Park.

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of 10th Street Northwest at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved or packed dirt, and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type. There are benches along the route for resting.

Try this 7.2-mile loop trail near Lemmon, South Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 32 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This short trail in Hartford Beach State Park travels from the edge of the main park road up a grass and dirt path to some old burial mounds. This quiet trail is tucked in the trees the whole time and is open all year long. When it is dry, it is open to foot-traffic, and it is open to cross-country skiing in the winter.

Get to know this 2.8-mile loop trail near Rapid City, South Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 17 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking and mountain biking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Cathedral Spires is a popular attraction in South Dakota. The trail starts at the Cathedral Spires trailhead and parking lot on The Needles Highway. Parking is limited and fills up in the afternoon. The views of the Spires are stunning. In addition, you will be able to overlook the Black Hills and the nearby prairie lands. This well-marked trail has a steep gradient, rocky terrain, and a few sections with scramble-like conditions.

This trail offers captivating views of the Badlands' dramatic landscapes, with sweeping views of layered rock formations and vast open spaces. Ideal for exploring unique geology and observing wildlife, it immerses visitors in the rugged beauty of the basin. The serene atmosphere and striking vistas make it a must-visit for those seeking a closer connection to the park's natural wonders.

The National Park Service maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is wooden boardwalk with edge railings and is typically at least 7 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting. This trail has little shade, so wearing appropriate sun protection is recommended.

Along the Creek Caves Trail, impressive cave structures close to the river, steep inclines, and creek crossings are found. Depending on the season, creek waters might be knee-deep or low. The trail features some rough and slick parts with a stone bridge. Hikers are rewarded with breathtaking vistas and chances to cool down in the stream. They might also come across colorful wildflowers along the trail.

Deadman Mountain is a fun hike through some rolling hills, though this route maintains a mostly-uphill trajectory until you reach the turnaround point and then it's pretty much all downhill on the way back. There are other trails in the area which connect to this one as well, so you could make this a longer hike if that's what you're looking for!

Check out this 1.9-mile loop trail near Lead, South Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 55 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, cross-country skiing, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 1.8-mile loop trail near Pierre, South Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 30 min to complete. This is a popular trail for fishing, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

A fun loop hike out to an old mine. This trail is not well-marked, and there's a lack of consistent cell reception in the area, so please arrive prepared and consider having access to a GPS device for offline map-viewing. The route is mostly forested, but be sure to bring plenty of water and sun protection.

This is a very easy crushed asphalt trail that gently ascends past a small pond and through a valley of mostly Oak trees at Great Bear Ski area.

This quiet out and back trail gently ascends an Oak tree filled valley with benches along the way. It begins by going along a picturesque pond and then crossing the usually dry creek bed via a footbridge. There is a covered bench at the furthest point of the trail where you turn around.

The Prairie Trail on the Hartford Beach State Park property is a short path that follows a mowed-grass pathway. The trail starts and finishes within the campground and makes a loop through an open prairie. The trail is open to both foot and bike traffic, and it is also an excellent area to go bird watching.

The Hell Canyon Trail takes you to the Black Hills National Forest from a trailhead with a parking lot accessible from Mount Rushmore Road. Be prepared for rocky terrain and narrow sections—sturdy footwear is recommended, as some parts can be slippery. You will be rewarded with beautiful canyon views featuring aspens, streams, and interesting rock formations.

This paved, mostly flat, trail parallels the Missouri River. There are campgrounds along the way and several opportunities for other recreation including fishing!

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Gavins Point Road at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges), smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to steep (6-12%) uphill and downhill sections at about 3.8 through 5.2, 7.0, and 8.2 through 9.0 when going counterclockwise. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

This is a fun hike up to the top of Medicine Mountain, which sits at 6,844 feet above sea level. Not the tallest mountain in the world, but still a fun one to hike up! There are camping opportunities near the trailhead marked here, so this makes for a good day hike for anyone staying in the area overnight.

Get to know this 1.2-mile point-to-point trail near Bruce, South Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 23 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, cross-country skiing, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This area features a network of maintained trails that meander through diverse habitats, including woodlands and grasslands, leading to the Missouri River. The lower loop trail is well-maintained, offering views of both woodland and grassland bird species. A notable spot along this loop provides access to river sandbars, which are habitats for species like the Least Tern and Piping Plover. While additional footpaths exist, some are less defined and may present challenges such as dense vegetation and ticks. Visitors can choose between two parking areas: one at the southern end near the lower loop, and another at the northeastern corner, which requires a longer walk to reach forested or riverine environments. Overall, the trails offer a serene experience for nature enthusiasts, particularly bird watchers, with opportunities to observe a variety of species in their natural settings.

This trail loops around Northridge Park and the adjacent neighborhood. Parking is available on East 11th Avenue along the road. 

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of East 11th Street at the southeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. Please do not park here during school hours. The trail surface is paved concrete, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

This trail offers a journey through diverse South Dakota landscapes, including forested zones, open grasslands, and a scenic overlook of the James River Valley. Along the path, visitors encounter native flora like cottonwoods and green ash, as well as non-native species such as buckthorn. Wildlife sightings are common, and interpretive markers provide insights into regional history and ecology. The trail features wide paths, rustic steps, and a historic bridge, making it suitable for adults, children, and leashed dogs. Visitors should be cautious of poison ivy and prepare for ticks and bugs. Open year-round, the trail is also ideal for snowshoeing in winter.

Heads up! This route covers the Pelican Lake Archery Trail, which creates a small loop on the Pelican Lake Recreation Area property. The trail is a dedicated archery course with fourteen targets spread out along the path. The area is only open to archery and should be done in the direction of travel and the order cited at the start.

Discover this 9.1-mile out-and-back trail near Pierre, South Dakota. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 38 min to complete. This is a popular trail for road biking, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October.

Try this 0.3-mile out-and-back trail near Hill City, South Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 10 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day.

This trail takes you around an open prairie system. The site itself is one of the oldest sites of long-term human habitation in the United States. The river, abundant wildlife, fertile flood plains, and protection from winds made the area an important gathering place for seasonal ceremonies and a significant trading center for many tribal peoples from 1300-1700 A.D.

Explore this 2.3-mile loop trail near Spearfish, South Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 52 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through July.

Discover this 5.1-mile loop trail near Blackhawk, South Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 11 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are October through August. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The trail follows the beautiful split rock creek, past the site of the old mill dam and onto a popular rock climbing area called the South Wall.  The trail then ascends a set of stairs and steps through the middle of a large fracture in the rock, giving a close-up view of the quartzite cliffs and dramatic landscape.

Experience this 4.1-mile loop trail near Rapid City, South Dakota. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 10 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This short trail makes a loop on the western side of the Terrace Park property. The trail is a common place to spot walkers, joggers, and children on bikes. The path circles around some baseball fields, softball fields, and a basketball court, and the path also offers views out onto the expansive Covell Lake.

This trail takes you to Albright Grove in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park via Madison Bald Trail. You’ll wander through a shady forest, cross pretty streams, and walk over wooden bridges. There’s even an old log cabin to check out.

Watch your step for rocky parts and tree roots. The trail can get muddy after rain, so it’s best to go when it’s dry.

Head out on this 4.5-mile out-and-back trail near Allardt, Tennessee. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 25 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and off-road driving, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This scenic trail winds through open grassy areas and lightly wooded sections within a quiet community park, offering trail-goers a peaceful route for walking, jogging, or casual biking. The natural-surface path features gentle terrain and a relaxed atmosphere, with benches and picnic spots nearby. It’s an ideal setting for everyday outdoor activity and a calm escape into nature close to home.

Head out on this 1.1-mile out-and-back trail near Mount Carmel, Tennessee. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 39 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This short scenic and historic trail in the southern Cherokee National Forest follows Coker Creek northern Coker Creek Trailhead to the falls. The trail is easy to follow but includes short, steep climbs over bluffs, adding a challenge to the mostly creekside hike. Coker Creek Falls is a series of four major ledge waterfalls, with drops ranging from 5 to 40 feet. The area is also known for gold panning, as gold was once discovered here in Tennessee.

This is a wonderful park adventure along the Tennessee River under the Walnut Street Bridge. Plenty of benches, grass, and trash cans. Parking can be found along Frazier Avenue or paid parking lots below River Street.

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of River Street at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete or brick. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The entire trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Darwin's Revenge runs along Fort Patrick Henry Lake. The trail is lined with a canopy of mainly deciduous trees, providing ample shade along the way. You'll encounter some technical rocky sections. Despite the occasional muddy spots, the trail rewards you with lovely lake views and surrounding forested areas.

Head out on this 19.1-mile out-and-back trail near Shady Valley, Tennessee. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 8 h 9 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, horseback riding, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this great trail around Fort Donelson mixing a great nature views of the woodlands and Cumberland River with the history around Fort Donelson. 

For more information and educational opportunities, check out the visitors center before you hit the trail! Located at the main entrance, you will find brochures, exhibits, passport stamps, and restrooms inside the facility.

Park at Holston High Point and take this trail down where it intersects the Chestnut Flats Trail. From there a number of trails may be accessed. Rye Patch (2023) and Low Gap (2024) intersect and lead up or down. The Holston Mountain West trail is also accessible via the Chestnut Flats Connector (2027).

Steep grade through the forest. Pleasant but best part about the trail is the access to the rest of the trail system from Holston High Point.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Get to know this 7.9-mile loop trail near Summertown, Tennessee. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 12 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, horseback riding, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through May.

Parking for this small community park is located off Old Springfield Pike in a nicely paved lot. This area is of great importance to the overall well-being of the Mansker Creek Watershed and this park serves to protect the area while also allowing the community to enjoy natural green space. Other amenities in the park include a playground, restrooms, and open recreational fields.

This trail travels along the Barren Fork River, also known as the Barren Fork Greenway. It is landscaped to complement the riparian forest remnants along the route. The trail connects Riverfront Park and Pepper Branch Park and offers a great opportunity to stretch your legs while possibly spotting the endangered Barrens Topminnow. Activities and amenities include birding, botanizing, fishing, picnic tables, a canoe launch, and a playground.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There is 1 designated accessible parking space with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or wooden boardwalk with edge railings and typically at least 10 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (3% or less) with a short, mostly gentle (5% or less) and moderately steep (5-8%) section at the trail's south end that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

Discover this 4.7-mile out-and-back trail near Vonore, Tennessee. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 54 min to complete. This trail is great for camping and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a scenic paved route that travels along the river and offers beautiful surrounding views of the area. The path is wide enough to accommodate a variety of visitors such as joggers, walkers, and cyclists. This is an easy and flat trail that is great for families to enjoy the outdoors together. Benches are located along the way to relax and enjoy the scenery.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
It is unclear whether designated accessible parking is available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved concrete and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

The Natchez trace trail is 100's of mile long represented by intermittent segments developed into independent hiking trails. The Old Trace Walk trail is a preserved  2000 foot long section of the old original Natchez Trace following a ridge above the Duck River. 

This short section is supported by about a 10 car parking lot and signage. The signage actually identifies this trail as the "old trace walk". It shows this trail as a road on the satellite view, but had to have been restored decades ago back to the original Trace. This short trail is a great one for those with limited mobility.

Experience this 2.0-mile loop trail near Oneida, Tennessee. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 38 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through March.

Check out this 2.0-mile loop trail near Talbott, Tennessee. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 56 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Sedge Hill Trail starts at the parking lot off Little Marrowbone Road and winds through a shaded forest leading to Beaman Park. You'll find a Nature Center and another parking lot at the park. It's a short hike, but be prepared for some steep, rocky sections that can be slippery—sturdy footwear is recommended.

Begin this route at the Stone Door trailhead. The first mile can be heavily trafficked because the Stone Door overlooks are nearby, and the first quarter mile is paved, terminating at the Laurel Gulf Overlook. Beyond the Stone Door overlooks, you'll pick up the Big Creek Trail, which is markedly less populated and runs for about 3 miles to the Alum Gap Campground. From there, pick up the Greeter Trail for no more than 1/2 mile to the Alum Gap Overlook.

Check out this 0.5-mile out-and-back trail near Maryville, Tennessee. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 12 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a short and simple trail that leads from the tennis courts in Norris Dam State Park, and through a beautiful forested area. This route makes for a great family-friendly hike for those who want a nice and easy trail to explore. There are many other trails that lead from this area, and visitors can easily extend their hike.

The old Civil War roadbed leads from the saddle of the Cumberland Gap to the Tri-State Peak. From there, you can see: Kentucky, Tennessee, and Virginia. You are also surrounded by remnants of Civil War history, such as rifle trenches. You may also catch site of the elusive trailing arbutus flower in the spring.

In 1755, William Floyd inherited his father’s Mastic Beach plantation, where he later hosted such guests as Thomas Jefferson and James Madison. In 1776, he signed the Declaration of Independence, one of four New Yorkers to do so. Learn more about Fire Island NS and America's 250th Celebrations at America's National Parks™: americasnationalparks.org/americas-250th

This trail encompasses long stretches through neighborhoods and retail areas and offers plenty of interesting history intertwined with nature. Visitors can spot lots of birds and stunning flowers along the way, with occasional views. The terrain is predominantly flat gravel and mostly shaded. It offers beautiful elements and is an excellent place for safe walking, running, or cycling.

Check out this 13.5-mile loop trail near Oneida, Tennessee. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 5 h 40 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This trail travels along the southern bank of the East Fork Stone River, beginning at the East Fork Recreation Area and ending near HWY 231, where the North Murfreesboro Greenway to the highway overpass. The multi-use pass is open to pedestrians and horseback riders, so caution is advised when traveling alongside other trail-goers. The path winds through the woods with plenty of shade, wildlife, and sites of the flowing river. This route also provides access to the Yellow and Green loops, which spur from the main trail at the 1 and 4-mile marks, respectively.

Experience this 1.9-mile out-and-back trail near Tellico Plains, Tennessee. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 54 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This route is located on FS Trail 59 in the Cherokee National Forest. The trail leaves from a parking lot on your right as you enter Watauga Point. There are blue-blazed diamond markers throughout this short route.

The whole family will enjoy this area as there are many places to stop and relax while enjoying the scenery.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 5 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the World's Fair public parking lot off Grand St.

Surface
The trail surface is concrete pavers and is typically at least 10 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some moderately steep (5-8%) sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

Wooded trails, waterfalls, creek crossings, wildlife and mountain views

All trails are marked with dayglo tape. 75' from parking area is a connector trail to the Caney Fork River Trail, the Joe Hollway Rock House is on this trail. The trail is an old logging trail and follows the Caney Fork River. You will connect to the Polly Branch Falls Trail with views of Upper Polly Branch Falls. You will then connect to the Yellow Bluff Trail with side trails to Honey Pond, Boar Hog Gap Overlook and Yellow Bluff Overlook. From here continue on to end the loop hike to Scott's Gulf Road. Great year round hike but spring is a great time for wildflower lovers during peak season of mid-April there are over 50 varieties for viewing.

Check out one of the many trails near Addicks Reservoir. This peaceful trail is located between Clay Road and I-10. Majority of this trail is covered, however the gravel trail leading to the top of the hill is exposed. This trail is also suitable for any fitness level. For an urban trail, there are a variety of bird species and water snakes! So, keep an eye out!

This route takes visitors along the perimeter of Arbor Hills Nature Preserve and showcases the open meadows and juniper bushes that line the path. There is a mix of terrain and surfaces along the way, and little elevation gain. There is both sun and shade on the path, and you can customize the trail length by taking a number of different trails in the area.

This route starts on the northern part of the Bamberger Trail, continues onto the Golden-cheeked Warbler Trail, circles the Little Bluestem Loop, and then returns via a section of the Bauer Trail. If you'd like to extend the trip, you can add the Curry Creek Overlook Trail. This route has great views of the Guadalupe River.

Explore the river sections along this relatively flat and easy trail located in Bud Hadfield Park. This are can be especially bug-prone in the hot summer months, and it is suggested to bring bug spray if traveling during those times. The majority of this route travels along a disc golf path but is shared and enjoyed by hikers as well.

This scenic paved trail in Roanoke follows the course of Cade Branch, offering a winding path shaded in sections by oaks and pecans. The route passes open grassy fields, playgrounds, and neighborhood greenbelts, creating a steady mix of natural and community scenery. Along the creek, trail-goers may spot ducks, turtles, and songbirds moving along the water’s edge. With its smooth surface and gentle flow beside the creek, the trail provides a pleasant walk through a quiet green corridor.

This paved, accessible trail winds along the shoreline near the parking and picnic area, offering scenic views of the lake and dam. Visitors can enjoy spotting wildlife and pass by a unique sculpture showcasing deep prairie roots. The trail provides a relaxing stroll with beautiful lakeside scenery.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 4 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is smooth concrete and typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

This peaceful paved loop at Cheyenne Park circles open grassy fields bordered by clusters of shade trees. The smooth path passes a playground, picnic areas, and open play space, giving the walk a lively yet relaxed feel. Songbirds and squirrels are often active along the edges, while the wide lawns provide open views of the park. With its simple layout and welcoming atmosphere, the loop makes for an easy neighborhood stroll.

This trail is relatively easy, but can sometimes be overgrown depending on the season and it is suggested to download the map offline to navigate. There is a decent amount of shade throughout the area as the path is lined by shrubs and trees. Beautiful views of the lake peek out from the trail along the way.

This loop consists of Callie's Crossing, Pete's Path, Stewart's Stroll, Latta Cut-Off, Marshall Trail Klingeman Trail, and Parish Path.

This loop is well maintained and there is interpretive signage to educate visitors on the local flora. There are many intersecting trails and it is recommended to download the route offline to navigate.

The Copperfield Nature Trail begins from the parking lot off East Yager Lane, where you'll also find a playground and pavilion. The parking area at the trailhead is limited, so arriving early is recommended. This beautiful hike in the Northern Walnut Creek Greenbelt winds through a shaded forest and along Walnut Creek, featuring small wooden bridges and benches along the way.

Take a peaceful and scenic walk through the desert with beautiful plants and flowers lining the trail. It can be easy to take the wrong turn or lose the trail and it is suggested to download the offline map to navigate. The trail is rocky and can be uneven, so wearing the appropriate footwear is recommended.

Try this 4.2-mile loop trail near Jacksonville, Texas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 12 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This community park features a paved loop trail that winds through its recreational areas, including sports fields and playgrounds. The smooth surface is ideal for walking, jogging, and biking, accommodating visitors of all ages and fitness levels. As you traverse the loop, you'll enjoy views of open green spaces, mature trees, and well-maintained landscapes, providing a pleasant environment for exercise and leisure activities.

This paved path runs from near Northbrook High School to Gessner Road and is part of the already constructed section of the planned Spring Branch Trail. The full trail is proposed to connect the White Oak Bayou Greenway to the Chatterton Dairy Ashford Hike and Bike Trail. 

The City of Houston maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
Street parking is available near the trailhead, but there do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces nearby.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 9 feet wide. Bollards at street crossings temporarily reduce the tread width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Take caution when crossing roadways; designated crosswalks are present. This trail has little shade, so wearing appropriate sun protection is recommended.

This is a well-maintained trail that travels over a wide and sandy surface. There is a decent amount of elevation change through the winding hill country, and there are several overlooks to see the surrounding area. Take a quick spur trail to the overlook trail for more of a big viewpoint of the park itself.

This is a paddle route meant for kayaking, canoeing, or other forms of paddling- it is not a hiking route. The put-in is located at the Confederate Reunion Grounds State Historic Site and travels along the Navasota River until it connects with Springfield Lake. If you do not wish to do this as a point-to-point paddle, you can return the way you came as the water is relatively calm.

This scenic paved trail winds through a peaceful neighborhood park, curving gently around a small pond and open grassy fields. The smooth concrete path follows flat terrain, with benches placed near the water for restful views of ducks and turtles along the shoreline. A few young trees provide light shade, and the route passes a playground and picnic area. The setting feels calm, well-kept, and ideal for a relaxed walk beside the pond.

This scenic multi-use trail runs through the woods south of San Gabriel Park, offering miles of flowy, natural-surface tread perfect for hiking, running, or gentle bike rides. The path stays mostly flat and has a family-friendly, easy rating. It is shaded in places by mature trees lining its route.

The trail traces close to the San Gabriel River, weaving through woodlands and grassy clearings. Shaded stretches and bench-cut curves add interest and rhythm to the walk.

Accessibility:

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking  
Street parking is available near the trailhead on East Ln, but there are no accessible parking spaces nearby.

Surface  
The trail surface is smooth concrete and typically at least 10 feet wide.

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

This is a straightforward trail to Jacob's Well. The route follows a dirt and gravel track to the impressive artesian spring. Swimming is only available seasonally, and visitors must book in advance. The passage down to the well is steep and narrow, with some large boulders to navigate around. Parking is available at the trailhead.

The majority of this trail is exposed and travels through open fields- bringing sun protection is advised. The Medina Loop can be challenging with loose rocky terrain and short climbs while the Pasture Loop is flat and enjoyable. Along the way, visitors can see remnants of the previous ranch as well as an oak oasis providing nice shade to rest beneath.

This scenic paved loop circles a calm lake, with smooth concrete paths curving past open lawns and a playground. Ducks and turtles are often seen near the shoreline, and a small fountain sends ripples across the water. Live oaks and cedar trees provide pockets of shade, and benches beneath their branches offer comfortable spots to pause and take in the view.

This beautiful boardwalk is a great area to explore for all ages. This is a nice even trail that makes for a perfect choice for beginners. There is little shade along the way, and it is suggested to bring some form of sun protection. Wildlife can be seen in the open areas and an incredible variety of birds can be observed.

This natural surface path in Houston guides trail-goers through wooded areas and grasslands, following an old roadbed. The trail begins near Sullins Way, just south of Pavilion 8, and passes by the historic Hillendahl-Eggling Cemetery. As it continues, the path crosses Patterson Road and leads into a forested area, eventually connecting with another trail marked by an old concrete cattle guard. Due to poor drainage in some sections, the trail can remain muddy after rainfall, and mosquitoes are prevalent; visitors should come prepared. The trail is not maintained, so visitors are advised to avoid disturbing the ground or vegetation.
Error: Failed to load page

This is a paved trail that goes around the edge of baseball fields, soccer fields, basketball courts, and fitness stations. 

Accessibility: There is a paved parking lot off of Enterprise Boulevard, but it is unclear if there are any designated accessible spaces there. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least six feet wide. The estimated grade is flat (1% or less), so this trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the trail for resting.

The Sauceda Nature Trail is an easy hike that loops the Sauceda complex just to the south. It passes through a country typical of this part of the Chihuahuan Desert, comprised of remnant desert plains grassland interspersed with desert shrubs and succulents. The trail traverses a ridge composed of lava-like that is found in the Bofecillos Mountains to the west. It is mostly exposed rock and does not have a maintained tread.

There are signs along the route that identifies some of the most common plants you will see elsewhere during your visit to the Big Bend. From the top of the hill, you can enjoy the park’s best views of La Mota Mountain and the historic Sauceda complex.

The Greenline is a linear park that offers a beautiful hiking and biking trail for the community to enjoy. There are also fitness stations, playgrounds, pavilions, lakes, and open fields to enjoy recreational opportunities. 

This park also connects neighborhoods and businesses at City-Base with the Mission Reach of the River Walk.

Check out this 0.2-mile loop trail near Rockport, Texas. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 3 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

This family-friendly hike travels through an open area along a sandy trail. There is very little shade along this route and it is advised to bring sun protection. While there are not many views along the way, there is a diverse variety of plants and wildlife to observe in the area. For those who wish to extend their hike, there are many other connecting trails in the park.

While not particularly scenic in terms of viewpoints, there is still a lot of diversity in flora and fauna to admire on this charming hike through the forest. There is plenty of shade along the way, making for a great option to escape the summer heat. This trail is great for families with young children because it is well-marked and easy to follow.

Try this 3.6-mile loop trail near Woodway, Texas. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 11 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Discover this 2.1-mile out-and-back trail near Moab, Utah. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 9 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Discover this 13.3-mile loop trail near Moab, Utah. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 49 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Enjoy this 4.1-mile out-and-back trail near Lindon, Utah. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 8 min to complete. This is a very popular area for backpacking, camping, and hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This off-road driving loop is generally best suited for ATVs and dirtbikes. Stock vehicles like Jeeps and trucks may be able to complete the route but would have a hard time fitting on the trail in most places. There are some sections of wide single track, for example. This area is beautiful, but the trail is also hard to follow in spots - so come prepared with a backup battery and map.

Head out on this 23.2-mile point-to-point trail near Bluff, Utah. Generally considered an easy route. This trail is great for camping and off-road driving, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Head out on this 7.0-mile out-and-back trail near Morgan, Utah. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 40 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, hiking, and horseback riding, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are December through December.

Enjoy this 4.0-mile loop trail near Heber City, Utah. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 2 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, cross-country skiing, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This loop starts at Snowbasin Lodge to Needles #1 to Last Chance #10  Green Pond #11  and then loops back to start. This route is open to hiking and mountain biking during the summer months when the ski mountain is not in operation. These trails close during the winter months when snows and snowmaking operations begin. 
Around half of the trail is shaded by trees, there is also a pond along the route (the trail's namesake).
The Snowbasin trails are marked by metal signs numbered 1-12. The trails are as followed: 1. Needles; 2. Mooonshine Trees; 3. Porcupine; 4. Philpot; 5. Diamond. 6. Sunshine; 7. Middle Bowl; 8. Becker; 9. Elk Ridge; 10. Last Chance; 11. Green Pond; 12. Snowbasin; 13. Maples; 14. Cirque Practice Loop; 15. Family Loop

Well-maintained forest service road to trailhead. Any vehicle clearance should be fine. One creek crossing 7-8 miles after turning off route 95.

While visiting Bears Ears National Monument, please remember to Visit With Respect. Visiting With Respect means leaving all archaeological artifacts where you find them, keeping dogs out of archaeological sites, and refraining from touching structures, pictographs, or petroglyphs. Learn more here: www.bearsearspartnership.org/visit-with-respect

Explore this 3.6-mile out-and-back trail near Kamas, Utah. Generally considered a challenging route. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are June through September.

Easy, but adventurous, drive to high scenic pass.

A short drive takes you through easy parts of Kane Creek Canyon to pleasant views from 4,780-ft. Hurrah Pass. Indian petroglyphs at the Birthing Rock. BLM and private camping along paved Kane Creek Road. Designated camp spots in Kane Creek Canyon. Stay on existing roads at all times. Arrive early on summer weekends to get best camp spots. You can continue down other side of pass to Chicken Corners (available as eGuide from FunTreks on EveryTrail). Located on BLM land. For current status call Bureau of Land Management, Moab Field Office at (435) 259-2100. 

Rating: 

Easy. A wide gravel road most of the way with occasional small ledges and steep spots last 3 miles. Suitable for two-wheel drive vehicles with high ground clearance under ideal conditions. Several water crossings on Kane Creek Road are usually shallow, but they can be deep and fast flowing in the spring or after a downpour. Don't cross if you can't see bottom and be prepared to wait awhile if you get trapped on other side.

Try this 14.4-mile out-and-back trail near Ibapah, Utah. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 10 h 28 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October.

Experience this 5.1-mile out-and-back trail near Ivins, Utah. Generally considered a challenging route. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are November through May.

Discover this 3.1-mile out-and-back trail near Oak City, Utah. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 46 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Enjoy this 6.7-mile out-and-back trail near Brian Head, Utah. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 50 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, hiking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This trail, managed by Sundance Resort, is a summer hiking and running trail. It offers beautiful views of Mount Timpanogos, Stewart Falls, and the Uinta Range. To access the trail, you'll park at Sundance Resort's Lot E. The route takes you on a steady uphill climb through meadows, sagebrush, and Douglas Fir stands.

The Cottonwood Loop ride begins from Marysvale City Park. First, head up the north slope of Cottonwood Canyon. There are spectacular views from 10,000+ feet, including a secluded waterfall. Then head down into Miner’s Park, a restored mining district, with walking tours and restrooms, old mining camps, and operations. After that, a beautiful drive down Bullion Ave then back out at Hwy 89, cross the hwy and back to Marysvale.

The next part which is called The Couples' Special ride begins at the Marysvale City Park. Go north on #02 to Trail 24 and then on #22 to #74 will take you to Hoover’s Café. The route then takes you up beautiful Deer Creek Canyon along trail #74 to the main Paiute #01 trail, then down into a steep descent where you can the devastation of last year's fires. Grab lunch at Rose Ranch, across from the Fremont Indian Park, where you can see ancient petroglyphs and pictographs carved/painted into the cliff faces. The ride then doubles back along the #01 and back down into Marysvale.

Head out on the Phelps Canyon Trail for a challenging adventure in the Wellsville Mountains! This steep trail is a great workout, but it rewards you with a bird's-eye view of the alpine area. Sections of the Phelps Canyon Trail are heavily overgrown, and the upper half of this trail must be blazed.

Discover this 12.9-mile out-and-back trail near Hanna, Utah. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 5 h 35 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, birding, and fishing, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Simple short trail that provides access to Bonneville Shoreline and meets back up with Quail Trail Loop. Theres the option to fork out to the Quail Loop trail earlier on on the way back to explore some different terrain. This is a great short hike to do if you live or work nearby and want a quick escape. 

The mild elevation gain makes this suitable for biking, hiking and trail running.

The Rim Overlook Trail begins with a gradual climb with little shade. Numerous markings and signs are present along the way for hikers to use as navigational aids. Bighorn Sheep and other wildlife are common sightings along the trail. The trail is home to various plants, such as prickly pear cacti and woodlands of pinyon and juniper. 

The trail passes by a few highlights, including the Hickman Bridge Viewpoint, which provides stunning views of Pectol's Pyramid. This remarkable mountain is flanked by volcanic rocks contrasting sharply with the light sandstone slabs. At the peak of Rim Overlook Trail, hikers are rewarded with a 180-degree panorama, which stretches for miles on a clear day. The breathtaking views extend to Scenic Drive, Sulphur Creek, and the Fremont River vistas.

Rock Canyon Trail offers a hiking experience with beautiful trees and stunning rock formations. The trail is well-known for rock climbing, with bolts placed throughout the canyon and some excellent bouldering spots. Bring waterproof hiking shoes to explore the creek more comfortably. Sledding down the trail is popular in winter due to its decent slope, providing numerous sliding spots. 

The trail is also adorned with wildflowers. The terrain is steep and rocky. About halfway to the Rock Canyon Cave, there is a refreshing water fountain where you can refill your water bottle. The cave has a low ceiling about 100 meters deep, so a bright headlamp or flashlight is recommended. There's also an exciting charcoal drawing at the back.

The trail ends at Rock Canyon Campground, which offers beautiful views and amenities. The campground has numerous picnic tables, fire pits, and tent spaces. The terrain varies from flat to sloped, catering to different camping preferences.

Park at the Yellow Pine Trailhead to take the Scenic Byway Trail to the Cedar ATV Trail. Then, begin the Failure Canyon ATV Trail before doubling back on the trail. Take extra water and snacks because you'll be hiking up above 7,400'. Be aware that this trail is open for multi-use, including dirtbikes and OHVs. Enjoy the riparian areas and forests alike on this adventure!

Enjoy this 10.8-mile loop trail near Highland, Utah. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 43 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November.

In the Southern Utah sea of slot canyons, the end of this one (the shelves that give it its name) is truly unique! Thanks to its slant, this canyon sees very little daylight and stays cool in the heat of summer. This route is not a trail, it is a technical canyoneering route that involves scrambling and other obstacles. 

Park at the second parking area for the Canyon Overlook Trail; it is the small canyon immediately to the north.

Check out this 11.2-mile loop trail near Moab, Utah. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 18 min to complete. This is a very popular area for camping, hiking, and mountain biking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

The hike through Albion Basin to Cecret Lake features wildflowers during the summer. Cecret Lake is a great mountain lake that sits below Sugarloaf Mountain and Devils Castle. Sugarloaf Mountain is one of the easiest peaks to summit topping out over 11,000 feet. There is a bit of scrambling along the ridge going from Sugarloaf pass to Mount Baldy, as well as the descent along the ridge once you turn north. There are incredible views of the Alta ski area and numerous peaks of the Wasatch Mountains.

Check out this 3.2-mile loop trail near Lake Powell, Utah. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 15 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and off-road driving, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

• Canyonlands National Park charges a fee to enter. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. For more information, please see https://www.nps.gov/cany/planyourvisit/fees.htm

Upheaval Dome is the most puzzling geological feature in Canyonlands National Park. A 1.7-mile hike visits two overlooks along the rim of this three-mile wide 1,000-foot deep crater. Geologists have two possible theories for what caused Upheaval Dome, which you can learn about along the trail.

From the trailhead, a wide track heads to the right before turning uphill toward the crater. Built-in stone steps aid with the ascent of 150 feet over 0.3 miles. When the trail comes to a junction, turn right and you will quickly reach the first overlook of Upheaval Dome.

The trail is an unpaved road that starts from the gate right before the water tank. The scenery is very pretty, the whole area is very quiet, and the end of the hike is rewarding as it takes you to the Wet Sandy River, a very relaxing place to rest before making the trip home. Make sure to do it on a cool day or a cloudy day because it’s completely exposed.

Starting from the Taylor Campground, this route leads to the base of Moses and Zeus, a pair of iconic 500-foot sandstone spires in the remote Taylor Canyon. Taylor Campground is a remote, primitive backcountry campsite located deep within the Island in the Sky district of the park. Hikers may need a 4X4 to access the trailhead.

This route takes you along a steady, challenging, yet rewarding incline on a well-maintained path with some steep and rocky sections. Sturdy shoes are recommended for this hike. The path takes you to Bristol Ledges, where you will be rewarded with stunning sweeping views of the Deer Leap Natural Area.

Experience this 3.0-mile out-and-back trail near Brandon, Vermont. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 14 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

The trail begins on Chittenden Brook Road which is off Brandon Mountain Road/VT Route 73. The trail heads through the forest and travels along Chittendon Brook and near the campground.

A trail also leaves from the campground and connects to the main trail. The Chittendon Brook Trail ends at a junction with the Long Trail.

Begin from the trailhead on Grout Pond Road. You will start out by following the Hilltop Trail which is inland from the pond. This will meet up with the West Trail which heads towards Somerset Reservoir and then back towards the starting point.

These trails are open year-round, but should be avoided during the spring mud season.

Enjoy this 3.8-mile loop trail near Huntington, Vermont. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 52 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, mountain biking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

Very little elevation gain, don't bother with the short loop near the beginning of the trail that goes down to the river. You don't see much that you didn't see walking to the trailhead. You'll go through the woods for another half mile or so, then the trail bends to follow the reservoir to a park (complete with picnic tables and port-a-potties).

This trail loops through open fields behind the visitor center at the state historic site. As you make your way through the fields there are views of the nearby Green and Taconic Mountains.

Hubbardton Battlefield was home to the only Revolutionary War battle fought entirely in Vermont on July 7, 1777.

This trail is fun and provides an awesome view at the ski lift on top of Sugarbush Ski Resort. 

It is a beautiful trek through the woods with some steep rocky sections and a little brook.

While Mount Ellen is one of the few 4,000 foot peaks in Vermont, the summit is wooded. So soak in the views from the top of the ski runs.

This trail goes along the west bank of the Connecticut River north of the Wilder Dam.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
It is unclear whether designated accessible parking is available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is natural dirt, grass, or asphalt and typically ranges from 2 to 5 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
There are bleachers and picnic tables along the route for resting.

Enjoy this 0.8-mile loop trail near Quechee, Vermont. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 20 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through October.

This stretch of the Long Trail crosses over the summit of two of Vermont's 4,000-foot peaks, Mount Ellen and Mount Abraham. There are wonderful views of the Mad River Valley below while you hike across ski runs at Mad River Glen and Sugarbush ski resorts. 

For those looking to spend the night camping, there are some established GMC shelters along the route.

You will encounter some steep sections of the trail with iron rungs in place while hiking up from App Gap.

Enjoy this lovely trail that explores Lowell Lake State Park. This is a lovely family-friendly trail that explores the forest and shores of Lowell Lake. The terrain is very uneven in spots, and there are some narrow boardwalks and stepping stones to consider. 
For more information about the park, please visit: https://www.vtstateparks.com/lowell.html

Cady Hill Forest is one of the largest and most popular trail networks in Stowe. On a nice weekend in the summer and fall you should expect to see plenty of other hikers and mountain bikers. The area is a recognized as a deer wintering area by Vermont Fish and Wildlife. Be sure to wear blaze orange if you're hiking or riding here during hunting season.

Enjoy this 4.3-mile out-and-back trail near Springfield, Vermont. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 56 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and snowshoeing, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The Mount Independence Trail in Vermont offers a mellow hike with a historical twist. Walk where Revolutionary War soldiers once stood, with views of Lake Champlain and ruins to explore. The trail meanders through classic Vermont woods – think maples, birches, and wildflowers. Informational signs tell the story of the fort. It's a chance to enjoy nature and learn some history.

Explore this 3.6-mile out-and-back trail near Eden Mills, Vermont. Generally considered a challenging route. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November.

On this exciting hike, you will start at the Hogback Mountain Parking area and climb an enjoyable yet challenging hill along Tower Trail. This trail takes you through a lush green forest with information boards along the way and stunning views of the area. It then takes you to Mount Olga and the Fire Lookout Tower, where you will be rewarded with sweeping, impressive views of Molly Stark State Park.

The summit of Mount Worcester provides breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding valleys, forests, and nearby peaks, including other parts of the Green Mountain Range. On clear days, you can see as far as the Adirondacks in New York. The top of the mountain is a fantastic spot for a break, allowing hikers to take in the natural beauty of the area while enjoying the quiet solitude of the summit.

Get to know this 3.2-mile out-and-back trail near Middlesex, Vermont. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 40 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through October.

Enjoy this 2.3-mile out-and-back trail near Fairlee, Vermont. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 12 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Experience this 6.0-mile loop trail near Groton, Vermont. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 23 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are April through October.

The Pease Mountain Loop offers hikers stunning views of the Green Mountains and Lake Champlain. As you trek through the trail, you'll meander through white pines and lush hardwood forests. Be cautious of muddy and slippery sections, especially after rain, and watch for exposed roots along the path that can make footing tricky.

Discover this 5.3-mile loop trail near Jonesville, Vermont. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 58 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through October. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

Explore the beautiful woodlands on your way up Putney Mountain! The trail travels through the forest made up of maple, birch, and hemlock trees, which are common to Vermont. Keep an eye out for forest creatures like chipmunks or maybe even deer. The summit is a special place, known as a great spot to watch for migrating hawks, especially in the fall!

Experience this 1.1-mile loop trail near Ascutney, Vermont. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 36 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Experience this 2.5-mile point-to-point trail near South Strafford, Vermont. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 18 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Enjoy this 3.6-mile loop trail near Morristown, Vermont. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 44 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and snowshoeing, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through October.

Follow the path from the parking area south to the Tubs. This destination offers views of gently eroded waterfalls and shallow rock pools for wading and swimming. Take caution when exploring the area, and watch children near the water as the rocks can be slick.

Parking is available off Fowlers Way.

Begin from the park behind Warren Elementary School past the tennis courts and skate park. The Warren Path heads up hill and then detours off onto the Vista Trail. From the top of the Vista Trail, there is a great view looking across the Mad River Valley towards Sugarbush Ski Resort and the ridge line near Mount Abraham.

This path follows a small brook at points and passes some old stone walls before arriving at the cemetery.

Here you will find several graves from the early to mid-1800s, including those of Civil War soldiers. Plaques have been placed by some of the tombstones that are more worn and faded so you can read what the inscriptions say.

Williams Woods may be the best remaining mature valley clayplain forest in the Champlain Valley. This forest type is composed of white oak, red oak, red maple, white pine, shagbark hickory and white ash. Associated species include hemlock, sugar maple, beech and bur oak. Although this forest type once covered thousands of acres in the Champlain Valley, woodlands like these are now rare.

Travel through the Wolcott Family Natural Area on a mix of hardpack dirt trails and boardwalks. There is a small parking area on East Road with limited room for vehicles. Cross Pond Brook along this route, which offers views of the wetland environment.

This trail is managed by Winooski Valley Park District.

Discover this 7.8-mile loop trail near Rileyville, Virginia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 56 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are November through December. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 9.1-mile point-to-point trail near Catawba, Virginia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 50 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, birding, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October.

Experience this 29.1-mile out-and-back trail near Crozet, Virginia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 14 h 52 min to complete. This is a very popular area for backpacking, camping, and hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November.

Explore this 20.3-mile out-and-back trail near Glasgow, Virginia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 11 h 43 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This is a great short trail to do if you're short on time and in the Big Meadows area of the park. The start is easily accessible from Big Meadows Camground. The trail heads uphill and leads to Blackrock Overlook. From here there are views of the rolling mountains and deep valleys. This is a great trail for kids to do!

This trail follows a section of the Appalachian Trail from Salt Log Gap to Punch Bowl Crossing. It is popular with backpackers on multi-day hikes. The trail is a steady incline, with some steep and rocky spots, but it gets easier as you go. You pass by Punchbowl Mountain, which has scenic views, and Bluff Mountain, which features stunning sweeping views of the area.
This trail is on private property. Please head somewhere else unless you've been invited by the owners.

Explore the unique sea-level fen community of the Mutton Hunk Fen Natural Area. This short route begins from the parking area and heads southwest through excellent bird habitats.

The parking area can only accommodate eight vehicles - if the designated spots are full, please return to the preserve later.

Discover this 14.8-mile out-and-back trail near Jamestown, Virginia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 28 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and horseback riding, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 5.9-mile loop trail near Lightfoot, Virginia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 6 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 8.4-mile point-to-point trail near Chesapeake, Virginia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 23 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This route takes you on a trail behind the Elkton Community Center. For a good portion of the hike, the trail runs along the Elk River, offering peaceful sights and sounds. The majority of the trail is shaded, making it very enjoyable. Yellow trails connect the riverside and the community center side.

This hike features several picturesque overlooks as it passes through woodlands of varying ages on Loft Mountain.

From the north end of the Loft Mountain Wayside Parking Area (mile 79.5), cross Skyline Drive and follow the blue-blazed Frazier Discovery Trail. Go right at the intersection and follow the steep uphill grade. Turn left where the trail joins the Appalachian Trail, staying on the blue-blazed trail. Turn left again at the next trail post to descend to your starting point.

Check out this 0.2-mile loop trail near Lyndhurst, Virginia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 5 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through November.

Begin from the Hidden Pond Trailhead, located at 10776 Belmond Boulevard. Follow the Hidden Pond Trail east through the woodlands to the pond's shores. Anglers with appropriate permits from the Virginia Department of Wildlife Resources can fish the pond.

The Bureau of Land Management maintains this trail.

Begin from the Ivy Creek Overlook at mile 77.5 along Skyline Drive. From the overlook Loft Mountain, Flattop, Weaver Mountain, and Brokenback Mountain. You will follow the Appalachian Trail down to Ivy Creek. There are some nice small cascades along the creek to stop and relax at before hiking back uphill.

The Jones Point Lighthouse itself is a fascinating piece of history. Originally built in 1855 to guide ships navigating the Potomac River near the Washington, D.C., area, it has been restored to preserve its historical significance. The lighthouse stands as one of the last remaining river lighthouses in the region, offering a glimpse into the past and a reminder of the area's maritime heritage.

Try this 0.4-mile loop trail near Newport News, Virginia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 8 min to complete. This trail is great for walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 1.0-mile out-and-back trail near Hood, Virginia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 29 min to complete. This is a very popular area for camping and hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 4.3-mile loop trail near Fredericksburg, Virginia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a popular trail for mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through November.

Discover this 5.7-mile loop trail near Lynchburg, Virginia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 59 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through November.

Enjoy this 0.8-mile out-and-back trail near Portsmouth, Virginia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 14 min to complete. This trail is great for running and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Enjoy this 0.9-mile out-and-back trail near Carrollton, Virginia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 16 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Head out on this 0.2-mile out-and-back trail near Portsmouth, Virginia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 3 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This route mostly follows the Appalachian Trail with a few loops to switch up scenery. It contains the park's two highest points in one route starting from the Little Stony Man parking lot on the Skyline Drive.

Expect sweeping panoramic views from the rocky summits of the valleys and mountain ridgelines.

Start near the Harry F. Byrd Visitor Center and Big Meadows Wayside. The trail is mostly wooded and crosses over a creek. Some stretches are close to the road so expect some road noise.

You will pass by the Big Meadows Air Quality Station, which works on researching the air in the Shenandoah region.

This trail is part of the new Clinch River State Park. https://www.dcr.virginia.gov/state-parks/clinch-river

The Sugar Hill Loop Trail traverses an open (bald) ridge line high above the Clinch River just outside of the town of St. Paul, Virginia. Views from the trail include a panoramic overlook of the Virginia Ridge and Valley and the Clinch River itself. This trail also features the remnants of an 18th-century settlement midway through the hike.

Sugar Hill is actually part of a larger trail system situated on a conservation easement just outside of St. Paul. A number of other trails share a trailhead with this loop, allowing for several longer hikes to be pieced together between this area, the town of St. Paul itself, and another conservation easement at the Bluebell Island Preserve just upriver from town. Collectively, these trails form one of the most diverse areas for outdoor recreation and varied scenery in the entire southwest Virginia region.

Discover this 3.8-mile loop trail near Mount Solon, Virginia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 12 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This section of the Tuscarora Trail starts at Rt. 50 right next to the bridge over Back Creek, on the south side.  New guard rails have blocked off the parking area next to the trail head.  The trail starts by following Back Creek for a little while and then crosses Back Creek.  The ford here was removed, and crossing can be tricky.  The trail then parallels Back Creek on the east side for while before turning east and up a small ridge.  After joining an ATV trail, the trail turns left and passes near the Barclays Run Shelter.  After a short climb, it turns south and runs parallel to an old logging road.  After crossing under the power lines, it runs southwest criss-crossing the logging road/ATV trail several times. At the intersection with the ATV trail near a cabin, you can return on the Tuscarora, or take a easier route back along the road bed.  After crossing under the power lines again, re-join the Tuscarora back to the start.

The West Dike Trail extends from a parking area near the visitor center all the way to the boundary with False Cape State Park.

The trail is mostly loose gravel, so it is not recommended for road bikes.

The East and West Dike Trails alternate opening, so check out the East Dike Trail if this is closed during your visit.

White Rock Falls features a 30-foot-tall waterfall that cascades into a peaceful watering hole. The trail leading to the falls is a mix of dirt paths and some sections of rock scrambling. As you journey through the dense forest, the sound of a flowing stream accompanies you. Along the way, scenic vistas open up, allowing you to pause and take in the natural beauty of the surroundings.

This trail starts at the Thomas Walker Civic Park parking lot and leads to White Rocks in Cumberland Gap National Historical Park. It ascends through the forest to a rocky summit. Be prepared for steep sections with exposed tree roots and rocks—sturdy footwear is recommended. Your effort will be rewarded with panoramic views of rolling hills and dense forests stretching as far as the eye can see.

In 1755, William Floyd inherited his father’s Mastic Beach plantation, where he later hosted such guests as Thomas Jefferson and James Madison. In 1776, he signed the Declaration of Independence, one of four New Yorkers to do so. Learn more about Fire Island NS and America's 250th Celebrations at America's National Parks™: americasnationalparks.org/americas-250th

Enjoy this 4.3-mile out-and-back trail near Natural Bridge Station, Virginia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 48 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

This trail ends at a beautiful gorge with a cascading waterfall. The NRA is only open for day use, no camping. The nearest campsites are Turnwater and High Bridge and both of these require a backcountry permit. 

You can not use the Agnes Creek trailhead to reach this trail, as that leads to the PCT.

Begin near the Austin Pass Picnic Area and head towards the larger lake with Bagley Creek flowing into it. After this, follow the creek towards Lower Bagley Lake. The trail loops around the lake and crosses a bridge before heading back to the trailhead. During the winter months, this is a popular snowshoe route.

This is a fantastic trail in Wenas Wildlife Area. The hike offers stunning vistas of Adams, Rainier, and the Stewart Range. It's an exposed trail, so make sure to carry enough water and wear sun protection. The ascent is very steep and rocky. The trail begins at Canyon Road, with parking available nearby.

Discover this 5.4-mile out-and-back trail near Mazama, Washington. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 41 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.
